name: Presidente. –
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday 19 September 2019.

name: Le Président. –
text: It was with great emotion that I learned of the death of Mr Jacques Chirac, President of the French Republic. A man attached to his country, to the city of Paris, he was also a great European. An early MEP, he has always advocated peace, tolerance and democracy, Europe's founding values. Our sympathy goes to his family and to the French people. I would like Parliament to pay tribute to him.

name: Presidente. –
text: I would also like to say a few times to remember those who lost their lives in the recent shipwreck near the coast of Lampedusa. We are at the umpteenth shipwreck. I would like to, but I know that it is also your feeling, not to have to speak in this House any more to talk about the deaths in the Mediterranean, but only to discuss concrete measures to put an end to this tragic situation. I would like to be close with you to the German police, to the German people, to the German Jewish community. German police confirm that at least two people were killed today in Halle, one of Saxony's most important cities in the east of the country, and that the attacker is on the run. The situation is not yet clear. Our thoughts are with the families, friends of the victims and German citizens. For these reasons, I would ask you to observe a minute's silence. (Parliament, standing, observed a minute's silence to pay tribute to the victims and in memory of Jacques Chirac)

text: The final draft agenda, established by the Conference of Presidents pursuant to Rule 157 of the Rules of Procedure, was distributed at its meeting on Thursday 19 September 2019. Wednesday The Council and Commission statements on the "2021-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework and Own Resources: It Is Time to Respond to Citizens' Expectations" are moved as the first point to Thursday morning. text: Are there any objections to everything we have said? If there are no objections, the amendments which I have proposed to you and which have been proposed by the political groups are approved. name: Tilly Metz
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, sorry for starting too early before. Together with our coordinator, we believe that it is the right time for a debate on authorisations of GMOs. As some colleagues will know, in its last sitting Parliament adopted 36 objections to GMO authorisations.  The resolutions outlined concerns we have surrounding health risks due to gaps in safety assessment, and they also highlighted the Commission’s lack of respect for democracy in the decision-making process.  The Commission continues to authorise GMOs despite lack of support from Member States, and Parliament’s objections. Tomorrow, the Parliament will vote on three new objections and the new Commission will shortly start its mandate.  This is therefore a good moment for this new Parliament and the Commission to exchange views on this issue. I hope colleagues can support this request.

name: Presidente. –
text: As far as Wednesday is concerned, the GUE Group and the Green Group have called for the Statements by the Council and the Commission on how to avoid conflicts of interest in the European Union to be added as a third item this afternoon, following the Commission's statement on the greening of the European Investment Bank.  I give the floor to Mr Beazley. Mr Aubry to make the request on behalf of the GUE Group.

name: Manon Aubry
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as the sequence of hearings of the European Commissioners, which in this Chamber can be satisfied with the record of the conflict of interest review procedure, comes to an end? Like it or not, doubt has settled, it is enough to see the number of questions from all the political groups that have been devoted to ethics and integrity during the hearings. The experience of the last two weeks illustrates all the flaws in the current procedure, which is sorely lacking in resources, time and independence to be sufficiently robust and credible. As the confidence of European citizens in their institutions is crumbling, it is time to put in place the mechanisms to fully guarantee the integrity of our European leaders. That is why we are offering you a debate on the prevention of conflicts of interest in the European institutions. This moment of exchange, which we propose without resolution at this stage, in order to obtain the widest possible support from our House, must bring us all together. The vote on this debate, which we are calling for with a roll call, added as the third item on the agenda, is a unique opportunity to show citizens that we prefer ethics over money.

name: Karen Melchior (Renew).
text: Mr President, thank you for the opportunity to continue the debate we have had in the JURI Committee in recent weeks. It is a bit of a shame to have a debate in plenary, without really having had time to look at the substance in the committees, which are the place of intensive debate in this Parliament. But I am in favour of a debate in plenary, which we may be able to pursue further on the merits in the JURI committee where Mrs Aubry also sits.

name: Presidente. –
text: With regard to Wednesday's agenda, the GROUP of the European People's Party has requested that a Commission statement on the fight against cancer be added as the last item in the afternoon before the one-minute speeches. The debate will end with a resolution that will be voted on tomorrow. I give the floor to Mr Beazley. Liese to make the request of the PPE Group.

name: Peter Liese
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the intention of the European People’s Party (EPP) is that we establish a non-permanent committee on the fight against cancer. Cancer is a disease that still kills too many Europeans, and, during the campaign, we learned how important this issue is for our citizens. We know that the new Commission also wants to make it a priority. Europe cannot solve the problem alone, but without Europe we will not solve the problem. I ask you to support this request, especially as coordinator of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI).  ENVI is responsible for public health, but we have many other issues, for example, the Green Deal. We also need to work together with the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE), the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (EMPL) and colleagues from other committees. That’s why I think this non-permanent committee would be a good opportunity. I understand that some groups are not prepared to support the resolution this week, because they need some fine-tuning on the text. Our compromise proposal is therefore to have a debate today and then, in two weeks’ time, we will have the resolution for the exact mandate of this non-permanent committee. Please support us in the fight against cancer.

name: Jytte Guteland
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Of course, we from the S&D Group support doing everything we can to fight cancer. We do not want any families to have to go through the suffering and pain that it means to see the person you love get sick and at worst get carried away from you. Many of us have experienced this and have memories of what it means. We think it is important that we can take the debate on this in plenary and show that we want to do this work thoroughly.  On the other hand, it is important to separate the issue and ensure that the resolution work is done in the best possible way. We therefore want a separate vote on the fact that we should have the debate here in plenary. At the same time, we shall make the resolution the right way. I would then like to say to Mr Liese and the PPE that doing so thoroughly is about going back to the Committee on the Environment and health and ensuring that the fight against cancer is taken there. With all the experts there are, all those Members who have the necessary skills, that is where we will work against cancer prevention in the best way. The best way to combat these diseases is to prevent the root causes of people becoming ill. Ladies and gentlemen, it is important that this work is done properly. The citizens of Europe deserve only the best. Everyone in this Parliament has a responsibility to do what we can to help. Then it must not be a catch. It shouldn't be at the wrong level. It will be done in the ENVI Committee, and it will be done together with all those who have the competence to ensure that we work out how best to prevent these diseases.

text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the preparation of the European Council of 17 and 18 October 2019 (2019/2711(SRR)).

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Dear President, the tugboat "Bourbon Rhode" owned by the French shipping company sank on September 26th in the Atlantic, 2000 km from the French island of Martinique. The result of the search so far is the discovery of three survivors and the bodies of the four dead seamen. Seven seamen are still being sought, including the ship's captain, Dino Miškić. I hereby urge the leaders of all 28 Member States of the Union who can in any way help locate and rescue these 7 seafarers, to do so. The very essence of the European Union lies precisely in the mutual solidarity of individual Member States, which can offer genuine added value to this community and its citizens. It is difficult for me to come to terms with the announcement by the French crisis headquarters Cross of Martinique that the search was abandoned with such ease, especially when some people are known to have been rescued even after more than 50 days at sea. Dear colleagues, I am convinced that each of us cannot even imagine this feeling (the speaker took his word away from the speaker)

name: Presidente. –
text: Mr Tomašić, we are starting a debate. We are starting a very important debate. For communications, please ask for the floor earlier, but not when I have already begun to discuss an agenda. I would also ask those Members who are leaving perhaps to stay for a moment because this debate is really important. We are talking about the preparations for the European Council meeting of 17 and 18 October. I would like to thank Mr Juncker, Mr Barnier and Minister Tuppurainen for being with us today. However, I also need to make a few comments, at the very beginning of this debate. As you know, I was invited yesterday by Prime Minister Johnson to London for talks with him. I would like to inform the House because I have taken to Prime Minister Johnson the position that the European Parliament voted on in the last plenary session on the issue of Brexit. Despite some confidence and hope, I have seen that there is not much progress at the moment. As you know, any agreement reached between the Eu ropean Union and the United Kingdom must obtain not only a vote in the House of Commons but also the approval of the European Parliament. Therefore, it is crucial for the Prime Minister to know our position.  Our approach is very simple: we think that an orderly Brexit, a UK exit with a deal, is by far the best outcome. As I explained to Prime Minister Johnson, however, the European Parliament will not accept an agreement at all costs. We will not accept anything that would undermine the Good Friday Agreement and the peace process or undermine the integrity of our single market, as was made abundantly clear in our resolution last September.  We have looked at the proposals put forward by the UNITED Kingdom recently as an alternative to the original back stop. Our assessment of Prime Minister Johnson was that they do not, at the moment, constitute a basis for reaching an agreement. These are ideas, but they are not proposals that are feasible, immediately feasible. There are two alternatives to an agreement at the moment: extension or no agreement. Parliament is, of course, open to the possibility of an extension if there are valid reasons or precise objectives. But requesting an extension is the UK's responsibility and prerogative.  With regard to the possibility of no agreement, I was very clear that this would be a very negative result, which would have serious economic consequences for both sides, but particularly for the United Kingdom and its citizens. A failure to reach agreement would clearly, however, be the responsibility of the British Government. As for the citizens, I reiterated to Prime Minister Johnson that the European Parliament will continue to ensure that their rights are protected, whatever the scenario. I also had a fruitful meeting this morning with House of Commons Speaker John Bercow. I have expressed to him my view that any request by the UK institutions to extend the withdrawal period should serve to give the british people the floor again – as this House has said – by means of referendums or general elections. With John Bercow there has been full consonance about the importance of the role of our parliaments in managing Brexit and there is a common awareness that a disorderly UK exit from the European Union would be against the interests of british and European citizens. I very much hope that a no-deal exit will eventually be avoided, even though in that case the European Union has taken all the necessary measures to prepare for and deal with the consequences.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Grazie President, honourable Members of the Parliament, next week’s Council comes at a crucial point. At the upcoming European Council meeting, leaders will be discussing some of the most pressing issues for the Union. Let me start with the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) on which the leaders will have the first substantial discussion. You will recall that the June European Council conclusions expressed the ambition to aim for an agreement before the end of the year. The Presidency has pursued work in line with that ambition. During the past months we have consulted and had extensive discussions with Member States in order to identify their priorities and where the so—called room for negotiation lies. We have now prepared a presidency paper to frame discussions at the October European Council. I believe it will be a good starting point for the leaders to provide further strategic guidance and indications for the Presidency’s MFF work.  The European Council will also discuss the strategic agenda, which leaders adopted in June. After four months they are keen to know how it’s been implemented within the Council, but also, crucially, how it is reflected in the future work of the other institutions, particularly in the Commission work programme. This is why Commission President—elect Ursula von der Leyen will attend the European Council and expand on this point with leaders. It is reassuring to see the largely similar objectives of the strategic agenda and Ms von der Leyen’s political guidelines. Of course, the exchange of views between the leaders and the President of the European Parliament will also be the perfect opportunity to hear the views of the Parliament. Beyond the discussion on the strategic agenda, leaders on this occasion will also formally appoint Christine Lagarde as the President of the European Central Bank. Now, the next topical issue on the agenda is climate change, an existential threat that has been, and still is, at the centre of attention, not least after the discussions in New York. We, as a Union, need to help raise global ambition and continue to lead the way on climate action. This is because we may soon reach a tipping point where we can only mitigate the effects of climate change instead of reversing them. But it is only with concerted global efforts that we can successfully tackle this global phenomenon. So, at the meeting in October, leaders will focus on the international aspects of climate change. They will discuss the outcome of the United Nations’ efforts at the climate summit in New York and they will prepare for the upcoming COP25 in Santiago de Chile in December. I cannot exclude, however, that during the discussion leaders may touch upon the EU’s climate objectives, too. Under external relations, it is likely that the leaders will discuss Turkey in light of its continued drilling activities in the eastern Mediterranean and take into account also broader EU—Turkey relations, including cooperation in migration. The recent developments related to Syria are likely to come up in this context as well and we have just received very worrisome news today. Leaders will also discuss enlargement where the General Affairs Council discussions on the 15th October will be crucial in relation to Albania and North Macedonia. And, honourable Members, finally, Brexit is an issue that is likely to steal the limelight. As you know, on 2nd October the UK submitted proposals to overcome the extremely thorny backstop issue. These proposals do not yet provide a basis for concluding an agreement, but the EU remains fully committed to work with the UK and avoid a no—deal Brexit. Although we are prepared to face it, it would be irresponsible for both sides to ever claim that a no—deal scenario is an attractive option. This would have serious consequences on our borders, our customs, our trade, on our citizens’ rights, all fundamental issues for both the EU and the UK. And yet, the UK crashing out is a dangerously realistic scenario, given the constantly evolving situation, leaders will have to take stock of the very latest developments and decide how best to proceed. So, thank you very much for your attention and I look forward to our discussions.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President der Kommission. Herr President, Frau Ratspresidentin, meine sehr verehrten Damen und Herren Abgeordnete! Ich fasse mich kurz, weil wir heute Nachmittag relativ spàt in die Gànge gekommen sind und die Frau Ratspràsidentin Wesentliches zu der Tagesordnung des Europeischen Rates gesagt hat, deshalb macht es keinen Sinn, sich hier in 'berflàssigen Wiederholungen zu. Als ich vor fenf Jahren hier antrat, habe ich ein Versprechen abgegeben, und das Versprechen war, dass die Kommission bis zum letzten Moment versuchen wird, konkrete Ergebnisse im Interesse der europeischen Bàrger vorzulegen. Ich stehe zu diesem Versprechen und hoffe, dass der Europ-ische Rat und der Ministerrat dies auch tun, denn die beiden haben ein 'hnliches ' wenn nicht sogar dasselbe - Versprechen abgegeben, das auf dem Tisch das Hauses liegt - Wir messen jetzt die Grundlagen fàr ein stabiles, handlungsf-higes Europa der kommenden Jahre schaffen, und dies setzt voraus, dass wir dringend die Verhandlungen zum mehrj-hrigen Finanzrahmen voranbringen bzw. abschlieen. Dies setzt voraus, dass wir uns mit aller Entschlossenheit im Kampf gegen den Klimawandel bew-hren, und dies setzt voraus, dass wir uns fàr die Stabilitet unser Region und dar-ber hinaus einsetzen. Sehr wichtig ist eine Einigung 'ber den mehrj-hrigen Finanzrahmen. Der Gipfel nechste Woche muss yesterday wirklich wesentliche Fortschritte erzielen, weil sich die Menschen in Europa auf die politische Fàhrung in der European Union verlassen kunnnen messen. Ich bin missvergn-gt, wenn ich dieses Gepl-nkel zwischen Mitgliedstaaten, zwischen Mitgliedstaaten und Kommission, zwischen Mitgliedstaaten, Kommission und Parlament beobachte. Wir sind nicht auf der Hàhe unserer Aufgabe. Wir sollten jetzt weniger reden und endlich zu Beschlàssen kommen, weil es sehr darauf ankommt, dass wir sicherstellen, dass europeische Forscher ihre Projekte fortsetzen kunnnen, es kommt darauf an, dass junge Menschen ihr Erasmus und es kommt darauf an, dass die geplanten Infrastrukturprojekte vorankommen. Deshalb messen wir das Budget - den budget-ren Rahmen - schnell beschlieen. Die Kommission hat relativ fràh - meiner Erinnerung nach im Murz, April, May 2018 - ihre Vorschl-ge zur mehrj-hrigen Finanzplanung vorgelegt. Anderthalb Jahre Debatte ohne erkennbare Fortschritte! Wir haben nicht noch einmal anderthalb Jahre Zeit. Wenn wir nicht zu Potte kommen vor Ende dieses Jahres, spàtestens Anfang nechsten Jahres, wird es nicht meglich sein, die Projekte, die Programme, die Absichten, die Initiativen, die geplant sind, in die Tat umzusetzen. Machen wir nicht noch einmal den Fehler, den wir bei der letzten mehrj-hrigen Finanzplanung gemacht haben, bei der wir uns erst einen Monat vor Inkrafttreten des Finanzrahmens geeinigt haben, was zur Folge hatte, dass wir zwei wertvolle Jahre verloren haben - von 2014 bis 2016 Es reicht jetzt! Wir messen uns beeilen, denn es geht nicht um uns, es geht nicht um die Institutionen, sondern es geht um die Menschen in Europa. Ohnliches gilt fer die Herausforderungen, die im direkten Zusammenhang mit der Migrationsproblematik stehen. Auch hier hatte die Kommission im Frahjahr 2015 Vorschl-ge vorgelegt. Die wurden mit qualifierzierter Mehrheit im Rat angenommen, die werden aber nicht umgesetzt. Ich hette gerne, dass der Europeische Rat sich diesem Thema wieder voll zuwendet und dafar sorgt, dass hier Fortschritte erzielt werden. Migration ist wichtig, der Haushaltsrahmen ist auch wichtig. Ich wise yesterday, was ich gestern gesagt habe und was ich 'bermorgen wiederholen werde' - also solange ich hier noch herumspuken kann: Wer denkt, dass europeische Aufgaben der Zukunft innerhalb eines Finanzrahmens von 1% of the kollektiven Reichtums der Europeischen Union Ich sage dies dem Parlament, ich sage dies dem Ratsvorsitz, und ich werde dies auch dem Europeischen Rat noch einmal eindringlich in den H-rkanal einflie-en lassen.  Mr President, it is clear that climate change is one of the major challenges ahead. We were the first major economy in the world to commit to the Paris Agreement, which would not have been possible without the European Union. A legislative framework, rules and not just words must now be put in place in order to achieve all the objectives of this agreement, by stimulating investment and social justice, which is not the least of the problems in the sectors in transition. It is clear that climate neutrality must be achieved by 2050 at the latest. It is no less clear that the global transition to achieve the goals of the Paris Agreement must accelerate. It is in this spirit that the multiple trade agreements of the European Union, which we have concluded in recent years and which are legally binding, will continue to contain specific commitments on the implementation of the Paris Agreement, as will our agreement with Japan and also the agreement signed with Mercosur, which does not betray the objectives of the Paris agreement. And while we can doubt the goodwill of those who are supposed to implement them, the fact remains that, for the first time in the history of the European Union, and therefore for the first time in the history of trade agreements, we have insisted on environmental standards AND social standards. So we have an instrument that we can use to get the most recalcitrant, the most reluctant to do what they have promised to do. I will say, Mr President, one or two words about enlargement. I said at the beginning of my mandate that there would be no further enlargement or membership in the legislature. Some of you have been saddened by this and this has also caused outrage in the Western Balkans region. But it is clear that to be responsible, one had to be sincere. It was absolutely clear that there would be no enlargement between 2014 and 2019. But if it is right and justified to be sincere, we must also be sincere towards those who want to join. Northern Macedonia and Albania have made substantial progress. That is why President Sassoli, President Tusk, President-elect von der Leyen and I have written a letter to the Member States urging them to keep the promises that had been made to the countries of the Western Balkans, including Northern Macedonia and Albania.  When Europe has a strong will, there is always a way to achieve the commonly accepted objectives. I take as an example the Prespa agreement between Northern Macedonia and Greece. The European framework and the European perspective have helped to resolve a conflict that has lasted for decades. The reforms that Albania has undertaken with courage allow us to envisage, not generously but favourably, the opening of negotiations with Albania and Northern Macedonia. But enlargement is not an end in itself. It is not enough to expand. It's not enough to expand galore: no! It is also a question of deepening the european construction by building on the values that are common to us, and which should not be abandoned when joining the European Union.  I would like to add some words on Turkey, which is characterised by relations with the European Union which are as complex and as important as ever. Turkey is, of course, a key partner for the European Union, not least when it comes to cooperation on migration. My full commitment, and that of the Commission - and, hopefully, that of our Union - to the implementation of the EU-Turkish statements of 2016 remains clear. The facility for refugees in Turkey continues to deliver concrete results on the ground, and this should not be forgotten. There are other issues on which I cannot be so complimentary when it comes to Turkey's illegal drilling operations in the eastern Mediterranean. I have to repeat that in this respect (in others too, but mainly in this respect), I'm a Cypriot, and I will remain in full solidarity with Cyprus. Turkey has security concerns at its border with Syria. However, I call on Turkey, as well as on the other actors, to act with restraint and to stop operations - already, as we are speaking, on their way. This military action is not leading to a good result, and we have to bring this to the attention of our Turkish friends. And I have to say, if the Turkish plan involves the creation of a so-called safe zone, don't expect the European Union to pay for any of it. A sustainable solution to the Syrian conflict and only be reached through a genuine political transition. President, dear honourable Members, as the European Union moves forward, we must also deal with the departure of a Member State. That was the choice of the British people, not a choice of a few European Union - although we are respecting that choice. As it stands, we remain in discussions with the United Kingdom on the terms of its departure. And personally, I don't exclude a deal. Michel and myself are working on a deal, and we are not accepting this blame game which started in London. We should not be blamed. But we'll see in the coming days how things will develop. My friend Michel Barnier will elaborate on this. I would like to repeat, for the attention of our British friends, that there is not only a parliament in Westminster that has to agree; there is a Parliament here. Without the agreement of the European Parliament, nothing will be possible.  I promised to be brief. As always, I didn't keep my promises.

name: Michel Barnier
text: Chief Negotiator. Mr President, Madam Minister, ladies and gentlemen, with your permission, Mr President, a few words in addition to what President Juncker has just said. So the British negotiators have given us their proposals and with their own team, which is a competent and professional team - I want to say this - they are trying to explain to us, to clarify , we ourselves are asking a lot of questions in all the technical meetings that have taken place in the last few days.  And to put it simply and frankly, objectively, as I speak to you, we are not at the point of considering and reaching an agreement, as you yourself have, Mr President Sassoli, reminded Prime Minister Johnson with great clarity, a great deal of strength - and I thank you on behalf of Parliament - yesterday.  And yet time is running out, ladies and gentlemen. We are now one week away from the European Council and a few days away from that date of 31 October, which was agreed with the previous government for the UK's exit from the European Union in an orderly form which, as you said, is much better than a disorderly exit. Why aren't we there? Because the British proposals raise three major problems. First on the issue of the border and control over property on the island of Ireland. Prime Minister Johnson rejected the backstop, which is a kind of insurance or safety net that we had agreed on with Theresa May's government, as soon as he arrived. At the same time, Prime Minister Johnson recognises that regulatory alignment for goods is essential between Northern Ireland and the European Union and we obviously agree on this point.  On the other hand, in order to solve the problem of customs controls, the United Kingdom simply proposes that we make a legal commitment in the international treaty that binds us to avoid, in all circumstances, customs or regulatory controls and any physical infrastructure on the border between Ireland and Northern Ireland. Of course, we share this objective, which is one of the objectives of the backstop: that there be no borders, no infrastructure. But what we are really asked to do is to accept a system that is not developed, that is not tested, of controls scattered on the island of Ireland and this would be largely based on exemptions, derogations from the European customs code, technologies that have yet to be developed, changes to international law which is provided for by the common transit Convention and finally a new compliance system but without the guarantees that are provided for by the protocol.  Ladies and gentlemen, we need at every limit of the single market and our customs union, we need at each of these limits of customs controls, serious and rigorous regulatory controls everywhere, outside, at the external border of this single market. In Ireland, as everywhere else, we need operational controls, real controls, credible controls. It is the credibility of the single market that is at stake and therefore the credibility towards consumers, businesses and also, we do not forget, the third countries with which we negotiate agreements. That is the first point of disagreement. The second point concerns the requirement that we believe is legitimate to find legally operational solutions. With the protocol, we have established a safety net that clarifies the applicable regime on the island of Ireland and this safety net is legally operational as it would apply until we find until and unless an alternative solution. By proposing to remove this safety net, to remove the backstop and to look for alternative solutions during the transition period, that is to say later, the British proposal does not give us the security of the protocol. An example: there is no real solution for small and medium-sized enterprises in these British proposals, except to propose a general exemption. Second example: what would happen if the joint committee, to which the British want to return all the unanswered questions at this time, did not reach an agreement during the transition? According to British projections, the solution would then depend on the adoption of unilateral measures to be taken by the United Kingdom or by the European Union. There would then, of course, be a significant risk to the integrity of the single market, since the British proposals would at the same time commit us to never providing for control at the border between Ireland and Northern Ireland, which will become two different jurisdictions. The third point of disagreement, as I speak to you, is obviously that of the British proposal on consent. We have always regretted Stormont's absence for two and a half years to give a strong and strong Northern Irish voice in our negotiations. In the existing protocol, we have mechanisms with the British that allow the representation of Northern Ireland. We are ready to re-examine new ideas for a greater role for the Northern Irish institutions in implementing the protocol in accordance with the Good Friday Belfast Agreement.  But today, the British proposal, as it is on the table, is simply to condition the implementation of the protocol on a unilateral decision by the institutions of Northern Ireland, which could then unilaterally decide, from the outset, the day after the ratification by your House and the House of Commons of the withdrawal agreement, not to activate at all the solution proposed for Northern Ireland. And then, if it were still activated, the Northern Irish authorities could decide every four years to challenge it. Ladies and gentlemen, the British Government's proposal today as it is - and we cannot accept - would replace an operational, practical, legal solution with a hypothetical and temporary solution. Finally, there is a fourth point which really causes us problems, which is not about the withdrawal agreement but about the political declaration, which is next to the withdrawal agreement and which is very important, because it describes what will happen after Brexit, with an agreement, I hope, and even without agreement, it is not a destination , everything that has been unravelled - 44 years of integration and cooperation - will have to be rebuilt with the United Kingdom, and a relationship will have to be rebuilt in all areas: trade, security, universities, fishing, aviation, police and judicial cooperation, defence and security. And we describe with the British government the framework of this future relationship in this political statement.  Today, Mr. Johnson is asking us to focus on the future of our economic relationship only on a basic free trade agreement and not on other options, which we had left open in the political declaration. It also asks us to remove the agreed references with Theresa May on a very important point which is the level playing field, that is, a basic rule of the game, a foundation of loyalty and rules of the game in tax matters, state aid, social rights, environmental rights, consumer rights. That is it, and so we are facing this demand. (Applause) We are faced with this demand, which suggests the risk for us, with a basic free trade agreement, of having to face regulatory competition, or even a risk of tax, social or environmental dumping, which we will not accept. That is why I say, on this point, that the ambition and level of our future free trade agreement with the United Kingdom - because there will be a free trade agreement - will be proportional to the level of commitments made by the British authorities for a sustainable rule of the common game. Ladies and gentlemen, Mr President, no one in London or elsewhere should be surprised that the European Union is committed to achieving legally sound and sustainable operational solutions in this withdrawal agreement. What for? For an extremely simple reason, Brexit, when it happens, will be sustainable. Because Brexit today creates - as we know and I have said for the last three years - concrete, precise, serious problems, in particular, and first in Ireland and in relation to the concrete, precise, serious, immediate problems created by Brexit, we need today and not tomorrow operational solutions that are legally binding for both sides and that are precise. In the serious and important moment we are at, we will remain, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as we have always been, calm, vigilant and constructive at the same time as we remain respectful of the United Kingdom and those who run it. It is in this attitude and with this attitude on both sides that we can have the ambition to reach an agreement that works for both sides.  We will therefore remain with our team, which is your team, in constant cooperation with the European Parliament, with the Brexit steering group - and I thank its members and in particular Guy Verhofstadt - with all the Member States, we will remain available 24 hours a day, in the days to reach an agreement. It is in this spirit that I will meet again tomorrow with the British Minister Steve Barclay.  I just want to say that, in the scrupulous respect of the mandate given to us by the European Council, in accordance with the resolutions - you yourself have spoken of your last resolution, Mr President - those of the European Parliament, which are very important to me, we will continue to work. I think I can say today that, although it is very difficult , for the reasons I have just indicated, if there is goodwill on both sides, an agreement is still possible with the British. (Applause)

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats President Sassoli, President Juncker, Mr Barnier, representatives of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to begin by thanking you for the solidarity you have expressed today with the victims of Halle. Mr President, there has been an attack on Jewish life on German soil, and that is a shock to everyone, especially me as a German. That is why Thank you for that. This horrific crime that has taken place must be condemned. I would also like to thank the police. Anti-Semites and all those who question the freedom of faith are not only our opponents, they are our enemies. We are all called upon to stand up and say 'no' to anti-Semitism. (Applause) Mr President, we are preparing the European Council, and I would like to begin by following on from the important basic messages of Jean-Claude Juncker. People now expect clear answers from us to the tasks of our time. In these hours, these days, there are many mayors, regional ministers in Brussels, because the Committee of the Regions meets. And they are waiting for answers: what will happen to the financing of regional support, with the MFF? Can we continue to finance our projects on the ground, yes or no? Many people are attached to these MFF plans and that is why we in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats expect progress to finally be made at this summit. I would like to thank the Finnish Presidency for the progress made on the matter, but the bosses must now also take care of it. I would like to make one thing clear to us, namely that the MFF discussion is not, first of all, a discussion about percentages, but about the political projects that we want to implement. And if certain countries in the European Union continue to insist on having only percentage discussions, then we must counter that these announced percentages will not be able to cope with the very tasks that lie ahead. We will not be able to make a master plan for Africa. We will not be able to strengthen Frontex. We will not be able to tackle the research work in the fight against cancer and, ladies and gentlemen, we will also have to make concessions on how we promote our regions. With all these tasks, we now need clarity, and that is why I hope that the Council will achieve results here. Secondly, of course, I would like to address the likely top issue– Brexit. First of all, I am less concerned with the content, because we fully support Jean-Claude Juncker and Michel Barnier and we thank them for the work we have done to keep Europe together and to describe clear negotiating lines. It is well known that he can count on our support in this. What drives us more, what drives me more, is the style that has now moved into the debate. If there is a phone call yesterday between Boris Johnson and Angela Merkel and then this is exactly what is happening, that we accuse each other of not making progress in the talks, then we have to ask ourselves what happened. What is actually happening in the foundations when, unfortunately, God's party politics are obviously more important than the interest of the country that these negotiations are supposed to be about? For me, it is a sign that Boris Johnson's ideas were not presented at a plenary debate in the House of Commons, nor in talks with Jean-Claude Juncker, but that Boris Johnson's initiatives on the future of Brexit negotiations were presented at the Tory party conference. This shows very clearly that it is obviously not a question of reliable, sensible negotiations, but of party politics, and this must also be branded, it must also be said that for a serious politician, for sensible politics, it is important to bring together interests and not to divide a country. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she Trade policy is one of the things that still concerns us as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats. I would just like to mention that we now have WTO decisions, and I hope that we will now bewise to act wisely between the United States and Europe, namely to find a common path that does not lead to a trade war. A trade war would bring joy to others, but not to Europe, nor to America, and that is why we need the outstretched hand to the Americans in order to resolve these conflicts now. Finally, i.e. a thought on the question of Turkey, which will also move us. The list is now long: illegal migration is increasing again, and it does not appear to be stopped by the Turkish authorities. We have drilling in Cypriot waters, obviously illegal activities. We have the fact that a kind of backstop solution is now being practised via the Turkish-occupied territories in Cyprus, unregulated products are coming onto the European market. We have the military activities, which are very worrying, where we know that the Kurds were partners in the fight against ISIS and helped us there, and the general question of the values of freedom of the press in Turkey. That is why I hope that Turkey, as a partner, will continue to take the European Union's partnership approach seriously. On the other hand, we should also ask whether the good economic relations between the European Union and Turkey can be maintained in the long term if, unfortunately, we have a partner with Turkey who is more aggressive than a partnership. We are ready for partnership in all these areas, but Turkey must also know that if the partnership is not practised, it will have consequences.

name: Iratxe García Pérez
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the next European Council debate on 17 and 18 October plans to discuss a set of key challenges for the future of the European Union: the budgetary framework for 2021-2027, the Union's priorities for the next five years, Brexit and climate change. Our aspiration for a tightly united Peoples' Europe will only come true if we are able to agree on a strong budget. With the Resolution to be voted on tomorrow by this House, we reaffirm our firm commitment to the priorities and items included in the interim report on the Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027, which we will adopt in November 2019. Additional financial support is essential to carry out the commitments made by the President-elect of the European Commission and, in particular, for a fair ecological transition. We have been waiting since November to be able to enter into negotiations with the Council, which means that we have wasted almost a year. We therefore call on the Council to begin negotiations for the next budgetary framework and remind it, moreover, that this budgetary framework is decided by codecision; that is to say, we will not tolerate any attempt on the part of the Council to undermine the prerogatives of this Parliament. Just as we will not approve the next multiannual budget if agreement on the reform of the European Union's own resources system is not reached first. Because only with an ambitious budget will the Union be able to meet the priorities of the Strategic Agenda for the years 2019—2024. Within the framework of the Strategic Agenda, heads of state and government have a responsibility to urgently fulfil the following priorities: the development of the European Pillar of Social Rights, which is an absolute priority in order to move forward in a fairer Europe; reform of Dublin's asylum and immigration system; the mainstreaming of the Sustainable Development Goals in the European Semester, and the objective of a climate-neutral Europe by 2050; the combination of banking and tax union and the fight against tax evasion to ensure a fair contribution to the strengthening of the Europe of well-being. Only by responding to these priorities can we eradicate the populist discourse that fiercely plagues our continent; a discourse that only understands patriotism as a weapon against the other and not as the defense of a common good. This is the same speech that arrincona to Prime Minister Boris Johnson and which leads to his country, which has been a beacon of democracy and enlightenment, to the darkness of ignorance and inscrace. For this reason, we will not accept your government's proposal to replace the Northern Ireland Protocol with a new protocol that does not envisage the so-called backstop. Let us be clear: the Social Democrats will only support a proposal to prevent a border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland. Any solution should avoid putting the peace process at risk and protect the integrity of our single market, in defence of consumers and businesses. Our political family is strong, as we have done in the past Plenary in which we adopted the Resolution. We are prepared to support an extension of Article 50 to avoid a Brexit without agreement because it would harm us all - let us be clear - to all, to Europe, to the United Kingdom, to citizenship as a whole. And we are also talking about issues that are currently fundamental on the Agenda: the fight against climate change. In this context, the recent New York Climate Action Summit has shown that only the European Union can exercise the leadership needed in this area. The fight against climate change and compliance with the Paris Agreement and the Sustainable Development Goals are of vital importance for the European Union and developing countries to face the devastating economic, social and environmental consequences caused by human activity. Consistent implementation of the Union's different external and internal policies and a robust financial framework for the implementation of adaptation and mitigation measures are key to reducing the impact of global warming. On 17 and 18 October, a window of opportunity to solve the problems of citizens opens before the leaders of the European Council. This Parliament is ready. It's in your hands.

name: Dacian Cioloş
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, the Council will have the Brexit issue on the agenda again. I welcome the fact that the UK Government finally produced some proposals last week, but I am also very concerned about their content. We have always been open to workable and legally operable solutions, but let's be clear: as they currently stand, they cannot be the basis of an agreement. As they currently stand, we will not and cannot support them. Any new UK proposals need to respect the Good Friday Agreement, protecting our citizens and the integrity of the single market. We have grave concerns about the UK proposal, not least fuelled by the latest recriminations arriving from London. This is not and should never be a blame game. We still have time to avoid a no-deal situation that would be catastrophic.  Speaking now of the budget, which is also on the agenda of the Council's debates, we must have a clear perspective on the direction we want to give Europe. The European budget is linked to the political direction we give to Europe, it is not just numbers. Let us not forget that our constituents and citizens expect us to implement the program we committed to in July. We need political perspectives, but we also need fiscal perspectives. The European budget is not just about numbers, it is also a political vision, a vision of the added value of Europe. This is the time to prove that we are, in fact, assuming this European project. A real European budget should have its own resources. We must have the courage to address this subject, not to avoid it, and to find a way to share the burden of this budget between the contribution of the Member States and the own resources, in order to have a clear vision on these budgetary perspectives. Mr Sassoli, in front of the Council, you will have to carry, on our behalf, a strong ambition for the budget, because Parliament has a strong ambition for Europe and Europe needs the budget.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, dear colleagues, so goes the story: a good-willed British Prime Minister is honestly seeking a balanced solution to the Brexit conundrum. But he is confronted with a hostile and antagonistic, inflexible European Union, conspiring with traitors back home, concentrated in the British Parliament and the judiciary, whose sole aim would be to frustrate the will of the people and surrender to the enemy. This is the story that Prime Minister Johnson wants to tell.  The reality is that Prime Minister Johnson does not want a deal. Listen, if we were to sign the British proposals, we would commit – forever – to keeping a 500 km stretch of EU external border, with no controls – forever – without any firm guarantee that goods crossing that border would meet EU regulatory standards – notably, safety and security standards – and with no guarantee that customs tariffs would be paid. That is the kind of blank cheque that Prime Minister Johnson wants us to sign. No jurisdiction in the world would ever accept this, especially from a neighbour whose stated intention, as has been repeatedly said, is to undercut the European Union’s social and environmental taxation standards. No one would accept this.  But you understand: these proposals are not there to be accepted. They are meant to lead the country to a no—deal Brexit for which the EU27 could be blamed. It’s not hard to read into Prime Minister Johnson’s game. And it now depends on all responsible women and men within the British Parliament to prevent this from happening and to muster their collective strength to put the interests of the country front and centre. Now, dear friends, I will just say one thing. We are all Members of Parliament here and we are proud of this. I listened to Prime Minister Johnson’s speech at the Tory Party Conference the other day. A few days after having illegally attempted to close down his Parliament, that Prime Minister was openly mocking, humiliating and deriding Parliament – the Parliament from which his own legitimacy derives. Dear friends, when chiefs of the executive – in any country – trample like this on parliaments, what is at stake is democracy.

name: Nicolas Bay
text: On behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, Mr Juncker, Mr Barnier, on Brexit, you say both no to Boris Johnson's proposal, not to an exit without a deal.  You reject the British government's proposal, when it is clearly a balanced position in that it allows both Britain's exit from the European Union and the customs union, which is the democratic will expressed by the British more than three years ago, and that it respects the Good Friday agreements.  You present the backstop negotiated between you and Theresa May (but against the advice of the British) as a 'safety net'. But you know very well that it is much more than that. In reality, it is about keeping Britain in all the european Union's arrangements, with the same financial contribution, and this situation could last until the thorny problem of the Irish border is resolved. You are well aware that the position you are defending is unacceptable to the British, unacceptable to the majority in the House of Commons, and that it results in a situation of total deadlock for which you will bear responsibility. With regard to the multi-year financial framework, which will be at the heart of the debates of the next Council, there are two pitfalls on which we will be very vigilant. The first is the inflation of expenditure, the increase in the budget, the ever-increasing expenditure of the European Union, which is also always further removed from the concerns of the citizens and in particular from what they have expressed to the last Europeans. The other pitfall, of course, is the idea of own resources: a European tax system that would not replace national taxation but would be added to it, making the tax burden in our states ever greater.  And, finally, I saw Mr Macron among the Heads of State, Mr Timmermans among the European Commissioners, speaking recently to condition the European Union's Structural Funds on respect for the so-called rule of law, obviously targeting Poland, Hungary and a number of other countries.  They should still remember that in the last European elections, the Law and Justice party in Poland, Viktor Orban's Fidesz in Hungary, were the parties that, in all countries, all political parties combined, achieved the best results. They are the ones with the greatest democratic legitimacy.  This should encourage the European Commission to respect them, because the Commission will never have the legitimate democracy that these heads of state and government have. Even though the European Union refuses to condition the financial aid granted to African countries to control their migration flows, it would at the same time want, within the European Union, to ban countries and deprive them of the financial resources to which they can legitimately claim on the pretext that they would not respect an alleged rule of law which has in fact become a political weapon against them.

name: Raffaele Fitto
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have listened very carefully to the speeches of previous speakers, including Mr Juncker and the other representatives.  I'd start with a figure. I hope that, important as it is, there will be very little talk of enlargement and much more of the concrete and real issues that concern us, among which I believe there are very serious emergencies and urgencies. I have listened to political positions, including lessons in style and behaviour from a Parliament in which, for example, during the last parliamentary term and in the Steering Group, which refers to itself as the balancing act for a joint proposal by Parliament, there are parliamentary groups that have been deliberately and unjustififully excluded without there being a reason for them, in order to be able to build positions that are artfully party-political. So I think that, before we give lessons, we should try to start from this attitude and, above all, start from a given. Apart from the positions, the negotiations are difficult, as Mr Barnier specifically explained, but there is certainly a fact that cannot be ignored, which is that of the need to reach an agreement because we will have to continue to have a fundamental relationship with the United Kingdom from an economic, commercial and relationship point of view. That is why the idea that we can continue to insult what we may not like is unacceptable, but it is the Prime Minister of a country. You may not agree with your position, you will have to find agreement with difficulty, but agreement must be reached, because the theme is that that country has a government, which may not please certain political groups in this House, but it is a government which, until proven otherwise, when there are new elections, is entitled to deal with its positions and also deserves the respect of this Parliament and the members of this Parliament. With regard to the Multiannual Financial Framework, I would like to say very clearly that we need a strong acceleration and, above all, it would also be important to try to put in place and on the timetable solutions that do not have an idea of an increase in the tax burden, but that can also give answers on the general issues that will affect the future of the new Commission.  There has also been a lot of talk here, and there has been a lot of talk at this time, about climate battles and policies. I believe that it is essential to start not with the extremism of position, but on the basis of the need to change and adapt the productive, economic and commercial system of our continent to needs that are indisputable.  Finally, I would like to mention the subject of immigration, since it has not been mentioned in any way. In the last few days, the Interior Ministers in Malta have announced many things, and I will not dwell on them, and a few days later, just yesterday, we checked that words, as usual, were not followed in any way by deeds. I hope that the Council will be able to begin to address and give precise answers on these issues.

name: Martin Schirdewan
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the This afternoon, at the request of my group, we will be debating Turkey's attack on Syria in this House. I think this Parliament will send a clear signal against Turkey's war of aggression against the Kurds in northern Syria, which has just begun, contrary to international law. But now let me come to the other political issue that is currently pressing – Brexit. The Left Group very much appreciates the Council's signalled willingness to agree to an extension, if requested, under Article 50. We expect the UK Government to comply with existing UK law and make such a request if no agreement is reached in the coming days. And we do not expect this for our own sake, we expect it because a crash out, a hard Brexit, would have the worst political consequences for all concerned, and because the political issues that are crucial to us, namely the protection of the peace process in Northern Ireland and the protection of the social rights of millions of Europeans, have not yet been adequately answered. Moreover, perhaps the question of Irish reunification could answer one or the other question that has now been raised.  But, ladies and gentlemen, there are also pleasing things happening in British politics: almost an export hit is taking hold. Before you torment yourself and let me put you on the torture, I'll tell you what it is: Extinction Rebellion. We are currently witnessing their climate protests in Berlin, Amsterdam, London, Paris and many other European cities. In the run-up to COP25, which is taking place in Santiago de Chile, I can tell you that we, as the left here in the European Parliament, believe that a policy that decisively combats the climate emergency is necessary. Our task for the Commission and the Council is to align EU policy with the United Nations And the Paris Climate Change Agreement from now on and in the future, without any ifs or buts.  And a small change of theme: the Council will also deal with the multiannual financial framework. In short, money must be made so that it can be spent on meaningful projects. Mr Juncker, I may now be giving you a crazy presumptuous or suggestive idea: let us close the tax loopholes! With the money raised, we increase the EU budget and invest in social-ecological conversion. We need investment in good jobs, in the necessary digital structural change, in the fight against social inequality, in the fight against the climate emergency and not in the military armament of the EU. Then you can keep your promises in the future.

name: Belinda De Lucy (NI).
text: – Mr President, let me make this very clear, Mr Sassoli, you have no right to go and speak with the UK speaker, having conversations that are directly interfering into our domestic politics. It exposes your intentions to intervene at all levels to stop Brexit. It is immoral. Shame on you. And Mr Barnier, I note throughout your speech, sir, you kept referring to the ‘British negotiators’ as just ‘British’. We are the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland and that will never change. Brexit was not a rejection of Europe or our wonderful European friends. It was a rejection of the anti—democratic nature of EU institutions and you confirm to us every day it was right to leave. (Applause from certain quarters)

name: Danuta Maria Hübner (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I understand that the political situation in the UK is, to say the least, challenging. However, it must be clear that the proposal that came from the United Kingdom, long awaited by the EU, that might lead to an orderly Brexit, has not met our expectations. We hoped to see a legally operational alternative to the backstop that would deliver on all its objectives. As Michel Barnier has rightly said, the proposal raises fundamental concerns. Here in this House, we will not accept a return to a hard border on the island of Ireland. We will not accept distortions to the all—island economy. We will not accept risks to the integrity of the single market and we cannot, either, accept replacing the legally operational backstop with a vision of a solution that might or might not come at the end of the transition period. We regret the lack of transparency at this stage of the negotiations on the British side in a moment when the third Brexit deadline is around the corner. The negotiating team has shown an enormous amount of flexibility over the last few years and is prepared to work around the clock to find a deal, so there is still a chance, but a significant movement from our British friends is needed. But I’m not convinced anymore, as many of us here are not, that the UK Government wants a deal. Let me finish by underlining that this unprecedented political process of Brexit continues to have a massive negative impact on citizens’ lives and, in this context, let me say that negotiating the future relationship should not be allowed to start before citizens’ rights are legally guaranteed.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, much has been said about Brexit, as it should be, but I would like to point out that among the items under discussion at the next European Council will also be the issue of climate change, precisely in the context of international agreements, which I would like to focus on. Following the recent United Nations Summit in New York, we are approaching COP25 in a few months' time, in December, in Santiago. We have successfully welcomed the Paris Agreement, with a global commitment to keep the rise in temperature well below the critical threshold of two degrees. However, today, it is good to say, we are far from getting there. It is the Environment Council itself that has said that, with the current commitments and the current evolution of greenhouse gas emissions, we will not be able to deliver on the commitments we made in Paris. So, on the one hand, we are well aware that the fight against climate change in order to be effective must be coordinated at international level and, alas, the picture is not exactly reassuring. The already well-known attitude of the Trump administration was followed by President Bolsonaro's worrying stance on the phenomenon of deforestation in the Amazon.  On the other hand, however, we must confirm and strengthen our leadership, the European leadership exercised in recent years to deal with the climate emergency. The data clearly show that economic growth and falling emissions can go hand in hand. This is an important and demanding change that we can achieve and that we must achieve in a fair, inclusive, sustainable way and, I have to say, also by adapting our production systems. The choices that the Heads of State intend to make between now and the next few months will therefore be decisive.

name: Guy Verhofstadt (Renew).
text: – Madam President, I want to start by responding to Ms De Lucy, who was attacking this Parliament, saying that we are undemocratic while they are here, elected here and they are not elected in the British parliament. So who is more democratic, do you think? Who is more democratic? In your own country, neither in UKIP before Brexit has one representative in the British parliament and here you have more than, I don’t know, too many representatives. You’re saying that we are not democratic. This is crazy.  But that said, I will be less diplomatic than Mr Michel Barnier. I think that the proposal that Boris Johnson put forward exactly one week ago, was not serious at all. Not serious at all because it was, in fact, I call it a virtual proposal. It was not a real proposal. It gives a veto to the DUP in a number of issues. It is putting custom facilities, not on the border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic, but in all the other parts of the island of Ireland that we don’t know yet. And finally, the proposal is to downgrade the political declaration and the future relationship by undercutting, in fact by making a sort of Singapore at the sea, at the North Sea – these 20 behind me like that – , but by in fact destroying the ecological, social and labour standards. I have to tell that to Mr Richard Corbett because he’s a Labour representative. I can never understand that today there are 20 or so Labour MPs thinking to vote together with the government of the UK for such a deal. That’s the contrary of all the things that Labour has always defended in the past. I hope that this is not happening.  The real reason why this is all happening is very simple. It’s a blame-game. A blame-game against everybody, a blame-game against the Union, against Ireland, against Ms Merkel, against the British judiciary system, against Labour, against the Lib Dems, even against Mrs May. The only person who has not been blamed is Mr Johnson himself, apparently, but all the rest are the source of our problems. That is what is happening today. All those who are not playing his game are traitors or a collaborator or have surrendered. Well in my opinion, the real traitor is he or she who will risk bringing disaster upon his country, its economy and its citizens by pushing Britain out of the European Union. That’s, in my opinion, a traitor.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Martin Edward Daubney (NI)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Verhofstadt, I would like to ask you why you don’t respect democracy. You claim to respect democracy; you just said you don’t think that the Labour party should be allowed to vote with our Conservative Party. Why not? That is their democratic right. And do you remember how you opposed the fact that Turkey wanted to throw a new election because you didn’t agree with the first one. Yet you want us to throw a second referendum in the UK.  Mr Verhofstadt, you do not believe in democracy, except when it suits you and except when you win, and when you lose – as you did in the European referendum and in the Brexit referendum, you just don’t like it, do you.  I'm afraid you’ve lost, my friend. Goodbye.

name: Guy Verhofstadt (Renew)
text: blue-card answer. – Democracy you can change your mind. And I have a small impression that, in the meanwhile, the majority of the British citizens have changed their minds. (Shouts of ‘rubbish’ from certain parts of the Chamber) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: President. –
text: Sorry colleagues, please listen to the answer and try not to holler. There’s no need for it. Mr Corbett, I think in fairness I will ask: will you accept a question, Mr Verhofstadt? You’re in demand from Mr Corbett. (Mr Verhofstadt agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8)) Ok, go ahead Mr Corbett: 30 seconds.

name: Richard Corbett (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Curiously Madam President, Mr Verhofstadt asked me a question during his speech about a small number of Labour MPs who have written to President Tusk, urging a deal and compromise, which they might vote for – not this deal by Mr Johnson. But another way to stop Mr Johnson, of course, would be to vote ‘No Confidence’ in the House of Commons and put Jeremy Corbyn in Number 10.  But it’s the Liberal Democrats who are opposed to that.  They say they’ll do anything to stop Brexit, but they won’t even put Jeremy Corbyn in Downing Street as a temporary government ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: President. –
text: I’m sorry, Mr Corbett, it wasn’t a question. I’m not sure, Mr Verhofstadt: can you make a question out of a statement?

name: Guy Verhofstadt (Renew)
text: blue-card answer. – I can make it into a question, but I don’t think that it is in this House that we have to discuss the internal affairs of the Labour Party and the British Parliament. (Shouting)

name: President. –
text: OK, you have succeeded in irritating both sides of the House, Mr Verhofstadt, so it’s a balance. Although I have to say... (inaudible) As I said, indeed, that was my remark: incredibly balanced. So calm down to my right, please. Our next speaker for one minute is Ms Chowns.

name: Ellie Chowns (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, colleagues, let’s focus on common ground, shall we?  For the third time this year, my country is looking over the cliff of a no-deal Brexit. But the difference is that this time our own UK Prime Minister is trying to drag us – kicking and screaming, – over that cliff, against the wishes of the large majority of UK citizens, and while trying to place the blame on anybody but himself.  But nobody is fooled – not in this House and not back home. We know that the EU has been bending over backwards, actually. (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: President. –
text: Excuse me Madam, really, just a second. Can I just say to my right Honourable friends: could you stop the tittering and giggling and pay respect to the speech, even if you disagree with it? Because it’s really very childish, the behaviour at the moment. So Madam, will you please continue? And I hope you will get the respect of the House.

name: Ellie Chowns (Verts/ALE).
text: – We know that the problem is not in the EU, but in Number 10 Downing Street. UK citizens are now raising their voices loud and clear. Young people, especially, are calling on us to remember – all of us – that it is their futures that hang in the balance here. We must hear their voices. We are all tired of Brexit, but we know Brexit will not be over if there’s no deal. It will just be the start of more years of painful negotiations, because we have to have a deal one way or the other, in the end. There is a way forward. We need more time so that when the Brexiteers finally agree among themselves on what the deal is, that deal goes back to the people, so that they can have the final say in a people’s vote.

name: Jörg Meuthen (ID).
text: Madam President, President Juncker, Mr Barnier, I would like to thank mr Barnier for his work and for his work. Let me shed light on another aspect. I am appalled by what is being reported about the phone call between Mrs Merkel and British Prime Minister Johnson. Let me start with the best: Merkel probably said that Germany could leave the EU without any problems. After all, an option, though not a nice one. But the Chancellor believes that the RULES for the UK are different. The UK, she says, can go if it leaves Northern Ireland in the customs union with the EU – forever. Mrs Merkel apparently wants to divide Britain in the event of Brexit. What an arrogance of power! The United Kingdom is therefore to become a divided kingdom. I find this incomprehensible to Mrs Merkel, who herself grew up in a divided country. How dare you! Or in British: "How dare you!". They would have to know what that means. Basically, Mrs Merkel has said that a deal is impossible without touching Britain's sovereignty. If you are looking at the future border between Ireland and Northern Ireland, take a look at the border between Norway and Sweden. That is also possible. Under these conditions, we can safely dispense with further negotiations, such as a further extension under Article 50. Let me finally be honest here in this House and admit that the EU institutions are doing everything they can to prevent and prevent the United Kingdom from leaving in an orderly manner. And you are always doing the same politically, namely to give the United Kingdom the buck. Britain should now pull the strings, there will be no orderly Brexit on EU terms, the earth will continue to spin, the economic damage will be smaller than predicted. Politically, it will be a liberation for the British.

name: Hermann Tertsch (ECR).
text: – Madam President, really moral superiority, the arrogance we are seeing on the part of the Social Democratic consensus is very scary, even those of us who are strong supporters of the European Union, who believe in subsidiarity, who believe in sovereignty but who believe in a European Union. We are frightened at attitudes such as those of Mr Verhofstadt, who does not really respect the views of all those who disagree. How really is that arrogance that is being given permanently when it comes to a state that has spoken, a nation that has had an opinion and has asked to leave here. Another arrogance that is of great concern, speaking of the climate, talking about the environment, is the moral superiority that already exists among certain radical groups, which are stirred by the media and by the European Union itself too, to coerce citizens into their daily lives: how streets are blocked, how people are coerced into everyday life. It is a danger of radicalisation, which is being fed from the European Union. And we have to be very careful, thinking about previous radicalizations.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, on 29 April 2017, the European Council sent a strong message to the people of Ireland. EU heads of state said, ‘in accordance with international law, the entire territory of such a united Ireland would not be part of the European Union in the event of Irish unification. The constitutional set—up in the north of Ireland rests on continued consent.’ Opinion poll after opinion polls shows that Brexit has evaporated the consent for the North to remain connected to Britain. The British Secretary of State has both the discretion and the duty to call a unity referendum if it appears the majority would likely vote for Irish unity. Every recent opinion poll shows that there is a majority favouring reunification. Tonight in this Parliament, Professor Colin Harvey and Barrister Mark Bassett will launch a report at 19.00 on the role of the EU and Irish unity, planning and preparing for constitutional change in Ireland. This is the sensible solution to the Brexit mess, both for Europe and for Ireland.

name: Ιωάννης Λαγός (NI).
text: Madam President, it is an inalienable right of every people to decide what they want. I am really surprised at the insistence of too many of you — both in this Chamber and more generally — to change a referendum and a given view of the people. The same thing happened in my country, Greece, when you led the people there to a referendum and the result of the referendum showed that we no longer wanted the European Union and we did not want the memoranda. But you, all the leaders of the European Parliament and the Central Bank, have led my country to disaster; Who's going to pay for the mistakes you made? In my country it has been paid for by thousands of families who are currently starving; too many people have committed suicide and you are all just developing theories without knowing what is going on.  So let the British people decide as they please, so that they do not go through what my country has been through. I would also like to emphasise here the great hypocrisy on the part of most of you with regard to the dominant issue of the day: Turkey's invasion of Syria. From where and to where do the Turks have the right to attack and bomb innocent people at this time? You guys sit here and just talk. The Turks have taken bottomless audacity from the tolerance you have shown them for many decades. This game with Turkey must end, it must be made clear that Turkey has no place in the European Union and the aid you provide to it must be stopped immediately. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Madam President, dear colleague, of course, I can agree that the Member States must decide their fate, but citizens have rights. Yesterday we witnessed, if you know the latest polls in the UK, about the position of citizens and the fact that they have been misled and that they have been lied to that nothing is happening to them after Brexit, that they remain the same rights without obligation.  Please answer me if you know the latest polls in the UK?

name: Ιωάννης Λαγός (NI)
text: "blue card" answer. – I believe that the world in Britain has not changed its mind; But I do not understand when a referendum is of value to you and when it is not. This referendum has been going on for some years. So why has this thing not been implemented so far? Will we wait for perhaps — with all the pressure to be exerted — to change the view of the British people? Until then, what happens? Well, the referendum was made, the decision was specific and based on your democratic sensitivities this must be accepted. (applause)

name: Enikő Győri (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. I would like to formulate three thoughts on three subjects, specifically non-Brexit specific. The first is the proposal for a multiannual financial framework: what is on the table could be formulated as less money, for more purposes, with difficult conditionality. I would like to draw the Finnish Presidency's attention to the fact that this seems rather nonsense.  The current brainstorming of the conditions under which the money should be spent would make it impossible to function normally. Please only put objective, aitable, all-in-one conditions into the system.  The second is climate protection. I do not think that there is a sober European citizen who does not consider the transition to a green economy to be important. A summary of the national climate plans will be used to decide what realistic objective we can have in terms of reducing emissions. So let's be sober about the commitments, let's not get into a league about who can unreswerably say a bigger number.  Finally, on enlargement, I say to President Juncker, who unfortunately left, it was a big mistake to say five years ago that there would be no enlargement. We can't be proud of achievement of an unsked goal. Taking perspective threatens stability and prosperity. I hope that there will be a decision to open accession negotiations with Albania, northern Macedonia, in October.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the proposal made by Mr Johnson is really not a convincing basis for an agreement. In a way, it looks like Mr Johnson is trying to sell us a very nice house with a swimming pool – the only problem is that it might not have a swimming pool after all. In fact, the proposal offers regulatory alignment of Northern Ireland with the single market. But is it a real offer? No. In fact, it depends on unilateral consent given by the assembly of Northern Ireland before the entry into force and thereafter every four years.
