This gives the EIB a relevant role in financing projects that can promote environmental sustainability and the fight against climate change.  However, over the years, EIB investments have not always been in line with the Proclamations of the European Union in these areas.  More investment is needed in areas such as energy efficiency, renewable energy, low-emission multimodal public transport systems, among others, but more is needed than this. More public investment, fewer market instruments are needed.  Instead of concentrating resources on large corporations, the EIB should use them as an instrument for effective promotion of economic, social and territorial cohesion to promote real convergence of economies, cooperation, employment, social justice.  We do not partwith these dimensions: the policies will be all the greener the redder they are too.

name: Tudor Ciuhodaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, obviously by investing in green we are investing in the future, but let us not be hypocrites – in order to make this happen, clear criteria need to be achieved, we cannot neglect any reality in which 250 000 European citizens live in this industry and that additional funds must be allocated precisely in order to find the necessary solutions.  I work in Iaşi in an emergency hospital where I see the effects of pollution, of poor infrastructure, and I believe that clear criteria must be set, perhaps by the European Parliament, so that these environmental objectives, which we all want, have a chance of being finalised. I call on the European Parliament today, we are very many people who want green energy and green transport to be the healthy solution for the future, to come up with clear criteria and additional investment, especially in those areas of Europe that really need to make these transformations in poor areas that will more easily accept to align themselves with these European requirements. Let us give Europe a green chance and come up with clear criteria. Thank.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D).
text: Mr President, in the eastern Mediterranean — and in the Mediterranean in general — the effects of climate change are already evident. That is why we support the commitment to the Paris Agreement and the European Union's policy on clean energy for all, with renewable energy sources.  However, the 'one size fits all' model cannot apply. Especially for isolated and island states, such as Cyprus, natural gas will have direct effects on reducing environmental pollution compared to other fuels, such as oil. It also provides flexibility for adaptation so that our objectives — Mr President — are achieved. This flexibility is absolutely necessary to be maintained by the European Investment Bank as well and I stress that ensuring energy flow is a top priority for the European Union as a whole.

name: Karen Melchior (Renew).
text: Mr President, I would like to address my colleagues who have said during this debate that this Parliament has no influence. You're wrong. This debate itself shows you that you have a voice, that this institution is a forum to express yourself, even if I do not agree with your views. There are also commissions in this house that are taxonomy what a green investment is, defining what are the sustainable investments. It is therefore in this House, in Europe, that we will define what green investments are for the future and I hope that the United Kingdom will take part, after 31 October and in the future.

name: June Alison Mummery (NI).
text: – Mr President, we hear a great deal about the environmental and ecology credentials of the European Union. This EU ecowarrior myth has become so dominant among the remain-minded that I wouldn’t be surprised if Commission representatives were not among the climate emergency mob blockading London streets. But for such an eco-friendly organisation, please answer me this. Why is the EU’s own common fisheries policy allowing a super trawler, 14 times the size of the average British vessel, to fish in an area of the English Channel that is thought to be a breeding area for seabass, a species the EU has banned British fishers from catching due to their scarcity? This vessel has already destroyed fishes off West Africa, been banned from Australian waters and caused controversy in Chile. This supertrawler is known to have horrific bycatch rates which endanger species such as bluefin tuna, John Dory and common dolphins in that area. Can you also tell me when the EU will learn that this type of fishing factory ship is not the way forward and start taking the environmentally friendly small-scale fishing fleet more seriously?

name: Werner Hoyer
text: President EIB. – Mr President, I leave this Parliament encouraged for the big challenges we have ahead in the next days and weeks because I feel strong support. I didn’t expect from the beginning that I would get support from everybody, but the overall feeling here in this Parliament seems to be that we better take climate change issues seriously, and this is exactly what we are going to do.  Sustainable finance is one of the key issues here because, as I said before, we will never achieve the Sustainable Development Goals nor the climate goals without mobilising private money. This requires – what has just been named – a taxonomy that requires more than just green principles, which we have developed over the last 10 years and we were the leader on that effort. But it is necessary to demonstrate also to investors, who trust us with their private money in order to achieve a green project. You cannot simply tell them, ‘I take a piece of white paper, paint it green and then it’s a green bond’. No, you need to have reliability and accountability for what you’re doing with the money that investors give you and the money that you give us. This is why we put a lot of emphasis on the sustainable finance issue and the activities of the European Commission to arrive at taxonomy in this context. I heard several Members of the European Parliament with great joy and listened to their enthusiasm about the 50% that we are targeting now. A very, very, very ambitious objective – I can tell you – because don’t make the other projects that the EIB is financing smaller than they are. It’s clear that we have said Paris alignment, so the climate must be in everything we do. We must not undermine our climate objectives by financing 50% green and the rest dirty. No, that’s not the idea. But I wonder what the Innovation Commissioner would say if our bank comes to a conclusion that says, ‘okay, the talks with Mr Gates today about malaria research and vaccines and different diseases cannot be continued anymore because it is not demonstratively a green project’. So we also have other issues and I’ll tell you: the European Union has huge climate challenges, but a few other challenges as well. Let me just take very, very few.  Number one, we are losing competitiveness day by day because we do not invest enough in innovation, research and technology. Therefore, we support wholeheartedly the activities of Commissioner Moedas to bring the European Union into first position when it comes to innovation and productivity growth.  Secondly, we have only just begun to think development big. If you look at what challenges are ahead in the next decades, when by the end of this century, Africa will have four billion citizens from now – a little bit over one and a half billion – and they will all need jobs. So we need to support leapfrog development in Africa and we need to think development big in order to produce economic perspectives. And then, of course, the climate issue. The climate issue is well spelled out, but the devil is in the detail as soon as we get to the regions where it’s going to be really, really difficult, and it’s better to get your people in these regions on board on this, and therefore we have to be very attentive there. Not by hiding behind the transition needs. Some people believe ‘let’s hide behind the transition needs and perpetuate the use of fossil fuels’. That is not the solution. But giving perspectives for jobs and growth in these regions via innovation: this is the right thing. By the way, it is also the reason why I believe we should overcome the dichotomy between innovation and cohesion. You can see clearly all around the European Union and beyond the European Union that those regions who are very open—minded on innovation are the best when it comes to cohesion policies. So, from that point of view, I’m quite optimistic.  There are many questions that have been posed that I cannot respond to right here now spontaneously. I promise we will all come back to this with our colleagues here in Brussels, so that from agriculture in Ireland to all kinds of other things, we will not shy away from responding to these questions.  The risk inclination of investors. That’s a real issue. We have many problems also in the context of climate policies where the risk situation is so difficult that the commercial markets will not service that and, therefore, we are so happy about the cooperation with the European Commission and the European Parliament and the Council – because only with the risk coverage by EU guarantees we can serve it. And you know we are going to come to the close of the Juncker Plan very soon. And I’ll tell you, in my view, this is the greatest legacy of President Juncker when he leaves his office – because that has been a smashing success and we need to celebrate that and learn from it for the financing of our ambitious projects for the future.

name: Presidente. –
text: Mr President, thank you for your intervention and for the work of the European Investment Bank, which is very important for the European project. I am now pleased to give the floor to Commissioner Carlos Moedas, taking the opportunity to greet him for his excellent service to the European project in carrying out his duties as Commissioner.

name: Carlos Moedas
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, dear Members, dear President Werner Hoyer, dear Werner, thank you so much. My words are your words, what you just said. I think that this was a very good debate, and from this debate I really draw three conclusions. The first is the sense of urgency. We all have this sense of urgency. We have to act now, and that’s something that we all understand and we all share around this Parliament, and I’m very proud of the European project for that matter. The second is the acknowledgment that the EIB is one of our best allies. The EIB is an ally of the European project, and I remember – I think there’s very few bankers that in their speeches as you do, talk so much about innovation, about science, about the future. Because one thing is sure: if we want to solve the problem, we have to do it with science and innovation, and there’s very few people in your domain, and your experience, that understand that. So Werner, thank you so much. And finally, I think that to the Members on the right, you know, you cannot solve this issue alone. You cannot solve this issue with your country alone; you have to solve together. We have to be together to solve and to tackle climate change. So thank you so much to all of you, and I will transmit the message to my successors, and I’m sure they will deliver on your expectations.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is over. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. The development of renewable energies represents a fundamental opportunity for the European economy, to create quality employment and to guarantee a sustainable future for the new generations. I therefore welcome the fact that the European Investment Bank (EIB) intends to place the decarbonisation of the energy sector and the development of renewable and green sources at the heart of its climate strategy and lending policy, in line with the UN Sustainable Development Goals and the Paris Agreement. It is also good that this strategy, with balance and equity, provides for measures to support energy conversion such as the energy transition package: in a strategic sector such as energy, innovation and sustainability cannot be separated from the maintenance of energy security and the protection of the social dimension associated with it. Finally, I believe that the EIB's focus on small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and the development of small-scale and widespread green energy projects is important. It is necessary to remove the obstacles that SMEs still encounter in achieving their energy efficiency, due to the fragmented nature of investments and limited access to financing instruments in this sector. The EIB will undoubtedly be able to make a major contribution in this area.

name: Presidente. –
text: The following is the debate on the statements by the Council and the Commission on how to "Avoid conflicts of interest in the EU" (2019/2853(RSP)). I would like to remind you that we will continue to test in this debate the new system which allows you to register electronically, both for catch-the-eye procedures and for the blue card. Information on the use of this system has been sent to everyone by email and is also available in your posts. To submit your requests for intervention, you can use the appropriate function buttons of your electronic devices.  I would like to point out, however, that the possibility of using the traditional system in parallel, where you signal through a sheet of paper or personally sign up for this purpose, remains.  I therefore ask you to use your e-card to register your intended application.  Those who wish to eventually sign up for the catch the eye procedure do so from now on without waiting for the end of the debate so that we can manage catch the eye requests.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members of the Parliament, thank you for this opportunity to discuss the issue of the prevention of conflicts of interest in the EU. You will understand that we did not have a lot of time to prepare this discussion on an important subject; therefore, I will be short. I ask you to understand that. The Council fully recognises the importance of preventing conflicts of interest and the highest ethical standards in the EU. On this subject, the ethical framework in the EU institutions was recently subject to a special report by the Court of Auditors, published in July this year. As is the case for all special reports from the Court of Auditors, the Council has been carefully examining it and will adopt conclusions on this special report before the end of the year. The Presidency takes note of a suggestion for an independent EU ethics body expressed by President—elect von der Leyen in her political guidelines.  Accordingly, the Presidency welcomes the commitment of the Commissioner—designate for Values and Transparency, Ms Jourová, expressed in her answers to the European Parliament to engage in a dialogue with other institutions on this matter. At this stage, no proposal has yet been tabled by the Commission. Consequently, the Council is yet to formulate a view.  The Council will await with interest any proposal in this important area and, in the meantime, listen with attention to your debate, honourable Members of the Parliament. Thank you very much for your attention.

name: Carlos Moedas
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, Minister, honourable Members of the European Parliament, I’m pleased to have the opportunity to present the position of the current Commission on the prevention of conflict of interests in the EU institutions and an independent ethics body in plenary today. Let me start by reminding the honourable Members that this Commission that I’m proud to be part of has constantly striven to preserve and promote the highest standards with regard to ethics and integrity for its members.  First, the ethical frameworks for both the Members of the Commission and the staff that are solid and represent a strong set of ethical values, principles and rules. These include, notably, the prevention and handling of conflict of interests. A new financial regulation entered into force in 2018 and sets out strict rules on conflict of interest and financial matters. Amendments to the EU’s Staff Regulation in 2014 strengthened the rules on conflicts of interest for staff of all EU institutions. This Commission completely overhauled the Code of Conduct for its Members in January 2018. The new Code, as you know, sets the standard at the top of the class in Europe and makes it possible to address all possible situations. These rules are more comprehensive than the rules of most of our Member States. That’s the reality, and often stricter than the rules of other EU institutions. They contain, for the first time, a clear definition of conflict of interest and sets out a detailed procedure on how such a situation needs to be addressed. I’d like to stress, in this regard, that the Court of Auditors of the European Union has only recently largely confirmed that the ethical framework of the Commission is adequate. Second, the Commission is convinced of the importance of having a body that advises the Commission and its President independently on ethical issues of all kinds, and this is why the Commission has already set up an independent ethical body, the Independent Ethical Committee, which is composed of three independent external high-level personalities. A renowned former Vice-President of the European Parliament, Ms Dagmar Roth-Behrendt, a renowned former judge of the European Court of Justice, Mr Allan Rosas, and a widely recognised former Director-General of several Commission departments, Mr Heinz Zurek. This committee has delivered, for example, an opinion on the ethical guidelines for Commissioners who participate in the European elections. This opinion is public. Moreover, the committee is closely involved in the evaluation of the post—term of office activities of the Commissioners. So the Commission decisions on these activities and the related opinions of the Independent Ethical Committee will be public and, therefore, also be open to public scrutiny. Third, I would like to recall that there have been discussions in the past about a joint ethical body for all the institutions. The Commission already proposed the creation of an advisory group on standards in public life back in the year 2000. This proposal did not fail because of the Commission, but due to concerns of other institutions.  Lastly, you are aware that the President-elect, Ms Ursula von der Leyen, has called in her political guidelines for an independent ethics body common to all EU institutions. Ensuring trust in the European Union and its institutions with regard to ethics, transparency and their independence must remain a cornerstone of our actions. I’m looking forward to hearing the views of the honourable Members.

name: Michaela Šojdrová
text: for the PPE Group. – Mr President, thank you for the Commissioner's report. I would like to say that the conflict of interest among politicians at local, national and European level is, of course, very risky, because it reduces citizens' confidence in democracy, in politics. Unfortunately, we have such a case at the highest level in the Czech Republic.  Of course, it is very difficult to face a conflict of interest in a situation where great political and economic power is combined, and therefore I can also say from our experience that it is very important that it is at European level that rules are being created that set a common standard. The Commissioner mentioned this here.  We all want European funds, our common resources, to be used as efficiently and transparently as possible. Thanks to the amendment to the Financial Regulation of 2018, this measure has also hit our Czech Prime Minister, and we believe that the EU will be consistent on this.

name: Domènec Ruiz Devesa
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the Socialist Group supports the suggestion to introduce this topic on the agenda. New evidence and some important leftovers from the previous term show that preventing conflicts of interest will be crucial in this term. We express our support to Commissioners—designate Šefčovič and Jourová, who will play an important role in this topic. We need a horizontal and holistic approach. Several committees will be involved in the ongoing reflection. We will be called upon to touch on this matter in several political and parliamentary forms: by improving and readapting our Rules of Procedure; by reopening interinstitutional negotiations; by asking for new and ambitious legislative files, like the Staff Regulations; and by enhancing the regulations on EU funds. A more pragmatic and flexible approach is also necessary, taking into account lessons from the recent past. We need to be firm in stressing again the ambitious EP proposals set in the transparency register negotiations, as well as in finally finding a way to achieve stronger transparency in all the EU institutions, notably in the Council. We, therefore, look with attention at the ethics body announced by President—elect von der Leyen. We will be ready to assess it, bearing in mind that we believe that ordinary legislative proposals or proposals under the ordinary legislative procedure, for instance, on the issue of revolving doors, are the key instruments to really push the transparency of the institutions.

name: Stéphane Séjourné
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Madam Minister, Commissioner, I would like to be concrete enough to explain to you why we have summoned you without much preparation for this debate and quite unanimously on the benches of this Chamber. Firstly, because this approach is the result of a feedback on the work carried out together by all the groups, the experience of the Committee on Legal Affairs which had to analyse the declarations of interest and the statements made by the Commissioners and then a perhaps personal conviction, which is also shared by my whole group and surely beyond the political groups.  First, if I read JURI's skills today, I see this. The Committee on Legal Affairs is responsible for verifying whether the content of the declaration is accurate - we do not know how to do it - if it is complete - we do not know how to do it - if conflicts of interest can be assumed - we do not have the means to verify it. The first observation is that parliamentarians today do not have the means to carry out their work, at least in terms of the JURI Committee and the work we are asked to do to analyse the Commissioners' declarations of interest. Second observation: perhaps an element of personal conviction, one walks backwards. We are parliamentarians, we legislate, but we have not legislated on the transparency and the degree of transparency that we want for the European institutions - I mean the European institutions because they are also senior officials, who are in contact with lobbies, who make decisions every day with interest groups. And of course we are being asked to do the work of an independent administration, that is, basically to evaluate - and we have absolutely no power to do so - if the statements are complete.  So we walk backwards. That is why this debate is interesting, Mr President, because it must enable us to succeed in the mandate to put things right and allow parliamentarians to legislate on transparency and, eventually, for an independent administrative authority to do the administrative work.

name: Daniel Freund
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which Corruption is a huge problem in the European Union. In several Member States, it has reached the highest level of policy. Viktor Orban has basically turned Hungary into a mafia state in which hundreds of millions of euros disappear from the central bank or from EU funds. Andrej Babic also enriches himself with EU funds. In Spain, in the 'belt' case, sham contracts were awarded in dozens of cases, thereby defrauding taxpayers. If the European Union wants to lead the fight against corruption in a credible manner, it must, of course, lead by example. That is why we urgently need institutions that are free from corruption, free from conflicts of interest, free from revolving doors, through which politicians move directly into well-paid lobbying jobs. 50% of the Barroso Commission's Commissioners now work for organisations registered in the EU Lobby Register. In the last five years, we have had 24 cases here in the European Parliament in which ethics rules have been violated. Not one of them has been sanctioned. And Transparency International has just shown that 48 Members of this House earn more money outside than through their salary here in the European Parliament. How can we be sure that they represent the interests of the citizens and not those of a company? I do not understand how this can be, and it cannot be explained to any citizen or a citizen outside. Parliament has now rightly rejected two corrupt candidates for the new Commission. This is a great success for this House, but I believe that we must go further and now create this independent ethics authority. I proposed the Ursula von der Leyen. I am very pleased that she has included this in the work programme, because we must finally take it out of the hands of the Commissioners and from the hands of Members of the Board of Representatives, whether or not ethics violations are punished. I hope you can support me in this.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, in the European Parliament, the Committee on Legal Affairs is responsible for identifying any conflicts of interest of future Commissioners. Unfortunately, it is very poorly carried out on this mission. I talk about it because I am a member.  It has just disgraced itself twice, first by vetoing the Hungarian candidate, whose only wrong was to have belonged to the government of Viktor Orban, and then by refusing to oppose the candidacy of Sylvie Goulard, whose financial subordination links to an American lobby, the Berggruen Institute, clearly constitute a conflict of interest.  The Committee on Legal Affairs did not even want to question Ms. Goulard on this matter. I immediately left the meeting in a sign of revolt, and I continued my revolt today by calling for the creation of an independent authority to examine in its place the conflicts of interest of future Commissioners. Let's outsource ethics control because we have failed to insure it.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 171, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Irène Tolleret (Renew)
text: "blue card" question. I wanted to react to Mr. Lebreton's intervention. We are in a state of law, so it is not the rumour that should decide how we choose the commissioners or not, it is the JURI commission, with the means given to it. What do you propose, which remains in the rule of law and not the rumor?

name: Gilles Lebreton (ID)
text: Answer "blue card." "Dear colleague, you have not listened to me, obviously. I propose the creation of an independent authority. You should be delighted, it will be likely to finally make the rule of law triumph, and we need it in this Chamber.

name: Manon Aubry
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, this debate comes in a rather particular context, since tomorrow will be the second hearing of Commissioner candidate Sylvie Goulard. Let us not hide our faces: the doubts that remain concern its integrity. This is proof that our initial conflict of interest review procedure is not sufficient to remove the shadows. It is the newly elected Member of Parliament that I am who speaks to you and who is surprised to see that the examination of the independence of candidates for the Commission ignores bank accounts or the ongoing legal proceedings against candidates. I am surprised, too, that we have no way of verifying this information that we have to take for cash, even when those statements are completely empty. Finally, I am surprised that the same standards do not apply to everyone. Why didn't we ask Josep Borrell to sell his half a million shares in large multinational companies, such as Bayer, when we asked others to do so? Let us learn from this before citizens' confidence in the European institutions is finally shaken. We are making concrete proposals to you that are here in this document, and I would be happy to give you, Madam, so that this can be followed up.  Two concrete proposals. Let us first work together to create an independent authority in the image of the High Authority for the Transparency of Public Life in France. Let us give it sufficient time and resources to carry out a real control of conflicts of interest, before, during and after the mandate of the commissioners. Let us also allow this committee to evaluate cases such as that of Sylvie Goulard, who was paid more than 10,000 euros per month by an American think tank in addition to her allowances as an MP. And how can we accept that more than a third of the Members here are paid more than EUR 1,000 per month in addition to their allowances and that they are thus accountable to private interests rather than to voters alone? Their trust has been sufficiently betrayed. It's up to us to restore it by showing, once and for all, that we prefer ethics to money. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 171, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Jordi Cañas (Renew)
text: "blue card" question. – Mr President, I would like you, before making biased insinuations about Mr Borrell in this House, to ask, for example, his representative at the hearing why he did not ask him. Because I was at the hearing and I didn't hear him ask you about it. Therefore, if you were so concerned about those amounts—that you don't know where you got them from—you should have insisted to the representative of your training at the hearing to ask. Do you know what happened? He didn't.

name: Manon Aubry (GUE/NGL)
text: answer 'blue card'. That is precisely the problem. That is not the role of our substantive hearings, which are supposed to be substantive, and I think we will all agree that it is the role ahead of the conflict of interest review that needs to be done independently. I want you to know that I sit on the Legal Affairs Committee, that I asked him to sell his shares in Bayer but also in BBVA, the bank for example, or also in the big gas company. The Committee on Legal Affairs did not do that, I regret that. This proves the whole issue and the whole problem and the need to review our procedures.

name: Tiemo Wölken (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which What is the highest value we have as politicians? It's integrity. It is the confidence of the citizens in the institutions of the European Union. The confidence that we decide here to the best of our ability and that we have no conflicts of interest. That is why it is so incredibly important that we have the same rules within the European Union for all the institutions – for the European Parliament, for the Commission, but especially for the Council. It cannot be that institutions are differently transparent, that we have different codes of conduct.  In the Committee on Legal Affairs and The Internal Law Committee – and I was also present – we had the great problem that we had a new Rules of Procedure that no one had applied before, and there were no clear rules of the game for the procedure that we carried out in the Committee on Legal Affairs. After all, we cannot sell this to the citizens as a clean procedure. That is why we must take the time to improve the procedure and discuss how we can restore the confidence that may have been lost in some places. The independent ethics body is certainly a good idea, but not the only one. We could make the Commissioners' statements public earlier, that OLAF could have a stronger role. We must discuss all this calmly, and we owe it to the Europeans that we have a Commission that is clean, and that is what we must work for in the next few years.

name: Karen Melchior (Renew).
text: Mr President! A special thank you to the Commission and the Council for their participation here today. The European institutions tend to have higher ethical standards of openness and of countering conflicts of interest than most of our Member States. It should continue. So when commissioner candidates are rejected, even though the norms and legislation of the countries have been followed, that is correct. If we look at the participants in this debate this evening, seven of the members of the Committee on Legal Affairs and two of the Members are from the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. In other words, nine out of ten of the Members who have been here today.  It has been a frustrating process, as many have mentioned. There has been a lack of time, there has been a lack of resources and there has been a lack of knowledge about what is going on. There has also been a lack of transparency, which has been criticised by several Members who do not sit on the committee. However, that frustration with the process should never lead to a breach of confidentiality as a parliamentarian and the disclosure of confidential documents and information to the media and to other Parliamentarians, as we have seen during the process. Hearings in JURI (Legal Affairs Committee) look at declarations of interest and hearings in the specialised committees are broader.  I would urge that we go back to our committees in this House and seek out knowledge about how authorities have been established in the individual Member States, to review our own procedures here in the European Parliament, and to look at how to feel about ombudsmen and with audit courts in other countries. In addition, we must follow the work that the Commission has already started and which the future Commission will continue, in setting up an independent ethics body. Thank you so much for today's debate and thank you to the Council and the Commission. I hope we haven't wasted your time too much.

name: Marie Toussaint (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, opacity, corruption, impunity: this is the Bermuda triangle in which the European Union finds itself locked up. How, then, can we ask citizens to trust us? Thanks to the environmentalists, we have conditioned the appointment of commissioners to the examination of their conflicts of interest. Thanks to the environmentalists, parliamentarians are prohibited from lobbying directly targeting the activities of the European Union. But these two notable advances are just rubbish on a much deeper wound. To treat the evil, it must still be taken at the root. We need stronger powers for the Committee on Legal Affairs so that it can investigate beyond voluntary declarations of interest. We need a new code of conduct that can establish full transparency about the activities and revenues of commissioners and politicians and new rules on those affected by indictments. As environmentalists have long called for, we need a high authority on transparency and ethics to end the forbidden love that is slowly killing Europe.

name: Lara Wolters (S&D).
text: Mr President, the new President of the European Commission wants to apply the highest standard of transparency, and that is good news, because the European Commission's track record is mixed. The code of conduct may have been revised, but many voters remember, of course, the revolving door of Mr. Barroso, who went to work for Goldman Sachs, or Mr. Selmayr's absurd flash promotion. It is good that the bar is now being raised, but we are not there yet, and that is why I would now like to address the Finnish Presidency. I hear the fine words on your part, but I would like to call for a very concrete act. The Council Presidency is usually sponsored by private parties. For example, Finland has accepted 100 cars from a major car manufacturer – just in a year when European passenger car emissions standards are being revised. That seems to me to be a pure example of a conflict of interest. My specific question is therefore: is the Presidency also prepared to raise the standard and come up with guidelines on these sponsorships?

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a very important debate, perhaps we should have had it a long time ago. We are talking here about prevention in conflict of interest, integrity, ethics and we find that there is an extremely big difference between the European institutions. The Council says it is not yet ready to have any discussion sat down on this. The Commission has other rules, the European Parliament has other rules. Every state has different rules.  There has been talk here of common standards, and I would add: yes, I agree to have that body, but a colleague said here – we have to do these analyses in a coherent chronological order. How, for example, to announce the Chair of the Commission team and then to find that the team is not good. That is, these integrity checks for Commissioner proposals, something concrete that we have now, had to be done before. And yes, I want it to be a single unit of measure, because it is very important not only to have a Code and to have measures, but also how we put them into practice is very important. That is why I am also asking the Commission and we, Parliament, to think, and the Council, to have a unique unit of measure for analysing the integrity of those who work, not only of members of the European Parliament, not only of Commissioners but also of officials. Thanks.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, let us be clear and direct. The promiscuity between political power and economic power is thus a kind of watermark of the European Union.   The conflicts of interest that we discuss here are present in the day-to-day life of the institutions. The former President of the European Commission, when after the financial crisis caused by the banks, he considered promoting a new regulatory framework for the financial sector, went to call representatives of megabanks to move forward with the lines with which this regulation was to be sewed.  We know how the story ended: we know where the former President of the Commission is today, several members of his College have gone their way. Specialised agencies caught, approval procedures for the placing of new products on the market based on risk analyses carried out by the industry developing the products, revolving doors between the private sector and the institutions... Finally, the list is long and there are no codes of ethics and conduct that alone are able to resolve this situation. Fundamental, structural, systemic, policy change is needed, a change that guides them to the defence of the public interest and not the interests of economic and financial groups.

name: Radan Kanev (PPE).
text: – Mr President, we are obviously all committed to the prevention of conflicts of interest. But how do we achieve this goal? Do we really need new paperwork? Do we really need endless new regulations? Do we need to impede, to hamper, I would even say, often, to suffocate small businesses with new bureaucratic requirements? Let alone, do we really need new bureaucratic bodies? Does such an approach deliver good results? Unfortunately, my answer is no, it does not. What we really need is the strong and comprehensive enforcement of the existing clause on conflict of interest and corruption. What we really need is severe and effective sanctions in cases of breaches of the existing clause. What we really need is a working European Prosecutor’s Office and a comprehensive European judicial system.

name: Tudor Ciuhodaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, tonight's discussions terrified me. I have seen that there are subjective criteria, political criteria in assessing the integrity of those who must be in certain public functions, and I as a European citizen wish that there are the same criteria for all, regardless of the public office or regardless of the European institution in which that individual is located. If three of the members of the Legal Committee have raised questions, I want to tell you this evening that we need very clear rules and an independent body to appreciate these things, because if there are political conflicts in a State, they could translate into the assessment of some committee and there will always be a question mark whether the assessments were correct or overshadowed by a political interest.  I want integrity for every European politician, and that is why I am asking you today to find that solution for an independent body to assess every time, for all European institutions, for all categories of officials, the integrity of those who are there. Otherwise, for nothing, we say, it's hypocrisy. Three of the members of the Legal Committee have raised big questions this evening and obviously I am asking myself the same questions. Thank.

name: Carlos Moedas
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me tell you something. I’m really very proud that I am part of this Commission and I’m very proud of what President Juncker did. We really strengthened the rules on conflicts of interest, the code of conduct of the Commissioners. So, when you compare what we did in this Commission to other institutions, to other Member States, we did an amazing job of strengthening the rules of transparency, of trust with the citizens, and we really are very, very keen on telling this not just to this House but to the European people. I think that that, for me, is essential as a message of tonight on this debate.  Secondly, trust and transparency, as you’ve said, so many of you, are crucial in the times that we live in, the times of the digital technology, exactly because without that there is no democracy. And we all agree on that. But there’s one thing that I think was very clear from the President-elect: we need to have an independent body for all EU institutions. I think that the political guidelines for the next Commission are very clear on that.  Thank you very much for the debate and for the ideas. I think that it is crucial to really discuss this point and so I’m very happy to be here today as a Commissioner and to be present at this debate which is crucial for the future of Europe.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, ladies and gentlemen, to conclude, I wish to thank you for this very useful debate. The issue of preventing conflicts of interest is an important one. Regarding the creation of a possible body to examine ethical issues at this stage, no proposal has yet been delivered by the Commission and, consequently, as I said, the Council is yet to formulate a view. We are open to dialogue with the Commission and the European Parliament and are waiting with interest for possible further developments in this area. As regards the question concerning corporate sponsorship, I would like to answer that we do not expect to have any discussions about corporate sponsorship of the EU presidencies with other Member States because this is a matter that falls within the remit of each Member State. But during our Presidency, we are enhancing transparency in many ways. For instance, we keep an open list of our EU-related ministerial meetings. You can find the list openly on our Presidency website. Now, transparency is a joint effort. Let’s work together towards that goal. Thank you very much once again for your very important remarks and for this useful discussion.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is over.

name: Presidente. –
text: The following is the debate on the Commission's declaration on "US customs duties on European goods following the WTO decision in the Airbus dispute" (2019/2846(RSP)). Before opening the debate, I would remind you that we will once again use the electronic registration system for the catch the eye and blue card procedures. You know that you can still use the traditional route, although you are invited to use the new electronic system.

name: Carlos Moedas
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, Minister, honourable Members of the European Parliament, notwithstanding our efforts to find a negotiated solution in the aircraft files, the US has announced that it intends to avail itself of the full the rights awarded to it by the WTO. The US decision follows the WTO arbitrators finding on the level of possible US countermeasures, establishing that level to be up to USD 7.5 billion, which is EUR 6.9 billion. The US tariffs will apply as of 18 October, after the WTO dispute settlement body has formally authorised the US to impose the countermeasures. The meeting of the DSB is scheduled for 14 October. Let’s be clear: we regret deeply the US decision to go ahead with the imposition of tariffs. While authorised by the WTO, it will only inflict damage on businesses and citizens on both sides of the Atlantic. The US product list mainly targets new civil aircraft produced by Airbus. The product list also includes a range of agricultural and industrial goods exported by different EU Member States. The additional duties are at rates of 10% on civil aircraft and 25% on a range of agricultural and industrial products. The US will impose 25% duties on a number of agricultural and manufactured goods. Some EUR 4.3 billion in exports to the US will be affected. So we’re talking about 60% of the total value of the list, including iconic EU products like French wine, Scotch whisky, Italian parmigiano, Irish butter, Spanish olive oil, German household machinery, Greek peaches and Dutch cheeses. The main burden of these additional duties will fall on products exported by the four Airbus Member States – France, Germany, UK and Spain. So that will be 87% of the total value of the list. Other Member States, like Italy and Ireland, will also be affected, although to a lesser degree. We’ve noted that the iconic products such as Italian wine or olive oil and pasta, as well as Irish whiskey, have been spared from tariffs. The published rates of 10% to 25% will allow trade to continue, even if in reduced quantities. But many companies and workers will be affected negatively. While we regret the US decision to go ahead with the imposition of tariffs, we have to remember that the US have followed all the steps prescribed by the WTO in a dispute that has been ongoing for 15 years. So we should avoid overreaction and respect our international obligations. An arbitrator will in some months decide, in the parallel Boeing case, what level of countermeasures the EU will be entitled to apply on US imports. The Commission made a serious offer to settle the aircraft disputes in July, and so we remain open to reach a negotiated outcome, in which we would notably agree on new rules on subsidies that could apply also to other plane-makers around the world. We must bear in mind that new highly-subsidised competitors from China and Russia are preparing to enter these market and may seriously disrupt it  if we don’t take urgent action. It remains to be seen whether, with the tariffs in place, the US will now start to give more positive signals about a negotiated solution to the dispute. In the press release accompanying the list, it explicitly said that it is ready to do so. We are ready to negotiate even with tariffs in place, provided that the US is ready to agree on a balanced solution, which will also need to end the subsidies provided to Boeing. There have been calls for a compensation mechanism for farmers, and I would only comment that we must try to settle this dispute in the next months and put an end to a self-defeating cycle of tariffs and countermeasures and counter-tariffs. This is the greatest service we could provide to those negatively affected by the US measures. Our common interest is probably best served by exploring a fair and balanced outcome with the US as rapidly as practicable.

name: Christophe Hansen
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, last week’s WTO Airbus ruling is not a ‘nice victory’, as US President Trump tweeted, but proof that multilateral dispute settlement delivers. The US administration should, therefore, also not forget this when it comes to appointing new members to the WTO Appellate Body. We respect the WTO ruling, but we regret the US decision to choose tariffs over talks, especially in the light of the Boeing ruling expected for early 2020. It, equally, makes no sense for our farmers, companies and workers to foot the bill for a dispute over aircraft subsidies. Our hands remain extended to find a negotiated settlement in the case where both the EU and the US were found guilty of illegal aircraft subsidies. Should the US, however, decide to trigger more tariffs then we will have no choice but to respond in kind. My group, and I believe, this House will support the Commission in a firm response if needed.

name: Bernd Lange
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which This time, Mr. Trump's tariffs are legal. That is what makes the procedure special. Otherwise, he is not afraid to impose illegal tariffs on steel, on aluminium, on Spanish olives. This time it is legal. And, of course, we also accept this because we, as the European Union, we in the European Parliament, are committed to the rules of the WTO. But it is a joke of history that this president, who is now relying on these legal tariffs, is in the same breath preventing the wto's jurisdiction from continuing. In December, we will have only one judge at the WTO Court of Appeal, and then there will be no more judgments that resolve conflicts, and he can keep illegal tariffs in place. This is a scandal and therefore: yes, we must negotiate, we must find a solution, because an escalation stage – imposing tariffs, we impose tariffs – does not help anyone. So, yes, negotiate, even if it's certainly hard with Mr. Trump.

name: Liesje Schreinemacher
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, this debate is called ‘US tariffs on European goods following WTO’s decision on the Airbus dispute’. But today, what we’re really talking about is our Dutch cheese manufacturers, our Scottish distillers and our French winemakers. These, and other European businesses, will be hit if the US tariffs are put into force on 18 October. They are the ones that suffer the consequences when their products become more expensive on the US market, as will American businesses, should Europe decide to retaliate after the WTO ruling in the Boeing case next spring. Our US-EU trade relations go back many years and form one of the most important pillars to our transatlantic partnership, a partnership that is built on our shared values such as democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. Our free trade has brought us prosperity. It has created jobs and made businesses throughout Europe flourish. I believe that in times where free trade is increasingly challenged worldwide, our transatlantic partnership should be strengthened rather than undermined. We cannot allow ourselves to be dragged into a vicious circle of tariff after tariff. It is not too late to avoid the harmful consequences of the USD 7.5 billion worth of tariffs.  I therefore urge not only the Commissioner but also the US administration and my colleagues in the US Congress to work with us towards an agreement. It is only by working together that we can resolve this situation and citizens and businesses on both sides of the Atlantic can continue to enjoy the benefits of free trade.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, to say that we regret the decision of the US administration without saying first that we regret the mistakes that we made years ago is hypocritical. I believe we should not get all worked up. As the Boeing case has not been adjudicated fully, it will not be possible at this moment to square it off against the Airbus case. But let’s not get distracted from the real issue. The real issue is that we have a basic conflict between this House and the European Union on one hand and the US administration on the other and, hopefully, some of our American colleagues would be on our side of this conflict over multilateralism in the global trade order. And I believe we can use this particular experience to argue very simply: ‘the WTO works, let’s not destroy it’.

name: Danilo Oscar Lancini
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, by condemning the Airbus consortium by the WTO, the United States will be able to impose $7.6 billion in new duties on European goods. Despite the fact that Italy is not part of Airbus, it will be its various sectors, in particular dairy, which have nothing to do with aeronautics. Today, the United States has the knife on its side of the handle, and calls for the spirit of Euro-Atlantic cooperation will certainly not be enough to stop their duties. The phantom European interest is a pious illusion. Merkel and Marcon are only as attentive to their own national interest, just as Much as Trump. In this European Union, Italy's troubles, such as the migration invasion, have to be paid for by Italy, while the problems of the Franco-German axis, the banks and Airbus are ultimately being paid for by all European countries. Why has the Commission, which is so strict in other situations, not monitored irregular aid this time? What action does it intend to take to remedy the damage that will be done to a sector, the agri-food sector, which has already been sacrificed on several occasions in free trade treaties with non-EU countries?

name: Mazaly Aguilar
text: ECR Group. – Mr President, Commissioner for Trade Malmstrom told the press a few days ago that the European Union had very little to do and very little room for manoeuvre. How can you say that? That's not true. There have been other cases, such as when President Juncker ran out to the White House to ask President Trump not to harm German cars. When the Russian veto, the European Union was so diligent that, a week later, there was already a regulation with compensation. What's going on? Are there first-rate citizens and second-rate citizens?  Since April, the European Union has known that these US tariffs were going to come into force, and little or nothing has been done about it to reassure the agricultural sector. Gentlemen, we cannot go to war with the United States of America, because our agriculture could not bear it, given the precarious situation it is in. If we fail to reach a satisfactory agreement for both sides, what needs to be done is to demand responsibility from this European Union, to provide solutions to the Spanish agricultural sector ⸺al which I represent⸺ and to be as diligent as it has been on other occasions.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which For Trump, the 7.5 billion-dollar tariffs are primarily an instrument of his campaign strategy. Incidentally, I find 25% duty on all books from Germany and great Britain particularly perfidious, even if it is WTO-compliant. The example makes it clear that we as the EU should not pay back with the same coin, at Boeing. I am against a trade war. On the contrary, we must agree in the WTO and with our partners on when state aid is a sensible industrial policy and should therefore be allowed. Let us be honest: neither Boeing nor Airbus would have succeeded without subsidies. If we want to make climate protection and the achievement of our UN Sustainable Development Goals by 2030 seriously an overarching policy target, then state aid will be needed in all countries. We must rethink the reform of the WTO in this direction.

name: Brian Monteith (NI).
text: – Mr President, free trade brings prosperity; it lifts all our boats. Protectionism through subsidies and tariffs is the enemy of free trade and prosperity. Subsidies and tariffs are doomed to fail: they make us all poorer. Singapore, without any natural resource except for its people, did not bargain away its tariffs; it unilaterally abolished them. Now its prosperity is the envy of the world. US tariffs are a response to EU subsidies in European steel and aviation. The EU introduced 25% tariffs on American whiskey and bourbon. Now the US is levying 25% tariffs on Scotch malt whisky. The way to respond is not to retaliate with new or higher tariffs, but to end the state subsidies and unilaterally reduce tariffs. Instead, the UK has been dragged into a tariff war not of our making. These are the UK’s tariff proposals for when we leave the EU. They are substantially lower than the EU’s. Thanks to Brexit, tariffs on US whiskey and bourbon will be reduced – they will be abolished. I expect Donald Trump to do the same for the Scotch malt whisky. Thank goodness we have a lifeboat.

name: Dolors Montserrat (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the threat of Trump's unfair and harmful tariffs endangers many sectors, products, workers, ranchers, farmers and thousands of families in Spain and Europe. Spain is one of the most affected countries. The European Union must give a firm answer, in order to defend economic freedom and market unity against tariffs, barriers and impositions. We can't leave the answer alone in the hands of each country. A European unitary response is needed. Spain, unfortunately, encounters a socialist government which, instead of being in office, is on holiday. And with trade wars we all lose. And Trump intends to punish some countries more than others, to justly break our market unity and punish those sectors in which we are world leaders. Let's not fall into his trap if we don't go together.  Commissioner, we ask you: unity, solution, aid to the sectors and countries concerned and more transatlantic relationship.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner. Yesterday, at the opening of the World Trade Organisation public forum, the well-known and renowned American economist Jeffrey Sachs said that it is absolutely the Trump administration's intention to completely undermine the World Trade Organisation's world trade system, which is based on common values and rules. And he does. We are aware of all the problems relating to the Appellate Body of the World Trade Organisation and it is therefore particularly bizarre and particularly cynical that the same government is using the World Trade Organisation ruling to impose additional tariffs. The second bizarre finding, of course, is the nature of tariffs: it is worth noting that it is absolutely the intention to divide Europe on the different tariffs in the different Member States. So my message to you, Commissioner, and also to the new Commission, is very clear: let us not be divided. Let us take one common position and not be naïve. Negotiating is good, but if it leads to nothing, Europe will also have to face punishment.

name: Jordi Cañas (Renew).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, in recent days I have received a multitude of worryings from Spanish farmers, producers and workers about the Trump administration's decision to increase tariffs on products as significant as wine, oil and cheese by 25%. And they asked me what their fault was, because they had neither received subsidies from aeronautical companies, nor had they given them, nor had they litigated for fifteen years in an endless way, nor had they distorted any markets. However, their products now had to bear, directly, the cost of tariffs and the cost of a penalty. And then I listen to you and say, "We're sorry." It's very nice to regret, it's phenomenal, but what else, other than regret, are you going to do? He says, "Don't overdo the reaction." Also phenomenal. But what else are they going to do? Because farmers, producers and workers with this don't have enough. Does the Commission intend to assess and decide to implement a contingency plan that provides an adequate response to the needs of citizens, workers and farmers? Because that is their obligation, in addition to negotiating appropriately, to give a real and immediate solution to these citizens, to those sectors, to those producers who are going to have a direct impact, being hostage to a situation that they have not provoked. Therefore, employment, the future of agriculture and, above all, the credibility of the Union, depend on you and your good work.

name: Tiziana Beghin (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, negotiating a trade war is our priority. But the biggest objective at this point must be to help our businesses before American tariffs fall on them, because among the many products in the crosshairs – cured meats, fruits, cheese – there are precisely the food excellences of our territories. That is why I would like to ask the Commission how it intends to provide financial support for the farms affected and whether it can undertake to allocate specific funds to them under the common agricultural policy.  The Commission has already found eur 1 billion for the agreement with Mercosur. There is an urgent need to do the same for American tariffs and to reshap the use of the Globalisation Assistance Fund to help businesses. This crisis must be a great opportunity to demonstrate that only a coordinated and European approach will enable us to cope with this threat. This is the time to show everyone, and especially the United States, how strong Europe is when it is united and when it defends its excellence.

name: Herve Juvin (ID).
text: Madam President, I would like to urge my colleagues not to fall into the American trap. The U.S. trap has been to institute tariffs and tariffs on products that have nothing to do with aeronautics. Obviously, it is a question of dividing European countries, of leading countries for which agri-food is important to neglect the aeronautics sector, of bringing the countries for which the automobile sector is the first sector to neglect aeronautics and, somewhere, of dividing to weaken this industry of sovereignty that is European aeronautics and, in particular, Airbus. I would also like to draw the attention of my colleagues to the impact on the fabric of SMEs that make up Airbus' supply chain. The aircraft manufacturer has every capacity to pass on the additional 10% tariffs to the supply chain, which means that the fabric of SMEs will be weakened, some of them weakened and, perhaps, some of them will lead to serious economic difficulties. I think it is important to draw the attention of my colleagues and the Commission to the importance of the aviation supply chain.

name: Άννα-Μισέλ Ασημακοπούλου (PPE).
text: Madam President, we obviously respect the decision of the World Trade Organisation on Airbus state aid. After all, we here in Europe want the World Trade Organisation to continue to function — and effectively. The position of the European People's Party is quite clear: we remain open to finding a fair and balanced solution. A solution which will not unfairly involve — in a dispute concerning aeroplanes — olive oil, feta cheese and canned peaches exported from Europe to the United States, nor beef imported into Europe from the United States. We have no reason to open up issues that have been closed.  Let us therefore limit the debate in this area and sit down at the negotiating table as soon as possible, so that together we can identify those which, with mutual benefit to our economies, our businesses, our producers and our citizens, can bear fruit at a time when many want us to move away from each other.

name: Paolo De Castro (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, our exports are under attack, and so are our agri-food products, which, after the crisis caused by the Russian embargo, have to foot the bill once again for trade reprisals decided on by others.  Commissioner, we cannot be caught unprepared. What strategy has the Commission envisaged in order to avoid a market crisis which would seriously affect our Parmesan cheese, our oil and our wine? We must show that we stand shoulder to shoulder with our citizens and businesses and achieve, as a first step, a sufficiently long transitional period before the possible application of duties, avoiding immediate trade shocks for our producers.  But that cannot be enough. We call for the immediate start of the procedures necessary for the activation of the crisis reserve, which is provided for in the common agricultural policy to deal with these situations. Commissioner-designate Wojciechowski himself told us this in the Committee on Agriculture.  And then we need to strengthen the promotion package in order to help our farmers. Ambitious choices are needed, Commissioner, to adequately protect strategic production from an economic and social point of view.

name: Marco Campomenosi (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, compensation and transitional periods are all solutions that do not go to the heart of the problem. If we are here this evening it is because the European Commission lost at the WTO. We are here this evening because it was planned, as we knew, we had been waiting for this judgment for two years. The European Commission has not been able to negotiate and negotiate first with its American counterpart.  We are talking about a subject, Airbus, where there are France, Germany, Great Britain and Spain. It is hard to understand why Italy has to pay like the others and for certain sectors even more than the others. Italy does not concentrate, Italy does not take money from Airbus, Italy does not put money into Airbus. But we have already understood that neither Mrs Malmström, who is not here today, nor her successor Hogan, want to deal with this issue.  It would be stupid not to think that if our companies are to expose themselves in this way to third-country markets, thus exposing themselves to external system shocks that are not conditioned by us, we also owe it to the failure of the European Union's internal market. Therefore, policies are being made to ensure that our products are also imported within the European Union and that our companies do not have to work only on third-country markets.  This European Commission is failing to ensure, for various reasons, that our products go to Russia, the United States and China. Try to open free trade negotiations with Mars and maybe they'il be a little luckier.

name: Jörgen Warborn (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Us measures with increased tariffs on a variety of European goods are a serious problem for Union exports. Despite this, they are perfectly legal, as they come from a decision of the World Trade Organisation Court. Then we must respect this.  Although this is negative for the EU, it is indeed proof that the dispute resolution system within the World Trade Organisation is working. That should give the United States a reason to rethink the future of the Court of Appeals. Today, the United States does not appoint new judges to the Court, which puts it at risk of malfunctioning. Of course, there is still a chance of resolving the deadlock in the Court of Appeal, and the EUROPEAN Union must make every opportunity to do so. We need a rules-based trading system in the world. That is why we must try to allay the level of conflict with the United States. We in Europe, and especially in my country, Sweden, depend on good trade relations with the outside world. Through the free trade system, we create the conditions for new jobs, for competitiveness and for prosperity.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Europe on Airbus has lost and is likely to win on Boeing in a few months' time. The main question is: what is the Commission's strategy for trying to recover the damage we are suffering? It is rumoured that a strong part of the Commission's strategy is to identify, in the reaction on Boeing, a surgical strategy to hit federal states with tariffs that should be strategic for Trump's re-election. But are we sure that is the right strategy? And if Trump still wins the election, what will our attitude be? We will have the enemy of the enemies, built and corroborated by our strategy. №. Let us review the wto rules of operation, let us create the conditions for dialogue with our natural ally, the United States, and let us not compensate our entrepreneurs. He doesn't need this. Let us give it the opportunity to remain in the most attractive market for us Europeans, which is the US market.

name: Angelika Winzig (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report Protecting the European Way of Life presupposes that Europe remains a strong trading community, to safeguard employment and to safeguard our prosperity. We all know that our trade landscapes are fragile internationally, especially since the world's political alpha wolves have no interest in an economically strong Europe. We are in a sandwich position between China and the United States, and I do not think it makes sense to impose punitive tariffs on each other. It is more expensive and also creates a lot of bureaucracy. Germany will be hardest hit by this trade dispute. Export losses of up to EUR 2 billion are expected. This is relatively bad for the surrounding neighbouring countries, which are suppliers to Germany, and there is a risk that it will trigger a chain reaction. It cannot and must not be the case that a dispute between two aircraft manufacturers should be fought on the backs of our SMEs and our agricultural economy. I therefore call on the Commission to provide clarity both within the framework of the WTO and to hold intensive discussions with the United States in order to achieve a win-win solution in the interests of our economy, in terms of our employment and in the interests of our prosperity.

name: José Manuel García-Margallo y Marfil (PPE).
text: – Madam President: a story.  He promised a genius to give him whatever he asked, on one condition. It would give his worst enemy twice what he chose. He chose to stay one-time. That's what Trump has done. Trump, who has never believed in the WTO, has rushed to announce retaliation against many European products. In the Spanish case: oil, olives, wine, ham, cheese and fruits.  We could do the same. We could ask to be compensated for the damage caused by export companies, foreign sales corporations, "doped" with more than $24 billion. We may also ask for $10 billion worth of U.S. products to be penalized, which is the value of the reductions granted to Boeing by washington state. But in this strategy, the only ones who would win here would be the lawyers and China. The only solution is to recognize that we have both sinned. Forgive each other and sit at a table to set the rules of the future. But to bring the Americans to the table, does the Commission believe that German prudence or French firmness is better? And in another order of things, does the Commission intend to pull the European Governance Adjustment Fund to compensate sectors bound by American tariffs?

name: Annie Schreijer-Pierik (PPE).
text: Mr President, global trade tensions are escalating. Mutual import duties and sanctions will ultimately only result in losers – on both sides of the ocean. The ruling on Boeing has yet to follow. Industry is struggling not only in Europe, but also in the United States. Why should the Americans penalise our farmers and mussel fishermen for an old conflict over aircraft subsidies? As much as EUR 39 million worth of Dutch cheeses, sausages and pork are threatened with punitive charges. That's not just something. We must therefore work with the Americans to ease tensions and negotiate to find a solution. That is best for both America and Europe. But if the Americans take us, unfortunately, European countermeasures will have to be taken. As Europe, we reach out for a fair negotiating solution. International trade based on rules is the key to our prosperity and is in all our interests. This applies not only to Europe, but also to America.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner (PPE).
text: – Madam President, colleagues, I agree with Commissioner Malmström that Airbus-linked tariffs are short—sighted and counter—productive. We repeatedly said that we were ready to find a fair and balanced solution to this 15-year-old legal battle. Also, a year ago Presidents Juncker and Trump agreed not to escalate trade disputes. I can only hope that, like Commissioner Malmström, also Phil Hogan, will spare no effort to engage deeply with the US on this. I understand also that negotiations are planned, and we should exploit fully a chance to find a solution before the tariffs become effective. But in more general terms, let me say that we should be worrying actually that in our Transatlantic relations it is getting hard to find anything working well. We didn’t manage to convince the American Administration that trade deficit is not a good measure of how we benefit from trade. The elections next year will make it also very difficult to move toward a positive EU-US trade agenda, but we should seriously think of a new, comprehensive reset between the European Union and the US. I think Europe needs it, but I dare say also the global economy needs it.

name: Juan Ignacio Zoido Álvarez (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, 'a very nice victory'. That's how Mr. Trump called the imposition of $7.5 billion in tariffs on European farmers last week. I very much doubt it will be a victory for anyone, but it is undoubtedly a serious defeat for European farmers and producers, especially the Spaniards. If approved, we will lose a key market for exports; companies will suffer million-dollar losses and thousands of jobs will be at risk. But in the face of these unfair Trump attacks, the European Union must live up to the circumstances, and farmers and ranchers are waiting for action to cushion the damage. I will put three measures on the table: the coverage of storage and financial costs, in the case of olive oil; support for campaigns to promote Spanish products that alleviate the loss of market share; and finally, the activation of exceptional CMO measures to support producers in severe cases of market imbalance, as has already happened with the crisis with Russia.

name: Clara Aguilera (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Mr Moedas. This thing has fallen to you, on behalf of Commissioner Malmstrom. I would like to transfer to you that we know that the Commission has been concerned and has taken care of it.   The agricultural sector only asks for the same energy as when other industrial sectors are affected. The agricultural sector cannot be a currency in trade agreements, nor can it be the victim of a trade war, like the four years we have been with the Russian veto. This can't be. Therefore, it is needed... it has to be fixed. You have to see the possibility of a transitional period and solve the problem with energy. I hope so from the commission already outgoing.  We know that the situation is difficult, but also that this sector is suffering a lot. Tomorrow there is a great mobilization in my country, in Spain. A manifestation for olive oil, in Madrid, because it came (incomprehensible words) prices. We need private storage for Spanish olive oil to be activated and we need other measures taken for wine. Important.  One very brief thing, do you know that a Spanish winery with an export volume to the United States of EUR 300 000 has been required last Friday to pay EUR 80 000 already for (incomprehensible words) of tariffs? That's the reality, it's not fair for this sector to suffer.

name: Klemen Grošelj (Renew).
text: – Madam President, dear people! Of course, I understand the Position of the European Commission in a concrete case and I welcome the commitment to multilaterism and free trade. But let's not delud ourselves about what kind of customs policy we're actually talking about. It is a policy aimed at under which the competitiveness of the European economy is reduced and that jobs are actually relocated from Europe to other parts of the world, regardless of the legal justification of this. I therefore call for the European Commission to take measures to protect European industry as part of its commitment to multilaterism and free trade. In particular, this protection is deserved by the diversified supply chains, which are made up of small and medium-sized enterprises, which are the mostvativable and numerous part of this European industry, and are, above all, part of an industry that has significant social and social effects in the event of difficulties.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (Renew).
text: – Madam President, I would like to express my agreement with the negotiating and management model of Commissioner Cecilia Malmstrom. We don't want a trade war, we want a basic agreement on the aeronautical industry. Negotiation is always better than confrontation. Protectionism hurts everyone. That is why I advocate persisting in dialogue and taking advantage of the skills gained and the relationships and networks woven while the TIC was being negotiated. I report, as a trick of bad ruler, to deal with this threat the blow to American aviation the problem with the Boeing B737 MAX, without which I do not think we would be in this situation. I must value European environmental and social standards, which are the best guarantee for our products to consumers. Finally, I hope that the plans to help the sectors concerned, such as high-quality Basque agri-food productions, will be contributed to by all public and private actors who can contribute to their design, development and implementation.

name: Carlos Moedas
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you so much for the discussion and for the lively debate. On behalf of my colleague, Cecilia Malmström, let me recall our position: we really regret the US decision to go ahead with the imposition of the tariffs, but we have to remember that this time is very different from the ‘232’ steel measures and other unilateral actions. The US has really followed all the steps of the WTO in this case, and as the Member said, it is paramount for the European Union to respect and to cherish multilateralism. Hopefully, the US announcement that they are willing to find a negotiated solution will be followed by deeds, and, as indicated before, both sides should have an interest in finally closing this long-standing dispute – also in the light of new entrants on the aircraft markets. Finally, let me conclude by stressing the words of Dolors Montserrat: the point here is unity. We have to be united. Without unity, we’re not strong – another proof of the importance of the European project. So the key to negotiating a good solution is really to be united. President, if you allow me, I will switch to Portuguese just for 30 seconds.  É a minha última vez neste plenário.
