Gostava de vos dizer que foi um grande privilégio, um privilégio dos últimos cinco anos, talvez o maior privilégio da minha vida, poder estar aqui e, por isso, quando os meus colegas me pediram se os podia substituir, aceitei na hora, porque adoro este espaço.  Gostava de agradecer a todos os membros do Parlamento, mas gostava também de agradecer àqueles que fazem um trabalho extraordinário que estão ali atrás, os intérpretes, a todos aqueles que estão aqui, os huissiers, o pessoal administrativo, que fazem desta casa algo de mágico.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Thank you very much, Commissioner, for these personal words. I have not had the pleasure of working with you now, but I am sure that the House will respond to the good wishes.  The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Dita Charanzová (Renew)
text: in writing. – The US has always been an important trading partner, and continues to be so even in these more challenging times. While we may have differences, we must do everything we can to find negotiated solutions with our partner. The WTO has made a ruling regarding Airbus subsidies, and we respect this. But as we are all well aware, a similar ruling against Boeing will very likely be made in the months to come, and I regret that we were not able to come to a mutual agreement to prevent escalating trade tensions through tariffs. If the US decides to go through with these tariffs, the EU must respond back. Entering a cycle of tariff after tariff is harmful for both sides, to our producers, to our consumers, and to our overall relations. Time is running out, but it is not too late yet for the US and the EU to find an agreement before 18 October and de—escalate.

name: Billy Kelleher (Renew)
text: in writing. – The ongoing trade dispute between the United States and Europe has the potential to hit farmers and primary producers hard. They will be the collateral damage of trading blocs being unable to reconcile differences without the outdated use of tariffs. The targeting of high-value dairy products with an additional duty of 25%, following a WTO ruling, will make many Irish food products prohibitively expensive in the United States. The US is Europe’s number one market for dairy exports with 133 000 tonnes exported every year. In 2018, there were EUR 250 million of Irish dairy exports to the US alone, including 78.5 million bottles of Irish whiskey and Irish cream liqueur. Kerrygold, a major job creator in Ireland, is the United States’ second best—selling brand of butter – this will see its price rise from USD 3.50 to close to USD 4.50 Too many people see this as an ideological issue. However, the implications of continuing trade battles for ordinary people is profound. Jobs will be lost in communities where agri—food jobs are the main economic driver and where other forms of well—paying jobs are rare. If we are to protect jobs in Europe and ensure the viability of farming, then common sense needs to prevail.

name: Marie-Pierre Vedrenne (Renew)
text: In writing. I deplore this further escalation in trade tensions between the European Union and the United States. Despite repeated requests from the EU, the United States refuses to reach an amicable solution and targets strategic sectors with the imposition of new tariffs: the aviation sector remains a flagship of our European industry and the European Union is the world's largest exporter of agri-food products. In this context, the European Union will have to react firmly. Indeed, it should in turn have the opportunity in a few months, when the WTO makes its decision in the Boeing case and for which the EU is already authorised to impose retaliatory measures. More generally, these retaliatory measures are of no interest to either the EU or the United States, at a time when The foreign competitors of Airbus and Boeing, notably China, continue to develop their aviation industry at full speed. Finally, we should remind the United States that they are using the WTO to their advantage even as they try to stop its operation by blocking the renewal of the appeal mechanism of the dispute resolution body.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, the Turkish operation in north—east Syria can open a new dramatic chapter in the already very dark history of the Syrian war. The potential consequences of such military action are clear to everyone – at least are very clear to us. The repercussions can be extremely serious and far—reaching in humanitarian, military, political and strategic terms. For all these reasons, we call upon Turkey to immediately stop its unilateral military action. New armed hostilities in the north—east will first of all exacerbate civilian suffering and provoke further displacements. This new escalation adds yet another obstacle to the UN—led political process, after the positive news just a fortnight ago of an intra—Syrian agreement on constitutional committee. Turkey’s unilateral action also threatens the progress achieved by the Global Coalition to defeat Daesh, of which Turkey is a member. Military action will undermine the security of the Coalition’s local partners – namely the Kurdish forces – and risk protracted instability in north—east Syria, providing fertile ground for the resurgence of Daesh. Let us not forget that Daesh still remains a significant threat to regional, international and European security. We are also aware of Turkey’s intention, in the medium—term, of settling Syrian refugees along the border. It is highly unlikely that a so—called ‘safe zone’ in north—east Syria, as envisaged by Turkey, would satisfy international criteria for refugee return as laid down by the UNHCR. It is difficult to imagine how such returns could be either safe, voluntary or in any way dignified. Mass resettlement on the scale suggested by Turkey would also profoundly destabilise an already fragile area. Any attempt at demographic change would be unacceptable for us. We have always supported Turkey for hosting three million Syrian refugees, providing them with shelter, assistance and services. But as President Juncker made very clear just a few hours ago in this Chamber, there can be no question of the European Union financing the infrastructure to receive hundreds of thousands of Syrian refugees in north—east Syria. The European Union will not provide stabilisation or development assistance in areas where the rights of local populations are ignored – or even worse, violated. Beyond the serious humanitarian and security implications, the Turkish incursion might also prevent the constitutional committee from beginning its work. Just two weeks ago we were in New York at the General Assembly, where we received the encouraging announcement that the regime and the opposition in Syria had reached their first agreement since the beginning of the war, thanks to the UN mediation that we have supported over all these years. We made it clear back then and over all these days, that this is just the first step, but a very important one – a real first step to allow the whole country a potential political resolution of the conflict. We were looking forward to the first meeting of the committee in Geneva – and I would like to say that we are indeed looking forward to the first meeting of the committee in Geneva – possibly even before the end of October. We hope that the Turkish attack will not delay the first meeting of the constitutional committee, and yet we cannot exclude this eventuality. We ask Turkey to execute an immediate cessation of hostilities. A destabilised north—east Syria, with new ethnic tensions and a resurgent terrorist threat, is certainly not in Turkey’s interest. We have always shared the goal of ending violence, defeating Daesh and promoting peace and security in Syria and in the wider region. Turkey has always been in this a key partner for the European Union and a critically important actor in the Syrian crisis and in the region. But Turkey’s legitimate security concerns should be addressed through political and diplomatic means, not through military action, in accordance with international humanitarian law. We urge all to ensure always the protection of civilians and unhindered, safe and sustainable humanitarian access throughout Syria. Our goal remains to help the Syrian people build a united, sovereign, democratic and inclusive Syria. A sustainable solution to the Syrian crisis will not come through military means. I think this is very clear to all – at least this is very clear to us Europeans. The only way to achieve peace and security in Syria is full implementation of UN Security Council Resolution 2254 under UN auspices. So our immediate goal is now to avoid renewed armed hostilities in the north—east of Syria, to stop them, and to do everything in our power to support the UN—led political process. This is why I have invited the UN Special Envoy for Syria, Mr Pedersen, to join us at the next Foreign Affairs Council next Monday in Luxemburg to discuss together the way forward in this critical moment. The Syria conflict will not be ended by weapons. This war can only be ended by mediation and true reconciliation within Syrian society. The conflict can only be ended through a genuine political transition, negotiated by the Syrian parties under UN auspices. The whole European Union is united behind this goal, and today I have issued – more or less one hour ago – a clear declaration on behalf of all 28 Member States to confirm and make extremely clear our common position. The five EU Member States of the UN Security Council coordinating have now officially asked to bring the issue in front of the Security Council, and I understand that this will happen tomorrow. We will also continue to be in touch with our partners, and to update obviously the European Parliament on any relevant developments and to discuss together – and I am looking forward to our exchanges tonight – the way forward in this moment. I think our position has been clear from the very beginning – just a few days ago – of these developments and we must see how we can make this call effective and with impact on the ground.

name: Željana Zovko
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, as we speak, Turkish forces are entering the north—east of Syria in an offensive against a reliable Western partner which played a crucial role in stabilising Syria. Yes, that partner – the Syrian Kurds – is being abandoned. The impulsive decision to leave this ally raises deep concerns. Due to the increased Turkish involvement in north—east Syria, we fear that ISIS will benefit and seize the opportunity to regroup. Furthermore, we share Kurdish fears of a massacre, as was already the case in the past in Afrin. Not only will the West lose its reliable partner in the fight against terrorism, but we may be a witness to human suffering and destruction.  The European Union is the biggest contributor to the UN multilateral system that establishes the instruments to prevent genocide, massacres and human catastrophes. Therefore, it is important that the Security Council take appropriate action as soon as possible. A possible displacement of people, no matter how small it is, calls for international resistance. Turkey is using the pretext of creating a safe zone. We saw a similar situation 25 years ago in Srebrenica and Bihać. We know the consequences of the first, and the cost of reinstating its status in the case of the second.  The Commission President, Jean—Claude Juncker, has said that if the plan involves the creation of a so—called safe zone, don’t expect the EU to pay for it. In this case we certainly hope the EU shall go a step further. Europe must play its part.

name: Kati Piri
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, High Representative, on Sunday night US President Trump gave President Erdogan carte blanche to invade north-east Syria – which Turkey just did today. The Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces have always been the international community’s closest ally in the fight against Islamic State. They are the ones who fought the battle on the ground, and more than 10 000 of them gave their lives for the peace and security of us all. And what for – if now the jihadis use Turkey’s invasion to reorganise and to continue their horrific violence in Syria and across the world? Turkey claims it wants to establish a so-called safe zone, but what they are in fact creating is a war zone. After all the killings, displacement and horrors of the Islamic State era, the citizens of north-east Syria are now facing new violence and, on top of that, abandonment by their international allies. Ankara’s security concerns cannot and will not be resolved by force. High Representative, my Group not only urges you strongly to condemn Turkey’s illegal military operation but we also call on you to use all the instruments and punitive measures at your disposal to pressure Turkey to start respecting international law Immediately. Backstabbing our Kurdish allies – after the huge sacrifices they have made for our security – is simply not an option.

name: Irina Von Wiese
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, the withdrawal of US troops from northern Syria is creating a dangerous power vacuum. I am very concerned about reports that Turkish troops have launched offensives in areas of Syria controlled by Kurdish forces. We call upon the Turkish Government to cease these actions. The focus now must be on defeating the UN-listed terrorist organisations, to play a constructive role in the Syrian conflict, abide by international law, and in particular the United Nations Security Council Resolution 2254 in order to find a solution to the Syria conflict.  The opening of new fronts in Syria is not in the interest of Turkey’s security. This intervention adds a new dimension to the conflict in Syria and raises serious concerns about the impact on the delicate internal balance in Syria. The conflict has already resulted in a high number of civilian casualties and now many more civilian lives are at risk. It is vital that we avert a further deterioration in the country’s humanitarian crisis.  We must keep at the forefront respect for international law, including the protection of civilians. We acknowledge the solidarity demonstrated by Jordan, Lebanon and Turkey in light of the Syrian refugee crisis, and call for EU and Member State financial support aimed at addressing the urgent needs of refugees and their host communities to be stepped up.  We call for responsibility-sharing, allowing refugees fleeing Syrian war zones to find protection beyond the immediate neighbouring region, including through resettlement and humanitarian admission schemes. We stress that Syria is currently not safe for refugee returns and that the EU must not support such returns.  Finally, it is evident that there can be no effective conflict resolution or sustainable peace in Syria without accountability for the crimes committed. We call for the adoption of an EU accountability strategy towards the atrocities committed in Syria.

name: Alice Kuhnke
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Turkey's invasion of northern Syria violates international international law. There is a great risk of a humanitarian disaster. Civilian lives on both sides of the border are at stake. People – many children – may be forced to flee.  President Trump's green card to President Erdoğan is yet another of america's betrayal of the Kurds. IS could not have been fought if it were not for the Kurds. Europe cannot accept – we must not accept – what is now actually happening.  Mrs Mogherini, will you work to ensure that the EU uses all the means at its disposal to stop the atrocity and prevent another humanitarian disaster? In 2017, the EU sold arms licences to Turkey for more than EUR 2.8 billion. Will you push for EU Member States to stop arms exports to Turkey?  Erdoğan wants to move 2,000,000 Syrian refugees to the region he has now invaded. He wants to build a human shield against Syria. Will you, Mrs Mogherini, work to ensure that the EU stops the disbursement of the remaining EUR 3 billion, which the EU has promised to pay for Turkey's migration management? We Greens demand that the EU use all the means that we have. We must stand up for the Kurdish people.

name: Thierry Mariani
text: on behalf of the ID group. - Madam President, the reality of the day is simple: Turkey is invading a state called Syria and we are looking at this, we are going to vote on a motion and you know very well that we will not do anything. We have sowed chaos in this region, which was in addition to the chaos already in existence, and today we are adding disgrace. The disgrace of letting down our allies, who helped us in the fight against terrorism. This disgrace, we had already known in Afrine, we will know it today under exactly the same conditions. Madam High Representative, we are no longer praising Turkey — you recalled a few minutes ago that it was our ally, and I imagine Mr Borrell will do the same - but the Turks are safe allies in the spring and are morphing into danger in the autumn. You know as well as I do that today the Turks are the first supporters of the fighters in the pocket of Idlib, Idlib, which the Un report last July described - I quote in French - as the largest dump of terrorist fighters on the planet. My question is simple: what do we intend to do concretely, other than pass a resolution? And you will allow me another question: a real ethnic cleansing will take place in the two Christian cities of Hassake and Qamichli, what will Europe do?

name: Assita Kanko
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, Madam High Representative. Are the Kurds once again becoming the plaything of history? Today, after the Turkish incursion into northern Syria, it looks like this. After the Kurdish militias delivered the ...to help end the IS caliphate, the US is now dropping them. Turkish autocrat Erdogan will be given free rein to undo Kurdish autonomy in the region. His plan to resettle Syrian refugees in the northern strip of Rojava, home to the Syrian Kurds' largest cities, will create long-term instability there. The Turkish offensive threatens to make the recovery of the broken country almost impossible. At the end of last month, thanks to UN mediation, a constitutional committee was set up in which the Syrian government and opposition would consult constructively. Erdogan is effectively burying this dialogue now. This raid could give the IS terrorists a second breath, both in Europe and in the Sahel region. This situation is acute and precarious, as my native Burkina Faso unfortunately demonstrates. IS is likely to be given free rein in camps such as Al-Hol. We can also expect a refugee crisis. Irresponsible, then, this Turkish action in Syria. That is why Europe must urge the parties concerned to exercise maximum restraint. Madam High Representative, make it urgently clear to them that the blood of the population must be spared in military operations and that mass displacements of populations must be avoided. I ask for democratic Kurdish self-government to be protected. Please let us effectively counter the resurgence of jihadist terror.

name: Nikolaj Villumsen
text: gue/NGL Group. Madam President! Mr Erdogan's attacks on our pro-democracy and Kurdish allies in the fight against Daesh are totally unacceptable. We must not let down the brave Kurdish men and women who fought at the forefront against the terrorists and the Assad regime. The Turkish invasion is a disaster. It is a disaster that will hunt down tens of thousands of civilians and will open the door for Daesh to the Middle East and Europe. Mrs Mogherini, while we are talking, civilians are being bombed right now by the Turkish military. Civilians lie dead in the streets! Mrs Mogherini, it is time for action. The EU must speak out against Erdogan and Trump. The EU must slam the box in for Erdogan. Our allies died for us, now it's time for us to stand up for them!

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Thank you very much, also for the time point landing. I would like to point out that we already have a large number of requests for spontaneous requests, and since we are already in arrears, I will only select five requests out of respect for those who are still here and also in the interests of the translators. So it no longer makes sense to keep reporting.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: Madam President, we condemn the new — third in a row — invasion of NATO Turkey, the European Union's strategic partner, on the territory of Syria, which is already facing the tragic consequences of the eight-year war, in the context of fierce imperialist rivalries. The United States has given the green light to the Turkish attack on the Syrian people and the Kurdish population in the region. This development is a sign of the New Democracy government and those in Greece who have celebrated the supposed protection that the United States will provide Greece for the dangerous base agreement signed on the recent visit of the American Foreign Minister, Pompeo, to Athens. The involvement of Greece — and each country — in the planning of the United States, NATO and the European Union puts our people and other peoples on great adventures, who today can learn from developments, strengthen the common struggle and defend their own interests. Hands off the Syrian people!

name: Peter van Dalen (PPE).
text: Mr President, the withdrawal of US troops is a blow to the Kurds and we immediately see the consequences. Dictator Erdogan has unleashed his troops on Ras al-Ain and Tell Abyad. Count on the ISIS rabble to emerge from its lair again. And what happens to the ISIS prisoners who are now in camps? Are they going to be released? However, Trump's disastrous decision is also a wake-up call for European countries. Criticizing Trump without deploying military personnel is not fair. This can be done, for example, by relieving the Americans in Iraq so that they can deploy their capacity in Syria. Kurds and Christians in the region buy nothing for beautiful European statements and tear-jerking statements.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: – Dear Chairman, this debate unfortunately coincidences the beginning of Turkey's military intervention on northern Syria. I join all those who express deep concern about this. Regardless of Ankara's reasoning, this action will contribute neither to peace nor stability in the region. While the Turkish president argues that the purpose of the operation is to eliminate security threats and allow Syrian refugees to return from Turkey after establishing a safe zone in the area, the real motives are different. Erdogan's military offensive into northern Syria reveals the extent to which domestic problems are pressing him due to poor economic performance and weakening support for his policies. It is particularly inadmissible for a Turkish president to identify Kurds with Islamic State militants. This attack is an attempt to deal with those who contributed most to the defeat of the Islamic State. I'm hoping for a permanent one, not a temporary one.  The European Union needs to continue to rethink relations with Turkey, but to the end reject illusions about US President Trump's foreign policy match with the values we seek to promote in international relations.

name: Ivan David (ID).
text: – Madam President, the EP today overwhelmingly refused to adopt any parliamentary resolution on Turkish aggression in the Kurdish-inhabited north of Syria. We have heard moving talk about the merits of the Kurds, but their slaughter does not bother these democrats enough to publicly agree to a proposal for effective action against murder. Their greatest European value seems to be hypocrisy and human rights to blabber wildly. Czech writer Karel Čapek paraphrased the attitude of a European politician in the 1930s by saying: "We condemn violence, but we are willing to supply weapons." Yes, European arms factories supply arms to Turkey.  I have heard from Mr Juncker how they say they resent turkey's non-implementation of the agreements on immigrants, the oil extracting in the Aegean Sea and the Turkish-occupied Northern Cyprus disrupting European trade. The so-called European Democrats gave way to Hitler and eventually signed the Munich Agreement with him, which was handed over to him by the industrial Czech borderlands and thus the whole of Bohemia. Churchill said of it, "They wanted to choose between shame and war, they chose shame, and they have war." Today, the Erdogans are leaving the border, then everything they want. That's the EU peace project.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Madam President, honourable Members, Honourable High Representative Mogherini, the fact that Turkish President Erdogan attacked the Kurds in Syria today is no surprise. We've been talking about this with you for over five years. We warn, insist and say, "This man is a dictator, this man is not interested in human rights." It attacked, occupied both the Kurds in Syria and Cyprus today occupied, so threatens Greece, so threatens Bulgaria. Here the question is what does the European Union do (and in your face – you are high representative). Measures must be taken. All financial flows from the European Union to Turkey must be stopped. The intent of the large German car company, which is trying to move its plant to Turkey because Turkey does not respect human rights, must be reviewed because Turkey attacks and kills civilians because Erdogan's Turkey is an occupier and aggressor and you can no longer bury your head in the sand. You have to make a decision.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, do you remember when in 2015 we committed ourselves to supporting Kurdish fighters in Kobane in the fight against Daesh? When we were talking about the incredible Rojava model, its social innovation, the focus on human rights and women's rights, the secularity of their system of government? Well, this model is about to fade away. Trump tweets and Erdogan cheers. After the 'Euphrates Shield' and 'Olive Branch' operations, carried out under the pretext of terrorism, the US withdrawal becomes a real green light for Ankara, with a resounding u-turn on an entire people who fought unreservedly against Daesh. While we are debating, Turkish aircraft are already bombing and there is talk of the first inevitable civilian deaths. It is not only a terrible humanitarian tragedy, but also an incomprehensible witness to Daesh. Ladies and gentlemen, we cannot remain silent. Every negotiating lever must be used to dissuade Turkey from this possible extermination. Turkey continues to be formally a candidate for accession, a status clearly no longer compatible with its aggressive attitude, which violates international law, tramples on the rights of the populations involved and which, once again, destabilises an already battered region.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam High Representative, this is the terrible and unfortunately long-awaited announcement of the Turkish military attack in kurdish-majority areas of northern Syria. An attack that takes place with the American complicity and puts Europe before all its limits. Erdogan seems to think he can now afford everything, including hitting our allies in the international anti-Isis coalition, which are crucial to their heroic resistance to defeating the Islamic State. The time has come to talk about extraordinary actions and economic sanctions aimed at the interests of the oligarchy linked to Erdogan and political retaliation far stronger than the mere suspension of accession negotiations and the reduction of funds. If we do not do so now, if we stand by and watch again out of fear, then Europe really will have betrayed all its values. I've known them up close in recent years. I have known the audacity of Kurdish men and women. Thousands have died for our safety. They do not deserve our indifference today. Let us show that Europe is there or will not be a second chance.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, what we feared has become a reality and Turkey has attacked.  I don't think we can wait. If this situation continues, then, of course, the EP must adopt its position in the form of a resolution, but today the executive authorities in particular must respond, and therefore: I would really like to hear from the High Representative what she will do today, what will she do tomorrow to stop turkey's attack on the Kurds in northern Syria?  You can't wait here. We know that the UN Security Council is being convened, now that we are, and the EU cannot wait. This is a huge violence, a huge injustice that we are witnessing, and Turkey, as has already been said here, has an association agreement with the EU that has not yet been completely interrupted. We have leverage and pressure on Turkey and we have to use them 100% of them. I beg your reply, High Representative.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the war-mongering chants from Ankara and the build-up of Turkish firepower on the Turkish-Syrian border is a sure sign that President Erdoğan is preparing to attack the peaceful enclave of Rojava, where Kurdish women have been rebuilding society through a new model of grassroots democracy, following the defeat of Daesh by the Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) and their allies. It is they who liberated the Yazidi women from their mountaintop prison in Sinjar, eventually opening the way for a sustainable peace process. More than 11 000 men and women from the SDF gave their lives to liberate this region from Daesh. Twenty-two thousand more were wounded in the campaign. I visited the graves of the YPG and the YPJ martyrs in Kobane as part of a women’s peace mission in May 2018, and I paid tribute to their bravery. The West’s abandonment of the Kurds is a stain on all of us. I am proud to be a true friend to the Kurds, and that means telling the truth about the fascist dictator Erdoğan.

name: Tineke Strik (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, the occupation of Turkey in North Syria is not only a slap in the face of the Kurdish forces who have fought ISIS and are now in imminent danger; it is also extremely dangerous for the two million refugees that Erdoğan threatens to send back to Syria. Despite this threat, Commissioner Avramopoulos talked with Turkey about refreshing the EU-Turkey deal only last week. It’s high time to show that this deal doesn’t hold a grip over the EU’s foreign policy. I’m happy to learn that the High Commissioner is urging Turkey to refrain from military occupation and to refrain from the deportation of refugees. But what will be the repercussions if President Erdoğan refuses to do so? Is the EU prepared to step up its resettlement efforts?

name: Mick Wallace (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the aggression of the Turkish forces is a clear violation of international law and of the sovereignty of Syria’s borders. In the light of the betrayal of the Americans and the apparent genocidal attitude of the Turkish Government towards the Kurds, it should be condemned in the harshest of terms. We should now support the Russian Foreign Minister’s call for dialogue between the Syrian Government and the Kurds on the current situation. This suggestion has been welcomed by the Kurds and they look to Russia having a role in the talks.  Ms Mogherini said that Turkey is a key partner of the EU and Syria, and do you know what, Ms Mogherini, you’re actually right. And sadly you were partners with them. Sadly, you too were part of the American and a Saudi effort to destabilise Syria. You armed the jihadists. The lies that have been told of what’s happened in Syria is too bad and, but for Russia and Iran, things would be so much worse there. Why don’t you just lift the sanctions against Syria and create a facility where it would be more possible for refugees to return home. You said the Syrian conflict cannot be ended with weapons; well why the God damn did Europe keep pumping weapons into the place? Tell me that!

name: Milan Uhrík (NI).
text: – Madam President, dear Ms Mogherini, the war is on again. You were talking mostly about Turkey, but what do you think about the fact that the US practically left behind the Kurds to the aggression of Turkey? This could, of course, cause a new influx of immigrants also into Europe. Isn’t this also a warning for European countries: that we shouldn’t rely on an alliance with the US, because one day we could also be left behind when we need it the most? Shouldn’t European countries rely more on their own defences instead?

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, first of all, I am glad to see, beyond some nuances or differences in tone, the same kind of analysis across the Chamber on the fact that this military intervention which Turkey has started in the north—east of Syria has to be stopped. I see that this unites the Chamber, as it has united the European Union Member States. I am often asked here to make sure that the European Union speaks with one voice, and a clear voice and on time. In this case, I believe we have been speaking clearly – extremely clearly – and early. As I said, we first reacted immediately after the news of the telephone call between President Trump and President Erdoğan came out, during my visit to Jordan, and today we have reacted again with the clear and official position of the 28 Member States, which I stated just a few hours ago. So: first we are expressing a clear, united position in time for it to be effective at least as a call; and second, we are coordinating with partners – partners in the region, partners beyond the region and other international organisations including, obviously, the United Nations. I’m glad that we managed, on the initiative of the European Union Member States sitting on the Security Council, to have this point on the agenda there, because it is there that it should be addressed. Furthermore – something that has not been raised here so far and I am surprised about that – you might have seen that NATO Secretary General Stoltenberg intends to have contact with one of the NATO Allies, namely Turkey, on this issue. I believe that we need to at least exchange views and opinions with them as well, to try and avoid this military intervention going on. That is, I believe, the urgency at the moment, and I feel the same sense of frustration, urgency and sorrow that many of you have expressed about what is happening today: not only for the civilians who once again are victims, not only for the already internally displaced people in that area who are suffering again, but also for the Kurdish forces who have been fighting in the coalition against Daesh. I very much agree with what some of you have said: the priority today is to focus on the UN-listed terrorist organisations. That means Daesh, first and foremost, and definitely not the Kurdish forces. Turkey has a different reading on this. We have had discussions several times in a very open manner with Ankara about this. For the European Union, these forces are definitely not to be defined as terrorist organisations. The other thing that we will put in place is a discussion with the Foreign Ministers, on Monday. That is already being prepared now. Today we had preparatory meetings and in the coming days these will continue – to see what other actions or reactions we can take from now to then, and to prepare for the European Council that will take place just a couple of days later. Some of you have raised other issues and elements on which you have asked me to act. The honourable Members know very well that it is not in the hands of the High Representative to take decisions which ultimately lie, in some cases, with the European Parliament itself – on the allocation of funding, for example – and, in some cases, with individual Member States – on the export of arms, perhaps – or the Council, as with the possibility of introducing targeted measures or sanctions or stopping financial flows. I want to say one thing here though: I believe we have to be careful not to mix things up in a way that can be dangerous. Some of you referred to the controversial, but ongoing, support that we are giving to Turkey – and not only to Turkey but also to other countries that are hosting Syrian refugees in the region. I want to name here Jordan and Lebanon and also Iraq and Egypt. We are giving this financial support not to those countries but to international organisations, starting with the UN agencies that are helping the Syrians in those countries. I believe the Syrians would be the victims – not twice or three times but four times over – if we had to think about stopping that financial support, because it is thanks to the European Union financial support that the Syrian refugees are being helped. And the EU support is going to those international organisations in those hosting countries – among them Turkey, yes, but the money doesn’t go to Turkey. I’ve said that in this Chamber many times, but it was in a different parliamentary term so I will repeat it today. That money, the money that supports the Syrian refugees in Turkey, as well as in other countries of the region, is not going to the Turkish authorities. It’s not going to Turkey. It’s going to international agencies, it’s going to international NGOs, and it’s going to the UN agencies for the Syrian people. I believe it would be a mistake to make them suffer – on top of what they’re suffering already – for the current situation as well. Having said that, you can count on my full determination not only to ensure we do everything we can to protect civilians at this time – and to join forces with those with whom we can join forces to protect civilians – but also, most importantly and beyond that, to stop this military intervention. It is a mistake from so many points of view, and most of you have said that: from a humanitarian perspective; from the perspective of our achievements against Daesh; and – I’m surprised none of you mentioned this but I want to insist on it – in terms of the possibility of it seriously undermining the relaunch of the political process under UN auspices. Two weeks ago we were hosting, as we do every year at the UN, the event on Syria. There, together with Geir Pedersen, we were saying that maybe this is the beginning of a new possibility for the political process to start, and it’s the first time in years that there has been a tiny step forward on the possibility of achieving a political solution. Now, two weeks later, we have this, which has also put at risk that very limited sign – but a sign nonetheless – of hope for the possibility of starting the political process. Obviously, it is also a mistake for all the other reasons that have been mentioned here, including with regard to regional balances. So I really hope that we will manage to join forces with others. I really hope that this issue can be addressed properly in the UN Security Council tomorrow. You can count on me personally and on the European Union’s institutions, the Council and Commission, to do what we can, and obviously I count on you, the Parliament, to try and use these hours to apply maximum pressure, and try to stop this intervention that is definitely not going to bring anything good.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Anna Fotyga (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I am following the situation in northern Syria very closely. I am afraid that developments in this complex region could have serious geopolitical consequences. I appreciate the role of the Kurds in the fight against ISIS terrorists. I also understand Turkey's long-standing enormous burden on the refugee problem and recognise the security risks to the country.  Unfortunately, today, the mistakes and omissions made by the West at crucial moments of the war in Syria, such as the lack of a decision to ban military flights, are even clearer. We lack a consistent strategy. I am afraid that the creation of a refugee zone – largely Sunni, for many years in Turkey – will create an even greater imbalance in the region. I am concerned about the possible increase in the importance of players such as Iran and Russia, whose actions so far, including on a global scale, have not served to stabilise.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. – In 1974, as a child, I experienced Turkey's invasion of Cyprus. But I got away with it and promised not to be silent in the face of similar crimes against humanity. Today, I hear the same lies, the same dirty propaganda, and the same crimes against humanity are committed by the well-known criminal of Ankara, as they were then. The criminal called the invasion of Syria a "peace operation" and the ethnic cleansing and movement of populations for purposeful settlement supposedly "creating a safe zone". The criminal who financed and supported the Islamic State, the modern scourge against humanity, is now attempting to eradicate the Kurds, the main ally of the civilized world against the barbarity of the Islamic State. As the European Union, we can impose an arms embargo, crush Erdogan's economy and allocate humanitarian aid funds to the Kurdish population instead of Turkey. However, interests and dependencies require EU officials to continue to call the criminal a "strategic partner." I don't expect much from those who speak publicly about values but invent arguments for the criminal to be criminal. Today, I am addressing the Kurdish fighters to assure them that the conscience of Europe is not the dependent officials. Europe's conscience is with them, against the criminal.

name: Leszek Miller (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I strongly view the Turkish military operation against the Kurds in northeastern Syria. Over the past years, the European Union has worked closely with the Syrian Democratic Forces against the Islamic State. Thanks to this cooperation and the sacrifice of the many thousands of Kurds who died in the fight, real results have been achieved in the fight against terrorism.  Unfortunately, now, as a result of an incomprehensible decision by the US administration, thousands of radical ISIS fighters and henchmen held in Syrian prisons will be released to fight again. The horror that isis jihadists have experienced in northeastern Syria can therefore be repeated.  In the face of the abandonment of Kurdish forces by US allies, the European Union should immediately take diplomatic action to bring about a solution to the crisis as soon as possible. All forms of pressure on Turkey to stop the offensive against the Kurds should be used. We should also consider immediately directing the necessary humanitarian aid and in-kind support to the area covered by military action in order to reduce as much as possible the suffering of civilians.

name: Bettina Vollath (S&D)
text: Writing. – Today, 9 October 2019, the Turkish Government has begun its war against minorities under the cynical title 'Operation Peace Source'. In doing so, Erdogan has made it definitively clear that he is not a reliable partner for the EU. The invasion is a humanitarian disaster. Displacement and new movements of refugees will follow. The region is already home to many members of minorities who have fled ISIS and found security there. The population is already heavily dependent on humanitarian aid. This threatens to escalate the whole situation in the region. The Turkish invasion is a violation of international law. The EU has the opportunity to impose economic and diplomatic sanctions and should use them. The arms sales of individual European Member States to Turkey are also completely wrong. We know that these weapons are being used against minorities. We owe it to the Syrian forces to liberate is FROM ISIS. Dutch S&D MEP Kati Piri stressed in the debate: "They were the ones who were fighting on the ground." If we take human rights seriously, it is now up to us to take all the necessary measures to prevent the war against Rojava.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Ukraine (2019/2834(RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, in these five years, the citizens of Ukraine have been calling for change in their country. I say five years because, when I started as High Representative, Ukraine was almost the only issue on our foreign policy agenda.  In one sense I am worried that this is slipping away, as if problems were disappearing, and I am grateful to the European Parliament for putting this issue on the agenda. This will also be on the agenda of the Foreign Affairs Council next Monday, exactly because I want to make sure that the attention does not get lower at this moment on the situation in Ukraine.  The citizens of Ukraine in these five years have been calling for change in their country, they have been working for change in their country. They have asked for reforms that would improve their lives, with more transparency, more honesty and no corruption. They have asked for a fully sovereign country, free from war and from foreign interference. And they have asked for a strong and close partnership with the European Union. They have not only asked for these things, they have also worked for these things. Since our first debate on Ukraine five years ago, Ukraine has come a very long way. This has been possible first and foremost thanks to the determination of the citizens of Ukraine, their constant work for a better country. Throughout these years, the European Union has always stood at the side of the Ukrainian people. After 2014 we put together for Ukraine the biggest support package in the history of the European Union, with over EUR 15 billion. We have invested more in Ukraine than in any other country in the world. No other partner has invested in Ukraine as much as we have done. Our Association Agreement – which has now entered into force – is the most ambitious agreement that the European Union has ever developed with any other partner. It has already delivered an impressive increase, for instance, in our trade by almost 50%. Our support and our cooperation are having a very tangible impact on people’s lives. We have supported the creation of thousands of new jobs and helped deliver, through decentralisation, higher quality services for the citizens. We have accompanied the reform of the security sector. And two years ago, we made travelling to the European Union easier for the people of Ukraine, thanks to visa liberalisation. I have always believed that the best we could do for the people of Ukraine was to be there for them, was to accompany this quest for change, this quest for reform and this work that they have done themselves to change their country profoundly and to give our full support to this work for change. And I believe that the people of //!!Europe!! Ukraine// understand and appreciate and know very well how close we have become in these years. After his election, President Zelenskyy chose Brussels as the destination of his first foreign visit, and he hosted the EU-Ukraine Summit in Kyiv/Kiev? in July – I was honoured to be there for an excellent meeting that we had. I met Foreign Minister Prystaiko two weeks ago in New York and he will be with us at the Foreign Affairs Council on Monday in Luxembourg.  The simple and powerful message that I will be proud to pass, I think I would say both of us, together, on Monday is this: the European Union and Ukraine have never been closer. This is something we say about other partners, but for Ukraine – if you look at five years ago – this was definitely not to be taken for granted. I believe this is an achievement that we can celebrate together.  The new government has taken a bold approach to reforms. Expectations in public opinion are very high. The number of legislative acts adopted since this summer is unprecedented, and we are ready and willing to support the government in ensuring that this wave of legislation truly delivers in practical terms. For instance, we are ready to work with the government as it seeks to review some of the reforms in the judicial field. The citizens of Ukraine expect to see the first results of this push to make their country more transparent and fair for all. Another extremely important area continues to be the fight against corruption. Improving the business and investment climate and tackling the oligarchic structures is also crucial to unleash Ukraine’s economic potential, but I would say for having a healthy environment in the country altogether. We also continue to engage on energy sector reform, and we look forward to the unbundling of gas transmission from production and supply, which should happen by the end of this year. We are also working with Ukraine and Russia through our dialogue to conclude a new gas transit contract. It is essential to use the current momentum in the best possible way, respecting all democratic procedures and in constant consultation with the country’s vibrant civil society. Thanks to these reforms and to our concrete support to these reforms – from the creation of the Anti-Corruption Court to security sector reform – Ukraine is today a much stronger country than it was five years ago. That is clearly visible today.   Our neighbours’ strength and resilience is obviously a core interest of the European Union. At the same time, we should never forget that Ukraine is still suffering a violation of its sovereignty and territorial integrity. Crimea is Ukraine, Donbas is Ukraine, and the European Union will continue to keep this position in the most unequivocal and united manner.   Through the years, we have never stopped working for the full implementation of the Minsk agreements. We have always managed to keep our unity on this, and I can tell you that five years ago, there were many that were betting on this: in the first place for it not to be possible; and then for it not to be possible to keep it.   We have always managed to keep our unity on this, and I am proud of it because this was and still is the right thing to do, and I am sure that we will continue to keep our unity in the years to come.   In recent weeks, we have witnessed some important developments in the Normandy format and in the Trilateral Contact Group. The outcome of the Trilateral Contact Group meeting in Minsk on 1 October, on the so-called Steinmeier formula, is a step that could hopefully lead to some progress towards the full implementation of the Minsk agreements by all parties.   It should be clear that the Minsk agreements remain central to reaching a lasting peaceful solution to the conflict in eastern Ukraine, to end the fighting and the suffering of so many people. It is crucial to sustain the progress in disengagement and constructing the bridge in Stanytsia Luhanska. And we need a lasting ceasefire, towards the ultimate goal of restoring Ukraine’s control of its whole territory.   We have never stopped supporting the work of the Normandy format, the Trilateral Contact Group, and the OSCE. And we will continue to do so until Ukraine’s sovereignty and territorial integrity are fully restored.   In the meantime, we have welcomed and we welcome the recent exchange of prisoners between Ukraine and Russia. That included the crew of the Ukrainian vessels detained by Russia last November in the Kerch Strait – a situation that we have discussed with Parliament several times – and Oleh Sentsov, whom you have awarded with the Sakharov Price. This is good news, and we will always encourage any step that can bring us closer to a solution.   We continue to call on Russia to release all illegally detained Ukrainians, and to ensure free passage through the Kerch Strait in accordance with international law. We are also investing in the infrastructure and security of the south-eastern regions of Ukraine that are affected by the situation in the Kerch Strait. We should never forget or underestimate these immense challenges that Ukraine is still facing. And at the same, I believe we should always continue to believe in the immense potential of Ukraine and its people and invest in it. After five years of work, I am proud of the progress we have achieved together in these years, in extremely difficult circumstances. And I am sure that – with this Parliament’s support – we will continue to stand at Ukraine’s side, as the country’s closest friend.

name: Sandra Kalniete
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the – Dear sitting leader! Ukraine has agreed to implement the Steinmeer formula for a solution to the conflict in eastern Ukraine. However, the question that has changed since 2016, when the formula was proposed, is justified. Almost nothing. I would like to believe that this agreement is a step towards peace, but there are still doubts. Because, in fact, russia will benefit from this agreement, because holding elections in the Donetsk and Luhansk regions would gain legitimacy for the separatists. And that is what Russia needs to return to the international community. There is even talk that Russia could make a promise to stop Ukraine's rapprocement to the European Union and NATO for its tolerance. In addition, protests against this forced agreement are already beginning in Ukraine. They can destabilise society and the country. And this, too, is beneficial to Russia, so we Ukrainian friends must follow developments very carefully to prevent the Donbass problem and the annexation of Crimea from disappearing from the international agenda. Thank you!

name: Kati Piri
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, over the past years, Ukraine has undergone a difficult political transition. The results of the presidential and parliamentary elections have given President Zelensky a clear mandate: the citizens of Ukraine demanded peace and higher living standards, as well as resolute action against corruption, and accountable public institutions with a modern judicial system at their core. With the ongoing conflict in eastern Ukraine, despite the progress made, the risk for political instability in Ukraine is still high. Some countries are trying to take advantage of such instability: the latest scandal involving the President of the United States is a showcase. Renewed momentum for diplomatic efforts is welcome and should be supported, but while we understand the context within which negotiations between Russia and Ukraine are taking place, the handover of a key suspect of the MH17 tragedy to Russia is, and remains, unacceptable. It is an offense to the victims and their relatives, and they deserve those responsible to be brought to justice.

name: Petras Auštrevičius
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement and our partnership with the Ukraine is delivering positive results, based on the comprehensive framework agreed in 2014. Ms Mogherini, I completely agree with your assessment in this regard.  We expect the new Government of Ukraine to embark on an ambitious and timely pace of continuous reforms, especially in large-scale privatisation, land reform, energy, healthcare and, of course, the fight against corruption. The transformation process in Ukraine, as well as in other Eastern Partnership countries, will take time, and it’s important to maintain not only their ambition and strategic focus, but also ours. We are entering the next generation partnership with Ukraine, dominated by the principle ‘more for more’, and it should lead towards a gradual opening of the EU single market to Ukraine’s economy. Furthermore, it is of utmost importance to involve Ukraine and other Eastern partners in major EU initiatives on digitalisation, migration, social inclusion, sustainable energy and climate change.  Ending Russian aggression and achieving lasting peace is a shared European and Ukrainian hope. We are seeking peace and the EU should not create illusions, especially ones undermining the legitimate interests of Ukraine, and should avoid fake agreements such as the former Budapest Memorandum.  Our actions within the soon-to-be-resumed peace negotiations need to be firm and reflect our commitment to a sovereign Ukraine and its people’s choice. We should help to achieve the eventual removal of all armed groups from the occupied territories of Ukraine, and Ukraine regaining full control of its border with Russia. Recent rallies in Kiev stand as a reminder that no agreement is possible unless accepted by everyone. I call on the Commission to elaborate and support a package for Ukraine’s macro-economic stability, including a social-stability package for the population of the occupied territories of Ukraine.

name: Viola Von Cramon-Taubadel
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the The people of Ukraine carried out a revolution at the ballot box in the parliamentary election on 21 July with their election decision. More than 80% of the Members of the Rada are new. This is both an opportunity and a challenge for Ukrainian democracy. It must therefore be in all our interests to continue to support this young democracy in Ukraine to the best of our ability. Although, as we have just heard, global crises are naturally increasing on a daily basis, this must not lead to the situation in Ukraine becoming out of focus. Ukraine, too, is still at a real war in the east of the country, and there are almost 3 million internally displaced persons there too. At the same time, we should be honest and also subject the country to critical monitoring. We must take the fight against corruption and the oligarchy more seriously. We owe this to the young Ukrainian citizens, especially the young generation. Under the old government, important reforms were initiated: decentralization, health reform, and public procurement. Moving these reforms to the next phase, thereby improving social standards, especially in the regions, would be an important signal to increase confidence in policy and institutions. The success of the reforms in Ukraine will therefore also depend on whether and how we accompany, support and, at the same time, take responsibility from Brussels to the new colleagues in the Ukrainian Parliament.

name: Lars Patrick Berg
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, High Representative, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. A few weeks ago, I was allowed to take part in an election observation mission to the parliamentary elections in Ukraine. I remain impressed by the commitment of the people, especially young people, to Ukraine and their commitment to democracy and the rule of law, and I firmly believe in the territorial integrity of the Ukrainian state. I am therefore pleased that, as a result of the Minsk talks, local elections are held in eastern Ukraine, attended by observers from the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe, in order to ensure that the elections are conducted freely and fairly. I am even more pleased that these elections cannot take place until troops have withdrawn from the area. De-escalation is to be welcomed in any case. This is a courageous step by President Selenskyj and all the other parties to the conflict involved, and I sincerely hope that we can support this initiative.

name: Witold Jan Waszczykowski
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, recently several new Ukrainian affairs have captured media attention. They do not give us a chance to forget about the conflict. One was the so—called Steinmeier Formula – a proposal to hold local elections in Donbas under OSCE and other supervision. The agreement does not however mention any military solution in Donbas. The proposal is in line with the Russian concept to federalise Ukraine, which may lead to autonomy of the regions, weakening of the central government and increased Russian influence.  I understand the search for a compromise solution. The democratic Ukrainian leadership has a full mandate to try to solve these terrible dilemmas in its own way. However, I should signal cautious behaviour, to be careful not to fall into another one of Putin’s traps. Only relying on the Normandy format has not led to a solution of the conflict. It seems that some do not want to resolve the conflict in favour of Ukraine. They want to get rid of the problem and to return to business relations with Moscow. Warsaw, therefore, reminds European capitals and Kiev that solutions to this international dispute must be based on current international law and respect for victims’ rights.

name: Mick Wallace
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, in February 2014 Ukraine replaced its democratically elected government with a strongly anti-Russian government. It wasn’t a revolution; it was a coup. It was organised by the US, as exposed by the taped phone conversations of Victoria Nuland, Obama’s central agent there at the time. I think the advancements made by Zelensky and the Russians towards peace in eastern Ukraine are to be warmly welcomed. People who are highlighting or voicing resistance to the deal made with Russia should ask: what do the Ukrainian people want? Zelensky won over 70% of the vote on a pro-peace platform: that’s what the Ukrainians want. In Ukraine, the opposition to the prospect of peace is mainly coming from neo-Nazi groups, which played a terrible role back in 2014 and since. There’s also opposition by people who have a vested interest in filling the place with arms still. Ukraine has many challenges: millions have left the place; 80% of employment is in the black market; they need independence. They should be independent of Russia and of the West, but whether Zelensky has the power to bring that about, we only have to wait and see.

name: Milan Uhrík (NI).
text: – Mr President, colleagues. If we want to facilitate peace in Ukraine, then first of all, it must be said openly that how it all started. That the secret services and NGOs, funded also from Brussels, but especially from Washington, took advantage of the frustrations of ordinary Ukrainians, frustration with oligarchy, corruption, and organized the Maidan first, and then the civil war unleashed. That after five years of conflict, after thousands of dead people, billions of euros spent and dollars spent, the situation in Ukraine is worse than ever, and peace is in sight. And why? I'll tell you without censorship. Simply because ukrainians do not care about anyone in this conflict. It is only about Western firms gaining new markets and weakening Russia's position in Europe. If the European Union really wants to help Ukraine, then it is best to do so by letting Ukrainians decide for themselves, when it communicates with Ukraine, to do business, because Ukrainians can decide for themselves, they are not fools.

name: Traian Băsescu (PPE).
text: – Mr President, although minorities in Ukraine have put their hopes in President Zelensky's election promises, according to the new Minister of Education, I quote, the schools of national minorities who speak in a language of the European Union from September 2023 will move on to teaching in Ukrainian.  Kiev must understand that minorities on the territory of Ukraine, whether ethnic Romanians, Hungarians or Russians, have the right to retain their language, customs and culture, thereby contributing to the enrichment of Ukraine's cultural heritage. I make it clear that more than half a million Romanian speakers live in Chernivtsi, Odessa and Transcarpathia. The solution for ending this social dispute between minorities in the territory of Ukraine...  (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Sven Mikser (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I believe that all efforts to support Ukraine’s reform agenda and sustainable peace in Ukraine deserve to be commended. However, it is not just peace that is missing: we should not forget that Ukraine’s sovereignty and territorial integrity continue to be violated. I very much agree with the High—Representative that we should stick to the measures which were put in place following Russia’s aggression against Ukraine and the illegal annexation of Crimea until such time as Russia has fully complied with its international obligations. Furthermore, I believe that our efforts to achieve sustainable peace in Ukraine must be driven neither by our desire to return at any cost to business as usual with Russia, nor by the Ukraine fatigue in our capitals, but rather by a very strong commitment to making sure that the wrongs done by the aggressor are righted and Ukraine’s sovereignty and territorial integrity, as well as its legitimate aspirations, are honoured by all.

name: Bernard Guetta (Renew).
text: Mr President, the exchange of prisoners between Ukraine and Russia gives us hope. It seems that Mr Putin has finally understood that he is getting bogged down in the Donbass and that China is certainly more threatening than the European Union is to his country. We know what he would have to do to end hostilities. Until it resolves, the Union will have to maintain its economic sanctions, but it takes two to get back to reason. Ukraine is the victim but it also has actions to do and Mr Zelensky has to reckon with less wise than he does. Is it not time, therefore, to remind all Ukrainians that we have provided them with more than EUR 15 billion in financial assistance in recent years, that we stand by them on the political-diplomatic front and that they must, therefore, help us to help them by standing up to their President?

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Honourable High Representative, honourable Members, as well as in the previous debate concerning Turkey, and here I will draw your attention to the need for a bolder and more organised policy of the Supreme Representation of the European Union with regard to the Government of the Republic of Ukraine. Yes, there are problems that need to be and can be solved. But I would like to draw your attention to the fact that there are several large groups of national minorities recognised in Ukraine. They are Romanian, Hungarian, Bulgarian (not to miss any). And when negotiating with the Government of Ukraine and the new President Zelenski, the rights of these minority groups must be clearly raised. These are minorities of Countries of the European Union. And we must encourage Ukraine to join the European Union as quickly as possible, but while preserving the rights and legitimate interests of these population groups. And that's in the foundation, at the heart of our founding treaties.

name: Nathan Gill (NI).
text: – Mr President, Article 19 of the UN Declaration of Human Rights states that everyone has the right to freedom of opinion and expression. This includes the right to receive and impart information and ideas through any media, regardless of frontiers. Every dictatorship and repressive regime immediately seeks to close down the freedom of the press and media, thinking foolishly that they can silence opposition. Ukraine’s previous President, Petro Poroshenko, tried, using legal process, to silence media that did not act as his mouthpiece. This was condemned and it failed. Ukraine has a new President, Volodymyr Zelensky, who is following the same old tired pattern. Despite claiming to be different, he has used legal process to strip TV stations of their licences and is threatening those he does not like. Ms Mogherini, are you content to remain silent and allow this repression of freedom? Or are you going to use your influence with President Zelensky to protect the freedom of the press?

name: Radosław Sikorski (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Ms Mogherini, for the record, I’m confident I don’t have to tell you how important this is, and that the principle that borders should not be changed in Europe by force is sacrosanct with this House. Therefore, if we were to find a solution in the Crimea Donbass, the people’s will should be freely expressed there – not under the barrel of a Russian gun. But I would also like to remind you that this should be a European issue: Ukraine is under Russian aggression because they chose to have an association agreement with us. They wanted their country to be more European. Therefore, I think the Geneva process – the EU, you, the United States, Ukraine and Russia – is perhaps a better formula for resolving this issue, rather than Member States freelancing on their own. Good luck.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Peace is one of the most precious values in international relations, it is obvious. We sincerely wish the new authorities in Kiev that the war that has been bleeding the Donbass since 2014 will end as soon as possible. However, sitting down for talks with Russia, it should be remembered that for Moscow any signal of readiness to compromise is a sign of weakness that will be ruthlessly exploited. Such historical experience has not only Poland, but also Ukraine itself. It is worth mentioning here the Perejaslav settlement of the 17th century and its effects on Ukraine. Steinmeier's formula can become a lasting guarantee of impunity for Vladimir Putin and absolmes his aggressive policies. It will also be a convenient excuse for France and Germany to start talking about lifting EU sanctions, although there is no justification for such a step. They also see these threats by Ukrainian citizens, who are increasingly protesting against this solution, calling it outright capitulation. It is worth considering these voices.

name: Miroslav Radačovský (NI).
text: – Mr President. I am honoured to sit in the presence of the great British who have chosen to be free and independent of the European Union. I say this because I am a Slav and I am the brother of both the great Russian nation and the great Ukrainian nation. This is a nation that inhabits one-sixth of the world. I can recommend how to solve the matter. Stop interfering with these great nations in their problems. They'll solve them themselves. And that's how you're going to do your best. These are not tiny nations, they are heroic great nations, they have lived together for a thousand years. Stop interfering in the affairs of the Slavs. Slavs are not fools. Slavs are also proud of how proud the British are, and we will solve our problems ourselves. That's all.

name: Andrius Kubilius (PPE).
text: – Mr President, we all know that Ukraine is a victim of Russian aggression because they made the choice of European integration. Ukraine is also a victim of the West’s inability to stop such behaviour from Russia. We see the new leadership of Ukraine seeking solutions, which would help to bring peace, security and integrity of their territory, despite the fact that the key to peace is not in Kiev but in the Kremlin. So we need to praise the Ukrainian leadership for their will to seek peace, but we cannot push them into implementation of some unrealistic formulas. Ukraine deserves our much more serious support in their reforms and attempts to bring stability. Unfortunately, for the time being, it looks like Ukraine is only becoming a victim of the US presidential campaign.  But peace is not only the business of Ukraine. That is why I propose to establish a special steering group in the European Parliament which would take care of the peace process in Ukraine, just as we have a special steering group for Brexit.

name: Beata Mazurek (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Ukraine is the European country that has experienced the most violence and, at the same time, has not received effective support from a democratic Europe. Ukraine decided to move towards the West and resisted Russia's aggression. She has built an army and is trying to carry out the necessary reforms. Ukraine's people have mostly accepted the pursuit of NATO and European Union membership. To maintain this course, Ukraine needs a clear declaration from Western countries that its accession is real. It also needs a clear declaration of when and under what conditions this can happen. Otherwise, supporters of rapprochement with Russia will again gain the upper hand, and Ukraine will move away from Europe. The new Ukrainian authorities are trying to maintain public support and not fail to disappoint the confidence they have placed in the elections. At the same time, part of the territory of Ukraine is occupied. It is up to us, Europe, whether the Ukrainian crisis can be resolved peacefully. However, there is a need for a firm and solidarity-based attitude of the European Union and political and economic support that will allow the new authorities to maintain the pro-European course and carry out the reforms necessary to strengthen the state and consolidate democracy.

name: Александър Александров Йорданов (PPE).
text: – Dear Mrs Mogherini, Mr President, don't you think the Steinmeier formula constantly encourages Mr Putin, encourages him to continue his plan for Ukraine? Does this formula not create prerequisites for long-term blocking of any sovereign decision of the institutions in Kiev? Isn't this actually a formula for less Ukraine in Ukraine? And one more question: corruption. In Ukraine, it is mainly the work of Kremlin-linked businessmen and politicians. It is a Russian product in Ukraine. In this sense, does it not impress you that any concession to the Kremlin is seen as a success of Putin's policy? And where it succeeds, rest assured that Europe is losing. And my view is that it has long been time for some European leaders to stop flirting with Mr Putin.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Dear High Representative, A new president was elected in April and a new parliament and government in Ukraine in July. It is important that the EU pays attention to the activities of the new government from the outset, to help the country transform in a European way and to fully and properly implement the reforms undertaken.  In many cases, the previous administration's reform of Ukraine was accomplished by abolishing or curtailing fundamental democratic human and minority rights. This is where I am thinking, first and foremost, of the law on education and languages, or of instising the mood against the Hungarian minority. In a written question to you, I also drew attention to the atrocities and state harassment of Hungarian leaders and organizations in Transcarpathia. After the change of president, this was somewhat eliminated, but harassment and intimidation of Hungarian community leaders and organizations, especially during the early parliamentary elections, continues. They continue to fail to meet international minority protection commitments, which should be more rigorously accounted for in association councils.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, news of Trump's famous, indeed infamous, call to President Zelensky has partially diverted attention from another key event. Moscow and Kiev have in fact reached an agreement providing for elections in the Donetsk and Luhansk regions, to be held in accordance with the Ukrainian Constitution, under osce observation and without the presence of the military. Subsequently, the adoption of a special statute for Donbass is also planned. This breakthrough comes after a promising ukraine-russia prisoner exchange and will lead to a Normandy summit in the near future, to which I hope the High Representative can also be added. I was impressed by Mr Trump's phone call, which was very harsh, in which the US President accused the EU and its Member States of not doing enough for Ukraine. President Zelensky confessed that he agreed. That is why I believe that Europe has a double important task: to strongly support President Zelensky's decision, despite all the understandable doubts and the necessary cautions, and to ensure that Russia fully respects the terms of the agreement. Five years of conflict have led to 13 000 victims, one and a half million homeless people and 40 000 injured. However imperfect, this agreement... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, media freedom is under threat in Ukraine. According to Ukrainian journalists themselves, the Ukrainian media market is hostile to independent media and freedom of speech.  This is because Ukraine is controlled by oligarchs whose media determines the rules of the game. The media, which seeks to operate truly independently, are then forced to violate their own principles in order to survive. They do not report on all serious topics and overload their employees and hire them illegally. The National Council of Ukraine for Television and Radio Broadcasting does not extend licences or seeks to revoke licences in court from entities seeking balanced broadcasting. Representatives of the Ukrainian media sector therefore call on us to join the fight for genuine freedom of speech and the independence of the Ukrainian media. The question is whether the EP will hear them and we will join them. We should, because at other times, especially on these issues, we are very active and everyone is getting support.

name: Domènec Ruiz Devesa (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I wanted to take this opportunity — because I do not know if I will have it later — to congratulate Federica Mogherini on her excellent work and commitment these five years. I would also like to wish you all the best and that, from now on, you will continue to help the European institutions.  On the question of Ukraine, I do not think we should forget that this debate affects all the countries of the European Union, because perhaps we have a tendency to think that it is a problem that only affects our friends in Central and Eastern Europe. Just as, for example, managing migration flows should not just be an issue that countries on the southern border are concerned about. It is important that we think of Europe, in the context of cross-solidarity.  This debate is also very important to safeguard the political stability of the whole region, maintain a sound neighbourhood policy and enable ukraine, if Ukraine really wants to have a European perspective, to be able to democratically move in this direction.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I will do my part to contribute to your time management.
