I know it is very late and you still have a debate, so I would just like to take this opportunity to thank you for the input on different topics and maybe say just a few words on the fact that, for sure, the protection of minorities and media freedom inside Ukraine is part of our constant work with the institutions and also with civil society. This is an issue that I didn’t raise in my introductory remarks, so I want to add that, because some of you have rightfully raised this issue. This constitutes a constant attention that we have. I also want to guarantee to you that all suggestions and input on different topics, be it on the kind of support we can give to the reform process inside the Ukraine or to the Minsk Agreement implementation and the resolution of the conflict, will be reflected in our discussions with the 28 foreign ministers of the Member States on Monday, but also – and mainly – with our Ukrainian counterparts, as the Foreign Minister will be joining us on Monday. As this might well be my last debate in this Parliament, I would also like to thank the Parliament – this mandate and the previous mandate – for an excellent cooperation, not only on the issue of Ukraine, but also on all foreign and security and defence issues in which the Parliament has played a crucial role over these five years. For me, it has been a real pleasure to share this work with you.  (Applause)

name: President. –
text: Thank you, Ms Mogherini, for coming to Parliament at this very late hour. The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Attila Ara-Kovács (S&D)
text: Writing. – Support the democratic reforms that have begun in Ukraine to increase transparency, create a fairer country and defeat corruption. While Ukraine is in the thres of dismantling the oligarch regime, it is facing an ongoing external threat, its sovereignty and territorial integrity continue to be undermined by the Russians.  The stability of Ukraine is also in the EU's interest, which is one of the reasons why its accession efforts to NATO need to be supported. This is particularly important at a time when the Russians are already interfering in the elections of EU Member States and the EU is dealing with ongoing cyber threats and disinformation campaigns. And the fact that there is still a government within the EU that puts Russia ahead of its country's interests, indebted its country with Russian credit (Paks 2) and allows Russian spies into the European Union through the Russian-controlled International Investment Bank is completely unacceptable!

name: Marek Paweł Balt (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Ukraine, one of the EU's most important neighbours, has been the victim of military aggression which has resulted in the lost part of its territory. The European Union has announced assistance to Ukraine, but our assistance is not enough. We need to get more involved and make these actions more effective so that the people of Ukraine feel that we are supporting them. We should provide the Ukrainian authorities with the technical assistance necessary for the reform of the state. The experience of the Central European Member States is an invaluable example for our eastern neighbour, because they have been able to do what Ukraine should have done. EU assistance must therefore be more effective and, above all, immediate.

name: Joachim Stanisław Brudziński (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – We are seeing the situation in Ukraine, in a country directly adjacent to the eastern border of the European Union and a very important partner of our community. These observations often arouse mixed feelings. On the one hand, we enjoy gestures of goodwill like the mutual exchange of Russian and Ukrainian prisoners. On the other hand, we are once again in a situation where the borders between the two countries have been changed in a forceless manner. We cannot accept this either from our neighbours or anywhere else on the world map.  As the European Parliament, we should be clear and firm in favour of international law being respected in conflict areas too, respecting the rights of national minorities, so that everyone has the right to information and freedom of expression. Let us hope that the so-called Steinmeier formula will not be perceived by Russia as a sign of weakness and taken as a concession to its policy. May it not be an incentive for further aggressive action, more or less camouflaged, as has been the case so far.  A Council meeting will be held shortly, at which the Ukrainian delegation is also to be present. I hope that its work will bring us closer to a peaceful resolution of the conflict in eastern Ukraine in accordance with international law.

name: Urmas Paet (Renew)
text: Writing. – Ukraine has been suffering from Russian aggression since 2014 following russia's annexation of Crimea and the start of hostilities in Donbass. Since the occupation of Crimea, Russia has significantly increased its military presence and repression against those who do not consider the occupation capacity to be legal. The European Union has taken various measures against Russia, including sanctions, to pressure Russia to comply with the principles of international law. At the same time, more and more recent requests for closer relations between the European Union and Russia have begun to be heard. A clear example of this is, for example, the restoration of the rights of the Russian delegation to the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe. At the same time, however, it is important that the EU's foreign and security policy also continues in a unanimous way on Russia and Ukraine, and to ensure that sanctions are not eased or lifted until the reasons on which they were imposed disappear.

name: Sandra Pereira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Much has been said in the debate on the situation in Ukraine, but few voices have recalled the role and responsibility of the European Union in the situation that is currently taking place in ukraine. The support that was given to the 2014 coup d'état opened the door to a junta of a fascist nature. What has happened since then is known: the multiplication, strengthening and institutional legitimacy of fascist militias, the rehabilitation and historical praise of fascism, the civil war, the flight of millions of Ukrainians to neighbouring countries, persecution of organisations and activists, including the Ukrainian Communist Party, whose illegalisation process is still ongoing and which is prevented from participating in elections. The recent election of a new president has not altered the country's political landscape; continues the anti-communist, reactionary, xenophobic and nationalist discourse. To all this the European Union has closed its eyes, even allocated €15 billion in support for reforms since 2014. For this too, the EU has responsibilities in the current situation of the country.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. – In the five years since the situation in Ukraine escalated and our neighbour was attacked by Russia, the European Union has been the partner that helped Ukraine the most. Not only with record loans, but also by opening up the market, introducing visa-free travel, but also by expert advice on solving the most pressing problems, such as judicial reform, the fight against corruption, energy or other areas. The European Union is not a military pact, and our assistance can only be civilian. However, as important as the fight against the aggressor is the restructuring of the functioning of the state, where no reforms have been carried out in the last almost 30 years. Our Ukrainian partners greatly appreciate this assistance and bring results. One of them is that there has been a peaceful handover of power this year and the new government wants to continue the pro-European direction of the country. Mrs Mogherini has a strong credit for these achievements. Our efforts should now focus on finally a ceasefire in Ukraine, Russia withdrawing its troops and the process of annexing the separatist regions back to ukraine's territory. It is striking to me, however, that it has almost completely ceased to be said about Crimea, which has been illegally withsemed from Ukraine. In this respect, the European Union should speak in a much clearer voice and open up this problem in any negotiations with the Russian side.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on authorisation of GMOs (2019/2849(RSP)).

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for giving me the opportunity to contribute to this debate. This discussion is timely as tomorrow this House will vote on draft resolutions objecting to the authorisation of two new genetically modified maize varieties and the renewal of an authorisation for a genetically modified soya bean, all for food and feed use. First let me state clearly: the European Union authorisation system for authorisation of genetically modified organisms has been established by European Union law. Through such legislation the Commission has received from the Council and Parliament a delegation of power to implement the system, but with little or no margin for manoeuvre. The Commission is bound to apply the law and Parliament can only expect the Commission to respect European Union law. Respect for the rule of law is a guarantee of fundamental rights and freedom within the EU and no institution should be blamed for abiding by the law. This does not mean that the Commission does not hear or listen to concerns and it is important to understand all of them, as some are very important. This is why at the beginning of this mandate this Commission proposed to the Council and Parliament to change the legislation on GMOs, in particular in light of the numerous objections voted on by the European Parliament. Unfortunately the last Parliament rejected the Commission’s proposal, without suggesting any amendment. This was clearly a lost opportunity and at the same time a clear instruction to the Commission to continue applying the existing law. This is what we have done. Second, the existing European Union law establishes a system which is science-based and relies on a scientific assessment performed by the European Food Safety Authority, independently of the Commission. Both the quality and the independence of the European Food Safety Authority ensure that human and animal health and the environment are protected within the European Union at a high level with little equivalent worldwide.  The Commission only proposes to authorise genetically modified organisms when the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) has confirmed their safety for humans, animals and the environment. In relation to the authorisations to be voted on tomorrow, EFSA has concluded that they are as safe as their non-genetically modified comparators with respect to the potential effects on human and animal health and the environment. As foreseen in European Union law, the Member States voted in these proposals for authorisation in the Standing Committee. However, the vote showed no qualified majority in favour of or against the approvals. In accordance with the rules on comitology, as adopted by the co-legislators, Parliament and the Council, and the Regulation on genetically modified food and feed, the Commission presented the draft decisions to the Appeal Committee, where again no opinion was reached.  I would like to make it clear here that, under European Union law, without such an opinion the Commission needs to take a decision alone. It does not have the luxury of having no opinion. It is not the Commission’s possibility. What is also sometimes frustrating is that Member States vote behind closed doors and the Commission is not entitled to disclose individual Member State’s vote. Here again, this Commission has considered the situation where Member States hide behind the Commission as very disappointing and unsatisfactory. For that reason, the Commission has proposed to both the Council and Parliament to modify European Union legislation on comitology, so as to ensure more transparency. Unfortunately, little progress has been made on this proposal and I regret this situation because making the Commission a scapegoat can be harmful to Europe. Overall, I hope I have demonstrated that the Commission has processed the applications for these GMOs in full compliance with the procedures set out by the co-legislators and that the Commission has fulfilled its duty.  Allow me to recall that the right of scrutiny of the European Parliament concerns the questions of whether the draft implementing act exceeds the implementing powers provided for in the basic acts. This is clearly not the case. The Commission has faithfully implemented the EU law, and therefore I fail to see the legal assessment that would justify the planned objectives. I would be interested to hear on which legal grounds the objection could be based.  Finally, let me conclude by stating the obvious. Genetically modified organisms are a sensitive issue. Citizens and Members of this Parliament have very strong and diverse views, not based solely on science. Some have concerns: there is a real and serious need to discuss which concerns can be considered as legitimate. Legitimate concerns are a very important area and it would be good to know from Parliament’s side, what does it mean by ‘legitimate concerns’. At the same time, European Union agriculture is highly dependent on imports of genetically modified feed and this is simply a fact that cannot be ignored or dismissed, and we know that Member States that always abstain, they know that. It is important, therefore, to move away from sterile fights. Blame-games between EU institutions can only fuel Euroscepticism. I would call for an open, honest and genuine discussion on our agricultural model, including its sustainability. I genuinely hope this can happen in the future, perhaps as part of the Green Deal and as a new Farm to Fork strategy.

name: Jessica Polfjärd
text: On the other: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr We all want this Parliament to reduce emissions and to protect the environment and the climate. Then we also need to think about how cultivation can be more efficient. In this context, plant breeding will play an important role, regardless of what our political opponents think.  I can only say that EFSA has carried out a risk assessment of these crops and concluded that they are no more dangerous than their conventional counterparts. That is the assessment that the Commission has listened to, and that is why it has not breached its mandate either. The central question is: should we listen to science or should we not listen to science? Then I have to ask those who are against this proposal: what is it then that we should listen to if we do not believe and trust the science and opinion that EFSA has made?  I can only regret that it seems to be ignored. We believe that this remains an important issue for the climate and how we can grow in the future.

name: Günther Sidl
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the It is fundamentally incomprehensible to me that genetically modified products should be imported into Europe, where a health risk to our citizens cannot be completely ruled out. In these specific cases, it is feed from herbicide-resistant plants, which have often been treated with far too much weedkiller.  Today's debate also provides an opportunity to refer once again to the statements made by president of the Commission, Mr Von der Leyen, which were also confirmed by the Commissioner-designate for health, namely that resolutions which have a majority of this Parliament will be taken into account in future Commission decisions. I am curious to see whether these statements are valid if we reject imports of gm stechs here in this House tomorrow and in the future. That would be real progress.

name: Jan Huitema
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Commissioner, we as the new Renew Group are not at all opposed to GM as a technique. In some cases, we are correct for the use of GMOs. We therefore want to have a major substantive discussion soon on the application of GMOs, the risks and the potential of the use of GMOs. I myself do not agree with this objection because I do not think that the European Commission has done its job wrongly. If you think the outcome should be different, then that is the task of the legislator – among others we here – to amend the legislation and to give the Commission a different mandate. How many objections have we had about this? Maybe 40. I think that is an inflation of this political instrument. What worries me is that EFSA's conclusions are always called into question. And why am I worried about that? Because I think it's very important that we have an objective referee who is going to scientifically look at whether something is dangerous or not. That is precisely what we have decided as politicians to prevent us from having a political welles-nietes game here in this Parliament on, for example, chemical pesticides and GMOs. So I would like to call on you as colleagues to do the negative assessment of a referee on a football pitch, but to really make sure that we have a very reliable European Food and Consumer Product Safety Authority because otherwise we simply do not get ahead of ourselves at all.

name: Tilly Metz
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his speech. We have heard these points many times, but the fact is that these crops are not safe. The three GMO crops we are objecting to have been modified to be tolerant to several herbicides, one of which is toxic for reproduction and no longer authorised in the European Union. This means ever increasing quantities of herbicide during cultivation, and a higher level of residues on the imported crops. This is dangerous and a vicious circle that is simply ignored by the European Food Safety Association (EFSA) and the Commission. The same goes for the devastating impact on health and biodiversity in the countries of cultivation. We finally need to stop this insanity, not support it through new authorisation. The last Parliament said ‘no’ to GMOs 36 times; tomorrow this new Parliament will hopefully adopt a strong ‘no’. The crucial question is this: will the Commissioner hear us for his decision?

name: Silvia Sardone
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in recent years we have really seen everything: hormone-treated meat, food from harmful GMOs and all kinds of various types of crap. To these, of course, must be added all the taroccati products: the fake Parmesan cheese, the fake cured meats, the fake mozzarella from dubious origins. For the economic benefit of a few, there is a risk of penalising everyone's food health. I believe that food safety and the cultivation of quality products must always be a priority, especially for us, here in Europe, and for this mandate.  However, I think it is absurd for the new Commission to deal with this issue in this way. In general, I do not think it is right that twenty-nine people in a room should decide for more than 500 million citizens. What's going on? Parliament says no to a GMO, the ENVI Committee says no, the Committee of Experts of the Member States does not produce any opinion and in the end what happens? The Commission cares and the GMO continues to be used opaquely. In practice, a bureaucrat in Brussels, locked up in an office of a Directorate-General for Agriculture or Health, decides for everyone. It's really absurd!

name: Anthea McIntyre
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, Greta Thunberg’s message on climate change is ‘I don’t want you to listen to me. I want you to listen to the scientists’. And everyone agrees: listen to the science. When we see a falling—off in the number of parents having their children vaccinated, we say ‘protect your children; listen to the science’. But when it comes to GM maize or GM soya bean, the objectors are saying ‘ignore the science’. These three objections call for us to ignore science. They make spurious assertions about the excessive use of glyphosate, but EFSA’s GMO panel in all three cases found no safety concerns for human consumption. In line with scientific evidence, both EFSA and ECHA produced favourable opinions. The draft measures are in accordance with the legal processes specified in Regulation No 1829/2003. These processes ensure that approved GM products are as safe as their conventional counterparts. We are in danger of undermining the legitimacy of the entire EU regulatory system by continually questioning the objectivity and authority of scientific evidence; by continually rubbishing the science. GM for food use is limited, but there is EU—wide dependency on GM for protein crops for use in animal feeds. We need to get this done. The EU has to decide whether we accept science or not. (Applause in some quarters)

name: Anja Hazekamp
text: , on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, while the Amazon is on fire, the Commission wants to allow genetically modified maize and soy varieties again. Ironic, because the rainforest is being cut down to make way for exactly this genetically engineered corn and soy. Only to satisfy Europe's appetite for animal feed. These corn and soy varieties are resistant to the agricultural poison glyphosate and glufosinate. Glyphosate is probably carcinogenic, according to science. Gluphosinate is banned in Europe because it harms reproduction. Both are nothing short of devastating to biodiversity. By importing this maize and soya, the Commission is endangering the health of people and ecosystems in the exporting countries. Stop these admissions! You no longer have to give the multinationals their way. Your responsibility is not to Bayer, Syngenta and Dow Chemicals, but to the citizens and the future of the planet. I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Marco Dreosto (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the battle against GMOs is not only a healthy and environmental battle, but also an ethical battle, my dear colleague. The preservation of products typical of traditional and historical crops can, on the one hand, preserve biodiversity and, on the other, give the agricultural and rural world a new economic energy and source of income. The cultivation of GMO crops also favours the development of industrial agriculture, based on monocultures, where living species are disappearing at a rate a thousand times faster than the natural one.  The European Parliament, in the last parliamentary term – as we said – approved some 36 objections to GMOs, and yet the Commission continues to authorise them, although it has no obligation to do so. The new European Commission, which is active on the Green Deal, will only demonstrate its commitment by taking concrete action if it listens immediately to this Parliament by not authorising the importation of products containing GMOs which, as we have said here, would lead to greater use of herbicides and consequently to a greater amount of residues in the harvest.

name: Tudor Ciuhodaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, primum non nocere, first of all do not hurt, it is an old medical dictum, and I am a doctor, an emergency doctor, so as long as we find ourselves in front of a product that is not checked and raises big questions in terms of efficiency and food safety, things are beyond doubt. I find it also hypocritical to compare with vaccines, medicinal solutions used for decades that have proven their effectiveness in the context of pre-existing epidemics, with something new to be placed on the market, which no one knows, no one has checked and which does not prevent any catastrophe at this time. Or maybe you're telling me, is there an insecticide epidemic? In these circumstances, I think we need to be very careful in what we want to do. The ethical criteria, the medical criteria tell us to look very carefully so that that ecological pact does not remain just an empty word and a green Europe is not just history. I ask you to look very carefully and such solutions never pass, because as long as there is any risk to the lives of European citizens, we, those sent here democratically, must oppose it. Thank.

name: Eleonora Evi (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is no democracy on the subject of GMOs in Europe, and this Parliament has denounced it several times in its 36 resolutions adopted by a very large majority in the last parliamentary term. Mr Juncker, who promised to review the decision-making process five years ago, also said so. A broken promise, since nothing has changed.  The Member States do not agree, they do not decide yes or no. Those for the 'no' vote raise legitimate doubts about the safety of GMOs for human health and the environment. However, the ball is in the Commission's court which, according to the current rules, always proceeds to authorise new GMOs, but in fact tramples on the will of this Parliament and that of millions of citizens opposed to GMOs and trampling underfoot the precautionary principle, for the umpteenth time. Commissioner, in doing so, we are putting a strain on the resilience of the European institutions and the confidence of the citizens. You said so too. But it is up to the European Commission, which has the legislative initiative, to finally make this process transparent and democratic.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, colleagues, I am very happy to listen to you, and especially let me react to the last speech by Madame Evi.  As you know, Jean—Claude Juncker’s promise was realised. The Commission proposed changes in GMO law to the European Parliament twice, and Parliament decided to reject it – not showing a willingness to cooperate and see which amendments would be better. Now you are once again repeating the situation on what was delivered by the Commission. The proposals offer the possibility to change the rules on standing committees – speaking about transparency and democracy and, of course, the rule of law.  We are all obliged under the rule of law. Now, I’m listening to Amazon issues, to different views. OK. But these are not about the substance and, concretely speaking, about the authorisation of cases which are under strict rule of law conditions. The Commission has no chance to deviate from the rule of law.  Thank you once again. I only want to reiterate a few important points of principle. EU institutions should look for common approaches and solutions, not fight each other. This will only help to fuel – as I mentioned before – conflicts in society, and Euroscepticism. GMOs are a most difficult and very decisive topic, but the Commission today has no choice but to implement existing European Union legislation. The Commission proposed to modify this legislation. I fully regret the situation now, but this is Parliament’s responsibility, because Parliament decided to reject our proposal.  You cannot fully ignore science in our decisions on human health, environmental protection and food safety. We should base our decisions on science, not only on public opinion. I know – speaking about legitimate concerns – that it’s very important to discuss these issues, but we need to know what ‘legitimate concerns’ mean, and not only to put the blame on the Commission. I invite you all to reflect about a sustainable future for European Union agriculture in the light of concerns for the environment, but also on the importance of having fresh, nutritious and healthy food produced in Europe at affordable prices.  European Union food should not be reserved only for its wealthiest citizens. We need to understand, social, economic, and other consequences. We need to be very careful. I once again see only one way: to follow the law, to follow science and to really create a good environment in our debates about legitimate concerns, describing what legitimate concerns mean. Then maybe we will see how we can continue in changing our laws, and so on.  The law is the law and the Commission will follow the law as it is.

text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Edina Tóth (PPE)
text: Writing. – In recent years, new biotechnology processes, including genetic and genome editing, have evolved and are gaining ground. At the same time, genetically modified fodder crops are widespread throughout the world, which can affect biodiversity, contribute greatly to pesticide resistance and are added to the natural environment by genetically modified organisms. It is important to point out that, according to the Eurobarometer report, more than half of Europeans have significant concerns about GM food due to unknown risks. I believe that it should be of the utmost importance for the European Union to ensure access to healthy raw materials for future generations.  Hungary is a strategic issue for the Commission to regulate activities relating to GMOs. In accordance with hungary's GMO-free strategy, the Basic Law and the precautionary principle, we intend to preserve Hungary agriculture free of genetically modified premoids, thus ensuring the production of high-quality, safe and healthy food.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the fight against cancer (2019/2852(RSP)). Before I open the debate, please let me remind you that we are running really late, we are running over time. Therefore, I cannot afford to accept blue-card requests, and catch-the-eye is limited, so I cannot promise that I will be able to grant all requests for the floor. Also, the electronic system is not working at the moment, so please ask for the floor for the catch-the-eye procedure in a standard way.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, Honourable members. It has been 22 days since I last addressed the plenary about cancer. In that time, many people’s lives have been turned upside down by a cancer diagnosis. Hundreds have had cancer treatment, and many patients have walked out of hospital and returned to their daily lives with cancer in remission. Some have also sadly died. My point is that cancer affects nearly all of our lives. I know very well the physical and emotional consequences of this disease, not only as a medical doctor, but also as someone who lost three brothers to this disease.  So I’m happy to stand before you again to reiterate the importance of Europe coming together to beat cancer. We already know that 40% of cancer cases could be prevented by avoiding key risk factors like smoking, alcohol, physical inactivity and excess body weight.  I would like to highlight once again how important it is to grasp this fact and turn it into action. However, this is difficult to achieve when we are only spending three percent of health system resources on prevention. This is simply not enough; this is a drop in the ocean. If we want to succeed, we need to increase this amount and make sure that what we do spend is spent effectively. I will not go again through all that the EU has so far achieved on cancer, but I would like to proudly recall: EU legislation that has been upgraded on chemicals, pesticides and exposure to carcinogens, including at work. Tobacco consumption fell through legislation and anti-smoking campaigns. The European Code Against Cancer, which is spreading the word on prevention. The continuous improvement in coverage and quality of national screening programmes for breast, cervical and colorectal cancer. Twenty—four European Union reference networks, of which four are dealing specifically with rare and complex cancers, especially in children.  This list is not finished; they have more to do. Dear Members, we all agree that we should grasp technological and scientific developments when it comes to cancer prevention, treatment and care. It is essential that this innovation and these developments reach the patients who need them. As you know, investment in research and innovation has been a long-standing priority of the Commission, and this will continue. With its proposal for Horizon Europe, the Commission has introduced a mission approach, which would help to build a coalition to address the most pressing global and European challenges.  One of the first mission areas identified for Horizon Europe is action on cancer to mobilise a broad spectrum of actors, including citizens, patients and all those who care for them. It is a relentless disease, but science is also a relentless, and so is our collective determination to fight this disease. Thank you for your insistence, determination and commitment to put cancer on the EU agenda. I am pleased to see that my successor has been given the privilege to present a European plan against cancer with a holistic approach. This means it will look at prevention, diagnosis, treatment, palliative care and survivorship. I’m sure that, together with you and the Member States, the next Commission will be able to forge a strong alliance to prevent cancer, promote innovation and improve treatment and care in the interests of all.

name: Peter Liese
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Why are we now discussing cancer for the second time in three weeks? Because it is important, but we, as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, also want to make a proposal that we set up a special committee on cancer in the European Parliament. I believe that there is agreement on the objective of combating cancer, thank God. We have two sides to subsidiarity: subsidiarity means that the lower level must do what can be done better there. We cannot regulate some things from Europe. Subsidiarity also means, however, that where the Member States cannot act successfully on their own, Europe must do more, and that is definitely the case with cancer. Let me just mention the example of personalised medicine. We have ever smaller sub-groups of patients, of diseases, and only if we work together at European level can we do good research and good medicine. But why now a special committee? Mrs Kopacz, former Prime Minister of Poland, made this proposal within the PPE-DE. First of all, I thought: is this not what the ENVI Committee has to do? But I was convinced. Firstly, the ENVI Committee has a great deal to do with the green deal, and we should not deal with this issue of cancer in a committee incidentally, but this must be a priority with its own committee. We also need cooperation. We need the expertise from the research of the ITRE Committee, protection in the workplace, social rights also of cancer patients – this is what the EMPL Committee is doing. All this must come together so that we can succeed together for patients. That is why I ask the other groups – when we then take the concrete decision, hopefully in Strasbourg at the next plenary session – to support this comprehensive approach to the fight against cancer. I would like to thank you in advance and thank you for your attention.

name: Nicolás González Casares
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Mr Liese, we agree to discuss cancer, but I believe that, to this day, this Parliament has enough tools, such as the ENVI Commission, where all the groups are represented and where health issues are dealt with. I agree with comprehensive approaches and discuss cancer, but I think we have enough tools to work on it. Cancer needs to be debated, europe's second leading cause of death needs to be discussed, a disease that produces 3.7 million new cases per year must be discussed. Of course, we have to discuss this, but above all, we have to fight cancer every day, with policies that show that we have a determined will. Of course, we have research programmes like Horizon Europe – the continuation of Horizon 2020 in the coming years – that must be the spearhead in the fight from here, from the European Union, against cancer. But let us not forget, from the European People's Party, that there is sometimes a certain bad conscience. The Commissioner said this: public spending on public health, on public health, is important. The cut in public spending and public health results in deaths or, in any case, also reduces mortality reduction. It is therefore ok to discuss this, but we are discussing it from a comprehensive point of view. Let cancer research, advances in prevention reach all citizens of the European Union, no matter where they live.

name: Petra De Sutter
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, we just heard the figures. I won’t repeat them, but I just want to say that in Europe we account for more than 20% of global cancer cases and deaths, whereas we only have 9% of the global population, so something is particularly wrong in Europe. We know that this leads to considerable direct health and indirect social and economic costs, and of course it should be a priority for this Parliament, so I very much welcome the initiative, the debate of today.  However, in light of the ‘health in all policies’ approach, I want to stress that we really should invest much more in prevention because all Europeans are exposed daily to several substances that we know are proven to be carcinogenic or pro—carcinogenic. Banning these should be a key priority because we don’t only need to fight against cancer but also against its causes, and this would perfectly fit in the zero-pollution ambition of the incoming Commission.

name: Joanna Kopcińska
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Currently, projects are underway in Poland to create comprehensive oncology networks aimed at ensuring equal access for all patients. As in Poland, the measures taken are to merge fragmented medical care and combine them into a single coordinated action, so in Europe we should join forces and create a plan of joint and concrete action without excluding anyone.  Therefore, if we are indeed to act here in the European Parliament, let us take steps towards the creation of coordinated health care in order to make the most of the knowledge that the Member States already have. Let us exchange experiences so that the treatment has the characteristics not of accidental and fragmented action, but of an action in which a simple principle counts that the patient's well-being is paramount. May the place of birth, wealth or health insurance reform not be a factor that deprives European patients of hope in cancer. May our actions be joined by the proverbial Polish solidarity, because in the face of illness we can all stand in solidarity with patients whose challenge is to fight the disease.

name: Ewa Kopacz (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The European Commission has been working on the fight against cancer for many years. A lot has been done, but that is still not enough. Europe needs an effective cancer strategy. Europeans deserve a comprehensive and horizontal programme with the best specialists. The introduction of uniform standards in all Member States and the strengthening of conditions conducive to the individual needs of patients are necessary and necessary. We will only win this particular race against time if we are bipartisan in the special committees. One thing we need now is political will, or maybe just goodwill. I am counting on your support. Our citizens are looking forward to Brussels. We must not let them down.

name: Sara Cerdas (S&D).
text: – Mr President, in a European cancer programme, I see a very large focus on early diagnosis and treatment, which are undoubtedly of great importance, but I would like to remind you that 30 to 50% of cancer cases could be prevented by reducing risk factors and by implementing evidence-based preventive strategies.  It is therefore essential to work more articulated between the European Parliament through its ENVI Parliamentary Committee, the European Commission and the Council, thereby eliminating duplication of effort, with better use of available resources in order to provide an efficient response to our citizens.  It is not enough to be in debates, we need to act and implement measures. Citizens want concrete and effective results, want greater investment in cancer research and the development of new diagnostic and treatment technologies, as well as better access to drugs. What concrete strategies will the Commission adopt to reduce the risk factors that are determinant for the development of oncologic disease?  I would like to stress here that the intervention in these determinants should contribute to reducing the development of other diseases, namely other non-communicable diseases, and I would also remind you that this is the main cause of death for European citizens.

name: Dolors Montserrat (PPE).
text: – Mr President, why is it vitally important to set up a Special Commission on The Fight against Cancer in this Parliament? Because cancer is on track to become the leading cause of death in Europe. This year 2019, 1.4 million Europeans are going to die from cancer.  This leads us to react, to act and to make it one of our top priorities. The European Cancer Plan and this Commission will help us to join forces, improve partnerships, improve solutions, have a holistic approach to improving prevention, early detection, increase investment in research. A concerted aid plan is also needed not only for those with cancer, but also for their families; social policies and social aid to their families.  We therefore lead and are determined in the People's Party to set up this commission and to launch this European Cancer Plan. The Europeans are asking us to do so.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: Mr President, according to statistics, one quarter of global cancer cases are reported in Europe: 3.91 million cases for 2018 and 1.93 million cancer deaths for the same year. We must therefore move very quickly and that is why we have asked for this debate today. We have asked for this debate to prepare ourselves, as citizens first of all and as family members, for cancer treatment. We have asked for this debate to look cancer in the eye, to ask for information, to ask for prevention and — ultimately — to ask for treatment. It is not conceivable, when we have 25 % of cancer cases, to spend only 3 % of the resources available. It is not conceivable that Member States should not make use of research financed from European resources, such as the 24 European reference networks for the monitoring of rare cancers.  Let me also ask my country, Greece, to join and support this initiative, as we cannot afford to stay out. Finally, I would like to appeal to everyone in this Chamber, but also to all colleagues who are not here today — so late — let us make the treatment of the disease a personal matter!

name: Tudor Ciuhodaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I have been working for 25 years in the "Nicolae Oblu" Emergency Clinical Hospital in Iaşi and I have seen that most cancers are diagnosed late, when little can be done. So, in my view, two barriers are against early detection and proper treatment, and I'm not just talking about cancer, about any pathology that affects a European citizen.  First of all, it is the educational one, because from school we should learn those knowledge, skills, skills, healthy living rules, so that we adopt a healthy lifestyle and have the first signs that guide us to a diagnosis.  But the most important is the economic barrier, and we are talking about the money we invest in health, because many often do not have access to such innovative techniques, screening methods, early diagnosis and even less treatment. We are talking about money, which is why I told you that I am also unhappy with this year's budget, the multiannual budget, the budget allocated to these regional hospitals, for treatment methods and early diagnosis. Maybe we should work here, and not necessarily to set up new committees.  And last but not least, think that unity in diversity means the same European standard of quality in health, to be treated the same: in Iasi, in Brussels, in Vienna, in Budapest, in Berlin. Thank.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ID).
text: Mr President, my political group Identity and Democracy voted to put this debate on cancer on the agenda. I think it is important that we show the millions of victims of this disease that we think of them and do everything we can to defeat this disease. Commissioner, I was moved by your testimony when you mentioned your three brothers who died of cancer. As you yourself have indicated, we are all victims of this scourge. I myself would like to point out that I lost a dear friend, who was called Édouard Ferrand and who was an MEP. He was one of our colleagues in the previous Parliament; he was swept away in a few months by a devastating cancer. Fortunately, much is already being done to combat this scourge. There has been talk of tobacco control, the fight against people's exposure to carcinogens, a lot of screening programs, but I think it is important to say that more needs to be done. We must help States to fight this scourge and I am glad to have heard you talk about a European plan to fight cancer, which we will of course support with all our strength, because this is not a subject... (the President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I see here all like-minded friends, and I see different political colours can join forces to really address issues on beating cancer. Cancer is a major disease in Europe and it is a common challenge affecting a large number of citizens in our own Member States.  You know, I always repeat four ‘P’s: prevention, promotion, protection. But prevention, promotion, protection of health first of all – healthiness: we need to invest more. But of course the fourth ‘P’ – participation – is very important and we need to invite all actors to participate in those issues because this is so important.  Prevention measures are common to all Member States, but this is not enough. We need to do much more at EU level, using preventative measures to address challenges related to cancer, because national initiatives will not always be able to achieve goals, because sometimes in the single market you can see a lot of risk factors that are acting in the whole of Europe, of the European Union. We need more Europe in prevention. Europe is committed to implementing the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals. This includes reducing premature mortality from chronic diseases such as cancer by one third by 2030. We are in 2019 now. We have only 11 years to act in a more energetic way, really to reduce in one shot all cases. It’s a big task and of course people will be very happy if the European Parliament, the Council and Member State governments do more in this case. I assure you that the Commission will continue its efforts on cancer prevention and control. The proposal for a new cancer plan for the EU, as envisaged by President-elect Ursula von der Leyen, offers a major opportunity to take the next big step forward towards beating cancer in Europe. Together our work will benefit patients, their families, and healthcare and cure services, and of course public health services, in this way to really achieve big progress in this very sensitive area.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at a future part-session. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Josianne Cutajar (S&D)
text: in writing. – The present consensus of this Parliament and the incoming Commission on the need for Europe to embark on a widespread process of digitalisation and technological innovation is very positive and raises optimism, including in our collective determination to fight cancer, which has killed too many of us. Innovation can only be successful if it is human—centred, and if it is human—centred it has to be a tool – if not the best tool we have – to improve treatment provided to cancer patients. It is also the key to improving our prevention strategies. The platforms to spur research and innovation are already set, especially through the Horizon Europe programme, which we are committed to keep bolstering robustly for years to come. Within a mission approach, this programme already puts thrust behind projects aiming to mobilise citizens and improve the tools at our disposal, both in prevention and in cure. However, if we are to ever win this fight, we have to fight it effectively, and that will require this Union to strengthen legislation against toxic chemicals, pesticides and emissions, while truly boosting our investment of resources.

name: Janina Ochojska (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "In May this year, I was diagnosed with breast cancer. Due to public information about my illness, many patients come to me. On the basis of their relationship, I can see more and more clearly that treatment in Poland is struggling with profound systemic problems.  Let me start with positive information: in Poland there is no shortage of equipment for treatment. But there is a lack of staff who can handle this equipment. There is a shortage of doctors, as there are only 2.4 doctors per 1000 inhabitants of my country on average (the eu-wide average is 3.8). Many doctors have left or left the profession due to poor working conditions. Those who remained work after hours, many above their strength. There is a shortage of nurses (the average age of nurses in Poland is 52 years), laboratory specialists and technicians.  We need to educate or accept thousands of new skilled workers to work in this sector. There is a lack of psychological care for patients and their families. Psychological support needs to be built. The pool of research and therapy is insufficient. Often, patients cannot afford to wait in several months of queues for research and treatment. Therapies prescribed for their diseases are not reimbursed. They are forced to pay for research and treatment themselves. We need effective treatment programs. All these shortcomings stem from a huge underfunding of the health service, so in addition to the creation of the ONCO Committee, we must guarantee funding for the fight against cancer.

name: Rovana Plumb (S&D)
text: in writing. – With more than 3.7 million new cancer cases and 1.9 million deaths each year, Europe accounts for 23.4% of cancer cases and 20.3% of cancer deaths globally. Cancer will remain one of the main challenges European citizens will face and it is important for both national and EU policymakers to act towards the implementation of stronger cancer control. We can speak of EU action, but at national level the reality is very different. In some countries, cancer patients do not even get any screening, while in others people die from cancer without even knowing they have the disease. However, this is difficult to achieve when we only spending around 3% of health system resources on prevention. This is not enough! If we want to succeed, we need to increase this amount and spend it effectively. Even more, we should not forget those cancer survivors who are left unchecked and not followed up on properly after the end of the acute treatment phase. It is important to develop national plans to ensure that the healthcare system can fully support cancer survivors’ needs. The survivors can be reintegrated into the workforce and be supported to have a proper working environment according to their needs.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the one—minute speeches on matters of political importance (Rule 172).

name: Gheorghe Falcă (PPE).
text: – Mr President, at this hour, 23.00, I want to talk about swine fever. There have been a lot of outbreaks in my region and I want to understand that we cannot wait for national intervention to solve such a problem. An outbreak of swine fever does not mean a fire where a fireman comes, but it means an outbreak at great risk for an area much larger than a county or country. That is why we should work together, the Commission and the Member States, because where there is an outbreak, where we affect small owners but also large farms, we should have a very rapid action. Thanks.

name: Tudor Ciuhodaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, since I have stayed in health, I will continue with health, because, paraphrasing a great Romanian writer, if love is not, nothing is. I tell you today that if health is not, nothing is, so our financial efforts in the future framework of the European Union should focus on this.  I come from a city, Iasi, on the border of the European Union, from Romania. Six million Moldovans need a regional emergency hospital, and I have come to the European Parliament to ask for this, to be properly funded for health, because we have come to unthinkable situations where a patient is walked between hospitals or in the sky of Europe because he does not have the right medical solution.  I ask you today in the European Parliament to think about this unity in diversity and to do everything possible to implement the European standard of quality in health in these countries and to have regional emergency hospitals and, of course, I will say, first of all in Iasi. Thank.

name: Phil Bennion (Renew).
text: – Mr President, Boris Johnson is playing a dangerous game, but nothing can hide the fact that there is no mandate for no deal, no prospect of a different deal before Council, and no recent opinion polls which give a majority to leave. Be in no doubt: Johnson is absolutely desperate to avoid a second referendum, because he thinks he will lose it. It is a travesty of democracy. He wants to crash us out to please his hedge fund backers who are betting on Britain’s economic decline. My message and the message from the majority of UK MEPs is that we need your patience. We need your help. We need your support in this crisis. We can turn this around, but only if we have a long enough extension for an election and to organise a referendum. Please keep the door open for the British people, especially those who were too young to have voted in 2016. We are fighting. We are determined. We can win for this generation and the next.  (Applause in some quarters)

name: Catherine Rowett (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, colleagues, yesterday we celebrated the magnificent campaign to end the ‘cage age’.  European citizens have spoken. They want the EU to outlaw the caging of farm animals and to do so not in the next century, but next week.  Yet even now, my constituents from the loveliest parts of Suffolk and Norfolk write in desperation, as permission is granted for yet more monstrous prison farms, yet more horrendous poultry processing factories. Neither the UK Government nor the local authorities are moving in the right direction towards eliminating this scourge. We urgently need EU regulations. These factories run counter to all current thinking on animal welfare, human health and environmental protection. They serve no purpose other than the obscene profits for investors, who blithely defile countryside and rivers with the stinking excrement of animals whose lives are too appalling to contemplate. It’s time to heed the cries of both humans and animals.

name: Anna Bonfrisco (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there are increasing calls in the last few hours for Turkey to stop brutal aggression against Syria, a country that has already suffered badly and which certainly cannot suffer any further suffering.  We expect a firm condemnation. The ID Group is calling for a strong condemnation of the European Union, which has even financed Erdogan's government with European taxpayers' money, in an attempt, alas, to protect those Syrian refugees fleeing Isis and the civil war. Today it is probably also because of that money that Turkey can bomb Syria.  The European Union is all too often driven by naïve optimism, and Turkey's is the emblem of this. It is clear that something profound needs to be reviewed in the European project. But the truth is that today we are with our hands tied, in a complex international situation because, lightly, the European Union at the time accepted Turkey's application for membership, rather than rejecting it. We had to reject it then, Mr President, so that we did not find ourselves in this tragic situation today.

name: Jorge Buxadé Villalba (ECR).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Eurostat's data for 2017 indicate that the Union lost 200,000 inhabitants to the difference between births and deaths. The media and economic and social pressure groups, serving their own economic interests, frighten the population with apocalyptic images of the end of the climate world, while endothing and funding migration processes—sometimes even illegal—to Europe with the population excuse. In Europe in general, and especially in my country – Spain – there is a genuine social emergency in terms of birthplace, but it seems that large globalist corporations are only interested in Europeans still consuming, spending and paying taxes. No birth, no strong families, if European nations do not initiate birth control processes and plans with financial aid, tax discounts, tax credits; if we do not take the decision to stop emptying the pockets of European families so that they can make them bigger, all the social and economic progress that is being worked on in this Parliament is going to become a vile deception.

name: Pernando Barrena Arza (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, there have been episodes in recent weeks that seriously violate the linguistic rights of citizens of the Spanish State. Last week, in Navarra, higher court rulings have scorned the disrecognisement of the Basque language as merit—not as a requirement, as merit—while considering that languages such as English or German should be valued. Also, ten days ago, the Councillor of Culture of the Government of the Principality of Asturias was prevented from speaking in the Asturian language at the General Meeting of the Principality of Asturias, an unusual fact wherever there are.  These actions are not in conformity with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which, in Article 21 there is, provides that any discrimination exercised on the reason of language is prohibited, so, as the Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe has already done, it is necessary to continue to urge the Spanish State to implement the European Charter of Minority Languages and the Resolution of this Parliament on linguistic diversity. The plurality of Europe is defended from the identity and language of each of the Europeans; and we are talking about rights, not choosing the most powerful language, because then we would only keep one, which is precisely the one that leaves the Union, it seems, on the thirties and one.

name: Martin Sonneborn (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I have here an open letter that 10 000 mad scientists, including nineteen Nobel laureates, have written to Mrs von der Leyen. Unfortunately unfranked, that's probably why he didn't reach them at all – so a second delivery attempt in this way. Von der Leyen's advisers have inadvertently removed science and education from the EU Commission's portfolio. And she didn't even notice it, because she's just looking for the rough-fibre wallpaper for the new penthouse that she can install in the commission building. Now this content is assigned to the strange area of Innovation and Youth. At a time when students take to the streets every Friday with the demand to finally take note of the findings of science. I would find it more innovative and younger, downright funky and, by the way, more promising if the old woman were to undo the blatant nonsense. Smiley.

name: Радан Кънев (PPE).
text: – Mr President, in Bulgaria the election of a Chief Prosecutor with virtually uncontrolled powers is imminent, with a seven-year term without the possibility of his early termination. The only candidate for this position in his program attacks the principle of separation of powers and threatens the independence of the court. No less alarming are the trends of pressure on the media. Pressure, once, to present only the indictment in specific cases and thus become a party to the criminal process. And secondly, pressure on the media to fire Bulgarian journalists critical of the prosecutor's office. Pressure that led to an unprecedented event for the last 100 years: suspension of the broadcast of the Bulgarian national public radio. Such a choice would be a sign of an institutional crisis. And I am very worried that this will unleash a wave of iniquity in my homeland. A problem that is not mine is not only Bulgarian, but is pan-European.

name: Alicia Homs Ginel (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the bankruptcy of Thomas Cook has had serious consequences for the tourism sector in Europe and, in particular, for the islands of Spain – the Balearic Islands and the Canary Islands – and has affected thousands of workers, tourists and entrepreneurs. Its most immediate consequences have been an advanced season finale in many hotels, which has caused seasonal workers to see their wage forecasts shortened by one to three months, a situation that directly and negatively affects many families. Having said that, I believe that the rapid action of the Government of Spain and in particular the Government of my region, the Balearic Islands, which, after the Canary Islands, has been the second region most affected by bankruptcy, must be valued. Real and direct solutions to large problems are the kind of help that citizens expect from institutions. In this sense, the European institutions must put our batteries on. Thomas Cook's bankruptcy, unfortunately, not only affects Spain, and not all states have the same, especially economic, capacity to deal with such situations. We need common solutions to common problems and thus demonstrate the added value of the European project.

name: Antony Hook (Renew).
text: – Mr President, I have important economic news. Between now and Saturday, 19 October 2019, sales of walking shoes are rocketing, because on that day in London will be a people’s march to demand a people’s vote – from Park Lane to Parliament Square – for the majority who want to stop Brexit.  Some Brexiteers want Britain to sleepwalk into a no-deal Brexit. They confuse with lies, they use money from hedge funds, the values of Trump and Twitter bots in Russia, but we are wide-awake, full of hope and free from fear.  We will not let Brexit wreck our economy, damage our NHS or pollute our environment. We will not let Johnson or Farage tell their lies again, because on 19 October, we march for our children’s future.  (Applause)

name: Gilles Lebreton (ID).
text: Mr President, Facebook has decided to create its cryptocurrency, the libra, with 28 partners including VISA and MasterCard as well as the internet platforms Uber and Booking. The board of directors of this Libra association will be appointed in Geneva on 14 October. Three dangers arise from the creation of this cryptocurrency. The first danger is that it poses a risk to the stability of the financial system and to monetary sovereignty. With more than 2 billion users, Facebook will be fiercely competitive with national currencies, as well as the euro - especially since the libra is completely flexible to use since it is not governed by any monetary and financial code. Second, this flexibility will also make the libra an ideal instrument of money laundering, as the U.S. Central Bank has not failed to point out. Finally, third danger, the libra will not offer any reliable protection of users' personal data. For these three reasons, I warn the European Parliament against the complacency shown by Mrs Lagarde, Director of the ECB, with regard to this new currency. We must fight the libra, which is nothing but a private currency seeking to supplant public currencies.

name: Sandra Pereira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the emphasis on regional asymmetries is undeniable. We regret the depopulation and desertification of the interior of a country like mine, Portugal, but we must assume that aging, impoverishment and depopulation of the interior have no natural causes.  The explanation lies in policies contrary to the balanced development of the country and the interest of the population, such as deindustrialization, lack of support for family farming, the absence of incentives to the fixing of populations. Schools, health centres, public services are closed in the name of budgetary impositions and public investment is limited because of the deficit.  It is clear to us that policies for the enhancement of the interior must necessarily go through another budget and Multiannual Financial Framework that strengthens and does not cut cohesion funds and improves the absorption of these funds, by a profound modification of the CAP, which protects and values local and family agriculture, by valuing national production and by supporting the productive sectors , the modernisation and valorisation of rail transport and the road network and the recognition of people who, despite adversity, continue to resist and live in land.

name: Rupert Lowe (NI).
text: – Mr President, Nicholas Kaldor presciently predicted, of the Mitterrand-inspired Werner Plan in 1969, that rather than bringing Europe together, the single currency would tear Europe apart. Floating currencies allow appreciation and depreciation to adjust smoothly for differing economic and cultural circumstances. Borrowing is kept proportionate in weaker economies. Only quantitative easing, or as I prefer to call it ‘getting high on your own supply’, keeps the euro alive. It will continue to grind the weaker economies into poverty, causing unnecessary hardship for millions of Europeans. The sleep of reason produces monsters. Europe has created a true monster in its desire for a post-war European super-state. Anti-capitalist negative interest rates will turn the coming economic downturn into a catastrophe. Britain must leave this failing project before the roof falls in and show other European countries how they can save themselves.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE).
text: – Mr President. Ladies and gentlemen. In 2016, the citizens of Great Britain expressed their willingness to leave the European Union. It's their right. However, the role of British state institutions is to carry out this will and, as we can see, they are not doing well. The two governments that emerged after the referendum were unable to bring this agreement to the table. I want to stress that we are always ready to negotiate with the UK and if the Government in London is not ready to leave, we can conclude a deferral agreement with it. However, we need to hear a clear position. We either leave or we stay, or we ask for time to think. Unfortunately, we are not getting that from London. In any case, we will always protect the rights of our citizens who work, study, live in Britain. Whichever way Brexit goes, our principles will remain clear. And I believe that, despite the current chaos in the UK, it is in the mutual interest of us to find a way together and not from each other in every situation.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the British company Vesuvius recently announced the closure of two of its plants in Spain, one of them in my region, Asturias, and fired more than one hundred workers. A difficult decision to understand, when these plants operate with benefits, they have flexible working relationships and there are no objective indicators that can explain this decision.  I would like to remind Vesuvius that, in Europe, there is a social market economy and that business decisions must be based on mutual loyalty between workers and the company.  And for that reason I would like to send a direct message to Vesuvius: 'You should open negotiations now with the workers and with the public administration. Otherwise I will be here in the European Parliament following all of your activities and studying all of your requests for European money.'

name: Yana Toom (Renew).
text: – Mr President, ‘United in Diversity’ is probably the most famous European slogan. Diversity has many dimensions – one of them is linguistic diversity – of which we also pretend to take care. But we’re systematically overlooking the fact that some Member States are making efforts to assimilate their minorities. During the accession period of my native Estonia and neighbouring Latvia, we received a list of recommendations concerning the Russian-speaking population. The main focus was on better integration of these people.  However, 15 years later, the ruling coalition in Latvia is preparing for a full transition to the Latvian language in education, starting next year – but with 30% of the population being Russian speakers – despite the protests, and despite the fact that forced assimilation is clearly forbidden by international law.  We’re not in the accession process anymore, so we can violate the rights of national minorities and nothing will happen. Europe has more important issues to solve. But colleagues, violation of human rights is violation of human rights, even if it takes place in the European Union. Before we go and strongly condemn somebody, let’s look in the mirror.

name: Claire Fox (NI).
text: – Mr President, on the 70th anniversary of the Chinese regime, it’s difficult to celebrate, with the backdrop of hundreds of thousands of heroic democracy protesters in Hong Kong facing ever-escalating repression. Yet still they march, because they believe in sovereignty and democratic rights. Many MEPs here cheer on these democratic warriors, and rightly so.  And yet the EU itself thwarts democratic spirit closer to home: look at the brutal and violent treatment meted out to the gilets jaunes at the behest of President Macron. Here, there’s not a murmur of outrage at France or emergency debates, and it’s ignored by the European mainstream media. And, closer to my heart: the EU cheers on Hong Kong democrats, and yet millions of UK citizens use their democratic vote to leave the EU and reclaim their sovereignty and this Parliament – too many in here – traduce, insult and demonise those voters, and even try to block their democratic decision. Well, just as the Hong Kong authorities are fought back against, we’ll will fight back too. Just as the Hong Kong authorities blocked the Umbrella Revolution, you block us. You can talk the talk, but you need to walk the walk. I show solidarity with the Hong Kong protesters, the gilets jaunes, and, of course, Brexit voters.  (Applause from certain quarters)

name: Traian Băsescu (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the Mediterranean has become a graveyard for thousands of people. It is inadmissible for the European Union not to take measures to protect people's lives, content only to make statistics with thousands of children, women, men whom the waters of the Mediterranean Sea swallow every year. We need to gain knowledge and neutralise the trafficking networks in the countries of origin and the countries of boating illegal migrants on ships. We must use the naval means available to the Member States of the Union to return boats carrying illegal migrants from the limit of the territorial waters of the landing states.  I call on the European Commission to draw up and submit to Parliament an action plan, as a matter of urgency, a proposal for a regulation on illegal migration from third countries, which by adoption will become applicable throughout the Union.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, this week is European Week of Action for Girls, when we call on EU Member States and institutions to better protect and champion the rights of girls. It’s our duty to ensure that every single girl – not only in the EU, but around the world – has access to quality education, healthcare and job opportunities, and is able to enjoy a life where they are truly equal. But sadly, these are universal rights that millions are still denied. We must demand that gender equality and the empowerment of women and girls continues to be a top priority in the EU’s international cooperation and development policies. We must dismantle patriarchal social norms that have been formed and cemented over generations, as well as challenging and changing discriminatory laws. We must recognise that intersectionality and structural inequalities are significant factors that impact negatively on the economic, social and political lives of girls and women and their meaningful participation. I stand with all feminist brothers and sisters who are fighting for true equality.

name: Irena Joveva (Renew).
text: – Mr President, the College of Commissioners is expected to decide on the proposal for Croatia's entry into Schengen shortly before the end of the mandate. While this date is now being stalled again, it may say something, but I will not speculate, of course I cannot predict the decision in advance, unlike some who are already explaining how Juncker has promised them the green light of his outgoing Commission and how Slovenia will then block them from the path and how it is wrong. However, this has not yet been decided at this level. The question now is, above all, whether Croatia is indeed technically qualified and flawless in securing the Union's external border. While it has no regulated borders with most neighbours, let me remind you, the border with Slovenia is fixed and regulated by arbitration. Once again: Slovenia supports the enlargement of Schengen under the conditions that all safety and technical requirements are met, that this does not pose a security threat to the Union, that democratic and legal standards are respected.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, on this day, that is, still 9 October, I am going out of my way to recall what happened 30 years ago.  It was on these october days that the Berlin Wall began to collapse. On October 7, as some comrades in the GDR celebrated the 40th anniversary of the founding of the socialist German Democratic State, thousands of their fellow citizens left through the Prague embassy of the Federal Republic of Germany to West Germany. Basically, it was the beginning when the Berlin Wall shook to the ground. It was actually a small migration wave of 15,000 people.  On 12 October, this EP passed a resolution in 1989, from which I would like to quote. "The EP calls on the government to start the democratisation process and end the police repression against its own people." Even then, the EP remembered human rights, and we must also remember today. It's our duty, our legacy.

name: Milan Brglez (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to draw attention to the danger of a certain normalisation of the idea of protecting the European way of life. He assumes that he is being threatened by someone from the outside and that he must be defended against strangers. The consequences are already visible – border protection is underway with gross violations of asylum law and human rights. It is impossible to submit applications, there is a chain of returns and police violence. Switzerland has even halted the return of refugees and migrants to join the Schengen area because of judicially vetted human rights violations. European leaders, however, are silent on this. However, it is not and should not become a European way of life. This is determined by the values set out in Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union. These values should also be highlighted as important in the naming of the areas of work of the European institutions, including the Commission, and as a key political criterion for Schengen membership.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, for one minute, I have chosen the subject of forestry and the state of forests in Europe. In the face of climate change, we underestimate forests that have not only an economic function, but also an environmental function.  However, forests are not in good shape in Europe. Unfortunately, we lack a comprehensive Europe-wide strategy precisely for forests that member states would implement. Of course, the basic responsibility for the state of forests lies with the Member States, after all, the primary law does not actually speak of forestry at all.  The EU should quickly help Member States to address the current situation, e.g. bark beetles, of course disasters, to motivate afforestation and, in general, to motivate good forest management. In cooperation with the Member States, we must clearly give priority to forests, because forests are our future.

name: Петър Витанов (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we as the European Parliament should be consistent in our support for the European perspective of the Western Balkan countries, as the accession process is a key driver for reform and stability in the region. I therefore welcome the European Commission's recommendation to open pre-accession negotiations with both the Republic of North Macedonia and the Republic of Albania. Over the past few years, Europe's focus has shifted from integration to security, making the region a target of struggle. This risks fighting for the Western Balkans instead of integrating the Western Balkans. The start of the negotiations represents a credible impetus for the Republic of North Macedonia and Albania, which will stop the erosion of our greatest resource, namely the European Union's commitment to these countries, and close the way to other geopolitical factors in the region. At the same time, however, the opening of negotiations must be seen as a guarantee of membership and as a driving force for accelerating reforms, strengthening the rule of law and maintaining good neighbourly relations. name: Mónica Silvana González (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it is very important to fulfil the commitment and to develop the International Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and to enforce to all Member States, but also to regional governments, their obligation, as responsible, to guarantee these rights to all persons on an equal footing. In the Community of Madrid, one of the richest and most competitive communities in Europe, but also more unequal, hundreds of deaf students have started the course without sign language interpreters, which is essential to ensure schooling on an equal footing. It is a clear lack of inclusion in the education system. But also many deaf people cannot access health care, nor can they go to make administrative arrangements because this service of interpreters is not guaranteed, and this is due to the job precariousness of the service and the defaults of the Government of the People's Party of the Community of Madrid. The inclusion of persons with disabilities must be guaranteed in every corner of Europe. Let's work for it.

name: Isabel Carvalhais (S&D).
text: – Mr President, thank you very much to all the resistant and especially to the interpreters who can stand here. I feel like "me, myself and I." On October 2, the Azores archipelago in Portugal was severely hit by Hurricane Lorenzo that left a destruction stun block on several islands. Despite enormous local efforts, material damage, both public and private, is very high. The damage is extensive, seriously affecting ports, coastal communication routes, private housing, among other infrastructure.  This occurrence is of particular relevance, considering the insular and archipelagic character of this region. I would remind you that the Azores are one of the outermost regions specifically mentioned in Article 349 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, due to its structural constraints.  European solidarity and support must therefore be guaranteed to the region at this difficult time by supporting local authorities in their reconstruction efforts and in helping local people, support that should be agile, effective and efficient.
